The bond market thrashed about inconclusively in yesterday's session as dealers awaited developments from the House Ways and Means Committee on the Administration's incometax surcharge plan.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 30 (AP)--An all-United States final was set up today in the women's doubles in the Victorian tennis championships.
AMERICAN Ballet Theater was the first company, apart from Britain's Royal Ballet, to show any interest in the young Scottish choreographer Kenneth MacMillan.
PARIS, Nov. 29--The Grand Rabbi of France, Jacob Kaplan, accused President de Gaulle today of anti-Semitism.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) --Assistant Secretary of labor Thomas R. Donahue says that Government officials are considering proposals to assure workers against losing earned pension credits when they leave a job.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov. 29--The Securities and Exchange Commission has formed a high-level group to study the effectiveness of Federal laws that aim to make sure investors get the information they need to buy and sell stocks and bonds.
TIME rolls back and nostalgia takes over in a newly opened shop called the Sybarites, at 221 East 60th Street, where the stock in trade are decorative and personal goodies of pre-World War I vintage.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29-- It was "a day in the life of Solel," as their rabbi called it, and by and large they were glad they had come although they did not think they had accomplished much if anything.

KATHY KUSNER, perhaps the world's finest equestrienne, recently applied for a jockey's license in Maryland. Horse racing officials retreated coolly with a promise to discuss the application next month, and Miss Kusner's lady lawyer promised the inevitable "on to the Supreme Court if necessary."
ROME, Nov. 29 (AP)--Pope Paul VI has given his first gift of the Christmas season today to the Palestine refugees.
LONDON, Nov. 29--In a major shift of power in the Labor Government and a move toward new policies, Roy Jenkins became Chancellor of the Exchequer today.
BUDAPEST, Nov. 29 (Reuters)--Former Premier Ferenc Munnich died here today at the age of 81 after a life spent fighting for Communism.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 29-- Mr. and Mrs. Albert Bruce Crutcher Jr. have announced the engagement of Mrs. Crutcher's daughter, Miss Priscilla Eaves, to Alfred Lee Loomis 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Loomis Jr. of Cove Neck, Oyster Bay, L.I.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UPI)--The space agency an nounced today that would eliminate 1,704 jobs, 5 per cent of its total force, because of Congressional budget cuts.
LONDON, Nov. 29--A Pissarro worth $48,000 was among five paintings missing today from the Tonbridge, Kent, home of Sir Henry D'Avigdor Goldsmid, a Conservative member of Parliament.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29-- The Organization of American States failed today on its fourth effort to elect a new secretary general. Acting on a Brazilian suggestion, the delegates agreed to postpone the next ballot until early next year.
TOKYO, Nov. 29--The police announced today that a Foreign Ministry official and a North Korean had been arrested for espionage.
FLORENCE, Italy, Nov. 29 --The Duke of Aosta, confined to bed with an ankle injury, will be unable to attend the Imperial Ball in New York tomorrow, it was learned tonight.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 29--North Vietnam's army newspaper has predicted that American and North Vietnamese troops will be embroiled in "savage" fighting in the next few months.
The American University of Beirut announced yesterday that it had completed six years of tests on a protein-rich diet supplement and was looking for a commercial producer of the substance.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29-- The House rejected today an attempt to speed into law a meat inspection bill designed to guarantee consumers wholesome meat.
TEL AVIV, Nov. 29--The Israeli Army issued gunpowder to Moslems in the occupied part of Jordon. Israelis today were then not to be alarmed by the cannon blasts.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 29--Suffering from a staggering variety of ailments, India's stateowned steel industry is looking abroad for ideas on what it can do to nurse itself to health.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 --The Senate voted today to increase postal rates, effective in early January after the Christmas mail rush.

ABOUT 27,000 pieces of what may be the most eagerly sought, and dullest, reading matter in the vast literature of the dog are being received this week by exhibitors in all parts of the country.

HOUSTON, Nov. 29 (AP)-- The Houston Mavericks withstood a fourth quarter rally by the Oakland Oaks for a 102-91 victory in an American Basketball Association game tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29-- A sociological study denied today that young Jews seeking business careers were in too much of a hurry for success to become corporation executives.

New York City's Police Department is making more arrests than ever. But its record in solving reported crimes--in comparison with the rest of the nation and its own past reports --is clouded.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 29-- The smoking of marijuana has been increasing so rapidly among Westchester teen-agers that it now is a major hazard to public health and law enforcement, narcotics experts told 200 educators and county officials here today.
Last night's program of harness racing at Yonkers Raceway and three afternoon thoroughbred racing cards were canceled because of the storm along the Eastern Seaboard.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 30 The 800 students of Kentucky Southern College were jubilant today after having won their fight to keep the six-year-old school from being absorbed by the University of Louisville, a metropolitan institution with 8,250 full and part-time students.
The state agency that enforces the Taylor Law the legislation governing strikes by public employes has decided to cancel the dues checkoff privileges of the United Federation of Teachers in the city.
Drastic increases in fines and jail sentences for those convicted of illegal dumping were approved yesterday by the City Council's Committee on Health and Education.

Milton Babbitt's "Philomel" was dropped from the opening program of the New Image of Sound series at Hunter College last night because of the illness of the soprano, Bethany Beardslee. That left the field open, appropriately, to two big works (about 40 minutes each) new to New York, Eric Salzman's "Verses and Cantos" and Luciano Berio's "Laborintus II."
DUBLIN, Nov. 30 Patrick Kavanagh, a leading Irish poet, playwright and journalist, died today at a Dublin nursing home at the age of 62.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP)--President Johnson's special representative for trade negotiations predicted today a hard fight but ultimate victory next year for the Administration over rising protectionist sentiment in Congress.

WNDT (Channel 13)won five of the nine local Emmy Awards presented yesterday by the New York Chapter of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences for outstanding achievement in television.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 A new focus of scientific attention is emerging to help unify research into the underlying cause of most American deaths.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 30 Mrs. Helen Dominick Smith, widow of United States Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican of New Jersey, died today of a heart attack at her home at 81 Alexander Street. She was 87 years old. Her husband, who died in 1966, was Senator from Dec. 7, 1944 to Jan. 3, 1959.

BONN, Nov. 30 West Germany's grand coalition of the dominant Christian Democratic Union and Social Democratic parties will mark its first year in power tomorrow.
OSWESTRY, England, Nov. 30 Tom Boyer Jones, a farmer whose dairy herd gave 200 gallons of milk a day last week, had to have four pints delivered to his house this morning by a friend.
DETROIT, Nov. 30 The General Motors Corporation today recalled 2,857 of its 1968 Chevrolet cars for possible safety defects.

A 22-year-old Inca from Bolivia, who was born without arms or legs, is returning to his native country to take a job as a computer programer after 12 years of rehabilitation here.

Leaders of the antidraft movement announced yesterday that they would try to "close down" the Manhattan armed forces induction center next week. It will be part of a concerted effort to force a "legal confrontation" with the Government over the war in Vietnam.

The Bangor Punta Corporation disclosed yesterday that it had made an offer to buy all of the outstanding common stock of the Producers Cotton Oil Company. The transaction would involve an estimated $28-million in cash and securities.

A Puerto Rican insurance investigator, a Negro clergyman and a white lawyer were honored yesterday for helping the disadvantaged and bringing about better relations between minority and majority groups.

A collection of Chinese porcelains and French furniture belonging to Winston Frederick Churchill Guest, the steel heir and sportsman, will be auctioned tomorrow at 1:45 P.M. at the Parke-Bernet Galleries.

The Interstate Commerce Commisson reversed itself yesterday and sanctioned the merger of three big Western railroads, which it had rejected 19 months ago as not being in the public interest.
DALLAS, Nov. 30 Texas Instruments, Inc., said today that beginning Jan. 1, all full-time employes now paid by the hour would be paid regular salaries.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 W.H. Auden, the prolific and prize-winning poet, essayist and playwright, received the third annual National Medal for Literature today at the Smithsonian Institution's Museum of History and Technology.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1--The District of Columbia's new municipal government, in office four weeks, made its first important moves today to reduce crime.

MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 1-- Sol Wachtler, the Republican who lost the race for Nassau County Executive by 2,863 votes last month, said today he had decided to "leave politics" and seek an appointment to the State Supreme Court.

To sit in some of the newest chairs and sofas feels like being enveloped by a mattress. To lift these chunky cubes is a lightweight surprise. To punch their sponky sides, backs and seats is a shock -- they bounce back.

President de Gaulle's press conference this week suggests once again that as his years increase, so do his ambitions, his illusions and also his cynicism. The aging general's private fantasies, it now appears, envision France re-established as a Continental power in the Western Hemisphere, and elevated to the status of a major oil producer in the Middle East--two changes to be accomplished with the help of blatant antiCanadian and anti-Semitic propaganda.

Eastern Airlines and Trans World Airlines have agreed to join forces to maintain, overhaul and train crews for Boeing 747's and other new planes.

Elderly people have written to express their gratitude that they were no longer facing burial among the unknowns in Potter's Field on Hart Island. In the past this was the fate of those who died while on relief. Now the city provides a special burial allowance.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 3--Truong Dinh Dzu, the peace candidate who came in a surprise second in the presidential elections in September, said today that he would formally protest to Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker over his twomonth house arrest.

As Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, Francis Cardinal Spellman was a conservative and a traditionalist in a see that has historically been an anchor of conservatism in the American church. For nearly three decades the nation's most powerful Catholic prelate, he exercised his formal authority and personal influence on behalf of the familiar and the narrowly orthodox. But if he was no friend of innovation, neither was he an implacable enemy of change.
United States Senator Jacob K. Javits and John J. Burns, Democratic state chairman, said yesterday that the 1968 election would turn on the Vietnam war.

A note of anxiety over increased charges of airlines at airports throughout the world is sounded in the 1967 "state of the industry" report to the International Air Transportation Association from its Director General, Knut Hammarskjold.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3 (UPI)--Gale Sayers scored three touchdowns today, two on runbacks of 97 and 58 yards, to carry the Chicago Bears to a 28-14 victory over the San Francisco 49ers before a rainsoaked crowd of 25,613.

WYCKOFF, N. J., Dec. 3-- In the Wyckoff Reformed Church today, Miss Pamela Toll, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Toll, was married to Francis Xavier Gina Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Gina of New York and Southold, L. I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Wilbur L. De Revere.
IF you built a house with your own two hands at the age of 13, what do you do for encores?
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 3--Steel producers are expected to support the price increase announced last Friday for coldrolled sheet.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3 (AP)--A cable car lost its grip in a driving rain tonight, hurtled down steep Hyde Street and rammed an automobile broadside at the Bay Street intersection.

The rich, but long overlooked field of Latin American literature is slowly coming to life on American university campuses, according to Jorge Luis Borges, the Argentine poet, short-story writer and essayist.

It is strange that Britain's devaluation of the pound has provoked so little debate in this country about American Government policy regarding the dollar.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3--By his decision to enter the Massachusetts Presidential primary, Senator Eugene J. McCarthy has created some tough problems for President Johnson, Senator Edward M. Kennedy and the state Democratic organization.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Dec. 3-- Daryle Lamonica befuddled the San Diego Chargers with four touchdown passes today in leading the Oakland Raiders to a 41-21 victory before a record San Diego crowd of 52,661.

Mayor Lindsay's proposals for constitutional reform deserve more consideration from the Legislature than they are likely to receive. At his request four amendments have been prefiled for consideration at the next session. They embody three recommendations which were largely disregarded by the Constitutional Convention and a fourth not even proposed there.

WENATCHEE, Wash., Dec. 3 --Maj. Gen. Guy V. Henry, U.S.A., retired, former chief of cavalry and a veteran of three wars, died here Wednesday. He was 92 years old and had lived until recently in Kenwood, Chevy Chase, Md.

ATLANTA, Dec. 3--Gov. Lester G. Maddox of Georgia, a man who blushes easily, may have flashed an especially red face recently after the disclosure of a letter setting forth some views hugely offensive to the state's powerful textile interests.
Eight children, ranging in age from 4 months to 6 years, died yesterday in two fires, in Brooklyn and Manhattan.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 3 (AP)--The Thai Government has accused some American publications of writing "malicious and scandalous" articles on Thailand.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 3--A Skye terrier, Ch. Glamoor Go Go Go, gained a distinction no other dog ever can claim tonight at the Boardwalk Kennel Club's show in Convention Hall. He became the first best-inshow winner of the event because the club never had held one before.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 3 (AP)-- The Kansas City Chiefs rallied from a 13-6 half-time deficit for a 23-13 victory over the Buffalo Bills today behind the receiving of Otis Taylor and the running of Mike Garrett.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 3.--An axiom of pro football is that only two or three plays out of the 140 or so in every game make the difference between winning and losing.

Carl Ruggles's granitic "Sun Treader" opened the concert of the American Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. Leopold Stokowski conducted and he drew glorious, rich sonorities from the orchestra. The hall swam with sound during the work's magnificent climaxes.

The Mayor and New York's finest appear at odds over how many police are needed to make the city's streets safe. The Mayor wants to hold the number at the present authorized strength--28,228 men. Some police officials believe that to do the job properly requires another 5,000 men spread around the city.

THE contradictions of American life, the bewildering galaxy of pluses and minuses that can please and distress, was vividly reported upon last night by the National Broadcasting Company news department in an absorbing pictorial illustration of John Steinbeck's book "America and Americans."

One of the world's newest nations, Israel, is the inheritor of one of the world's oldest, folk traditions. Sophie Maslow entwined a meaningful selection of both elements in the four dances she choreographed for the Hanukkah Festival for Israel at Madison Square Garden last night.

MISSOULA, Mont., Dec. 3- It is not easy to reach this isolated university town in the snow-covered hills of western Montana, and once here the political cares of Washington and the East seem far away. But they press in, nevertheless, and the state's politicians are already trying to anticipate their impact.
The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation has been sold on four winners of the 1967 Guggenheim International Award.
Interest rates on high-grade bonds continued to climb yesterday, reaching levels not equaled in American corporate history.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) The Federal Government may recover from shipowners the costs of removing negligently sunken vessels from navigable waterways, the Supreme Court ruled 8 to 0 today.

Dr. Fulton Cutting, a pioneer in the development of radio, died yesterday in his home at 15 East 88th Street. He would have been 81 years old on Dec. 27.

The American-Scandinavian Foundation's student exchange program will benefit from the proceeds of the New York chapter's traditional Christmas Ball on Dec. 14 in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre Hotel.
Crowds that reached the rate of 3,600 persons an hour filed past the purple-draped funeral bier of Cardinal Spellman yesterday as his body lay in state in the nave of St. Patrick's Cathedral.
A Transit Authority train dispatcher who decided to "make an issue" of his beard has won a legal battle with his employer.

ST. MICHAELS, Md., Dec. 4 William Littlewood, a former vice president of American Airlines and a developer of the DC-3 airliner that revolutionized air travel when it appeared in 1936, died at his home here last night. He was 69 years old.
MOSCOW, Dec. 4 This is Monday, but Moscow took its Sunday leisure today under bright winter sunshine that made the fresh snow glisten and strollers smile.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 4--The President of Cyprus, Archbishop Makarios, said today that guarantees against military intervention in Cyprus should be insured through the United Nations Security Council.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 William McChesney Martin Jr., the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said tonight that the United States "must not bow down to the idol of gold" as the only discipline against inflationary national economic policy.

Cy Feuer and Ernest Martin, Broadway producers, brought suit in New York State Supreme Court yesterday to cancel the sale of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus to Irvin and Israel Feld and Roy M. Hofheinz.

A group of angry parents broke through police barricades and tried to force their way into a Bronx school yesterday to protest the transfer of their children to schools in other neighborhoods. It was the second time in less than a week that they had defied the police.

WASHINGTON, Dec.4--A sign over the door said "DeQuincey's," and in smaller lettering, "Suppliers to the White House since 1800." An old-fashioned bell tinkled in the rear of the shop as the door opened. It was pleasant inside.
Lewis Einstein, a retired American diplomat, an art collector and man of letters, died yesterday at his home in Paris at the age of 90.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 A yearlong search begun by the Federal Government to find new sources of funds for home mortgages was said today to have produced a shower of ideas but no flood of money.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 4 The Nassau Board of Supervisors will adopt a 1968 county budget providing for a tax reduction of about 25 cents for each $100 of assessed valuation.

Swinging Mood of the Harbor view Farm responded in the stretch to take the feature event at Aqueduct yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 4 Sir John Hobson, Attorney General in the former Conservative Government of Harold Macmillan, died here today following brain surgery last Friday. He was 55 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4--The initial success of the first heart transplantation yesterday in Capetown, South Africa, dramatizes a situation that is already a cause of concern to many doctors--the shortage of organs for transplant.

After having read pages of stylized, colorless reports of what happened in Boston Sunday night, President Clarence Campbell will levy at least $1,275 in fines today on 25 National Hockey League players.

Teledyne, Inc., is planning to expand into the metals field through the proposed acquisition of Rodney Metals, Inc. for stock worth about $38-million. An agreement in principle was reached yesterday by George A. Roberts, Teledyne president, and Martin Barell, chairman of Rodney Metals.

Arthur A. Houghton Jr., president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, announced yesterday that a "small group of the museum's intimate friends" and the museum itself had purchased, as rumored last Friday, a painting by Claude Monet sold at a London auction for $1,411,200.
A convicted bank robber demanded and got $50 a month for his wife before agreeing to be a key state witness in the murder trial of John (Sonny) Franzese, it was disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 4 A slowdown by locomotive engineers cut into British rail services today, especially in the heavy commuter traffic south of London.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 The Supreme Court agreed today to decide if community antenna television systems are guilty of copyright infringement when they relay to their subscribers television broadcasts that include copyrighted films.

The city's License Department announced yesterday a relaxation of restrictions on sidewalk cafes that will permit them to stay open later and operate on a year-round basis. It is hoped the new rules will encourage proliferation of such cafes.

Two exporters entered pleas of not guilty in the Southern District Court yesterday to a 72-count indictment charging them with conspiring to violate the nation's foreign trade laws.
LONDON, Dec. 6--Britain plans to make travel by publicly-owned buses as attractive as private motoring. This is part of a reorganization of public transportation announced this week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--A Federal judicial center designed to modernize the operation of the United States court system was approved by the House of Representatives today and sent to the White House for the President's signature.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 6-- Oren Lee Staley, president of the militant National Farmers Organization, declared today that within 40 days his members would stop selling grain.
THE ukase of the tournament committee of the Interzonal Qualifying Tournment in Sousse, Tunisia, was simple, and sensational: "Fischer is officially and finally withdrawn."

The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit ruled yesterday that a lawyer is not permitted to be present at a guidance conference conducted by school officials concerning a student's suspension.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 6-- Harvard's hockey team scored four goals in the first nine minutes of the final period tonight in its own rink to break out of a 4-4 tie and forge one of the season's early surprises, 8-5, over previously unbeaten Boston University.
Dr. Bela Schick, the internationally renowned pediatrician who developed the Schick test for diphtheria, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 90 years old.
EGLIN AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., Dec. 6--A huge new radar that the Air Force says doubles the nation's capability to track friendly or hostile space objects was unveiled here today.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6-- Benton M. Spruance, the lithographer, died unexpectedly this morning at his home at 45 West Walnut Lane in Germantown. He was 63 years old.

Oscar Gestido reluctantly and belatedly undertook drastic measures to haul democratic Uruguay back from bankruptcy and chaos. It is tragic that death has removed him at 66 before this necessary program could show results to a skeptical country.
Stephen Porter, 42-year-old whitehaired staff director of the A.P.A.-Phoenix Repertory Company for the last five years, woke up yesterday to savor the sweet aroma of his first dramatic hit.

THERE was plenty of sparkle yesterday in Schen ley Industries and satellites of Rapid-American Corporation. The splash grew out of recharged rumors of merger talks between Glen Alden and Schenley. Rapid-American controls Glen Alden through a 56 per cent interest in McCrory, which, in turn, owns about 50 per cent of Glen Alden.
CHILMARK, Mass., Dec. 6-- "I only buy long-line swordfish if I can go aboard the vessel and pick them out," says Everett Poole, owner of Poole's Fish Market here at Menemsha Bight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6-- President Johnson appealed directly to a group of the nation's top business executives today to hold the line on price increases.

The status of Aldo T. (Buff) Donelli as Columbia football coach remained in doubt yesterday as discussions concerning his reappointment continued within the university administration. A decision is expected within a day or two on whether or not Donelli's one-year appointment will be renewed for the 11th consecutive year.

The International Minerals Chemical Corp., in another move to expand into the consumer products field, is planning to acquire 120-year-old Morton International, Inc., popularly known for its Morton salt.

BOSTON, Deb. 6 (AP)--Sam Jones scored 12 of his 27 points in a last-period surge tonight that carried the first place Boston. Celtics to a 115-113 National Basketball Association victory over the New York Knicks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6--A new Government survey of business plans for investment in new plant and equipment shows that such spending may rise by close to 7 per cent next year, compared with an increase of only 1 per cent this year.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 6--Although now in the midst of harvesting the best crop she has ever seen, India is counting on receiving as much food aid in the first six months of 1968 as she did in the corresponding period this year, when famine threatened.
WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 6--A State Supreme Court justice paved the way today for the burning of thousands of big trees and some houses in the way of new superhighways in Westchester County.
CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP)-- An unforeseen circumstance poses a threat to the success of a human heart transplantation in South Africa, the leader of the team that performed the surgery reported today.

OTTAWA, Dec. 6--Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson won overwhelming political support in Ottawa today for a Government report calling for true equality for Canada's citizens by officially placing the French and English languages on an even footing.
Cora Baird, who operated a puppet theater with her husband that delighted adults and children around the world, died at New York Hospital last night after a long illness.
Bond prices rose for the second straight day, trading activity picked up and new bond issues sold quickly as the market's buoyancy that developed Tuesday continued yesterday.

SAIGON; South Vietnam, Dec. 6--A Vietcong force using flamethrowers and hand grenades was reported to have killed more than 100 civilians and to have burned and wounded at least 100 more yesterday in an attack on a hamlet 74 miles northeast of Saigon.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 6--Organized labor's high command began a drive today to raise a special strike fund to aid the United Steelworkers of America and 21 other affiliates involved in the long copper strike.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 6--Union Miniere du Haut Katanga, the big Belgian copper producer whose properties in Katanga were expropriated by the Congolese Government 11 months ago, announced today a major diversification move in North America.

The city's Health Commissioner said yesterday that he had no intention of resigning, and the Hospitals Commissioner said that he had "no comment" on the recommendation of their former chief that the two Commissioners join him in quitting their posts.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 6 (AP)--Reports of an alleged plot to assassinate Gov. Winthrop Rockefeller were confirmed by the Governor today.

ABOUT three years ago a small group attending an obedience school decided that Atlantic City had been without an all-breed dog club long enough, so they organized the Boardwalk Kennel Club. Last Sunday the club achieved a goal.

Constantine Caramanlis may have fused the forces necessary to throw the military junta out of power in Greece. The former Premier's call on the junta leaders to quit; his description of them as "putschists," and his charge that "it does not enter their minds to re-establish democracy" have now been printed by all Athens daily newspapers in a spectacular backdown by Col. Papadopoulos, Brigadier Patakos and company.
The City Planning Commission yesterday presented a sharply reduced capital budget for the coming fiscal year.
ALBANY, Dec. 6--The State Tax Commissioner will recommend shortly a major expansion of outlets for the state lottery, ranging from barbershops and newsstands to department stores and supermarkets.
Undercurrents of strength, particularly in lower-priced issues, were present yesterday in a busy but generally indecisive stock market.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 6--Gov. Ronald Reagan said today that his visit to Yale University was giving him "an opportunity to correct some misconceptions" that he contended news accounts had created about his record and policies.
Three major American banks and one of Britain's leading merchant banking houses announced yesterday the formation in London of a new international bank.

THREE years ago, when Bill Bradley braced himself for Princeton home basketball games by listening to "Climb Every Mountain" from "The Sound of Music," it was considered neither flip nor, foolish to predict that he would be Governor of Missouri at 40.

LOUISVILLE, Dec. 6--Proposed open housing legislation, which caused racial demonstrations and disorders here last spring, has been introduced by the Louisville Board of Aldermen. It is expected to be approved.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 6 --Harvard University has joined a growing list of institutions whose undergraduates will be able to take one course each year marked only "Pass" or "Fail."

ROCHESTER, Dec. 6--Promotions of eight executives of newspapers in the Gannett Group were announced today by Paul Miller, president, at the annual meetings here of subsidiaries of the Gannett Company.
PABLO PICASSO arrived at the GiveBooks-for-Christmas Revels with the first Duchess of Marlborough, Cole Porter and Susan Sontag.
Vice President Humphrey will join ranking religious and civic leaders today at funeral services for Cardinal Spellman.

TRENTON, Dec. 6--The state Public Utility Tax Bureau reported today that the Jersey Central Power and Light Company had been paying taxes on a Burlington County electrical power substation to the wrong township.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 6--Rumania's Communist leader today coupled an announcement of radical party and administrative reforms with veiled charges that the Soviet Union and other Communist countries were not honoring long-term trade agreements.
The chain-store sector of the retailing industry moved ahead perceptively in November, according to reports of sales received yesterday from 15 chainstore operators.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) --A new oral anti-tuberculosis drug regarded as having a promising potential in treating the disease is now available for prescription by doctors and hospitals throughout the country.

Is technology going to destory our independence, our creativity or our environment? Several of the nation's scientific and intellectual leaders addressed themselves to this question yesterday and came up with some contradictory answers.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 6--The Acting Maritime Administrator, James Gulick, proposed today steps to improve productivity in the shipbuilding industry so as to make both ships and shipyards more competitive with their foreign counterparts.
Two young boys, both sons of policemen, followed a purse snatcher into a basement in Brooklyn yesterday, barricaded a door to keep him in a boiler room, then called the police, who arrested him.
ONE of the New York Jets is missing, except that he really isn't a Jet (but that's a long story) and maybe he isn't missing, but there's no one at grandma's house to shed any light.

A second attempt to transplant a human heart ended fatally at a Brooklyn hospital yesterday when an infant in whom surgeons had placed a heart from another baby boy died 6 hours after the intricate operation.
Old timers in the business could not recall yesterday the death of any actor as closely identified to a product as Bert Lahr was to Lay's Potato Chips.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6-- Arthur J. Goldberg has talked at least twice with President Johnson about leaving his post at the United Nations soon, but no definite arrangements appear to have been made.

As the three holdup men entered the front doors of the Maspeth, Queens, branch of the Bankers Trust Company last Friday morning, three bank tellers almost simultaneously pushed hidden buttons beneath their counters.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6-- Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, said today he might ask the Senate to reject the antipoverty bill approved yesterday by a conference committee.
The Twentieth Century Fund, a $27-million tax-exempt foundation with headquarters here, made a voluntary contribution of $10,000 to the city yesterday for the free municipal services it receives.

WAR is in danger of becoming a spectator sport. Do all people really distinguish between the soldiers being killed in the television newsreel and the Indians biting the dust on the "Late Late Show"? This I suspect ...

BONGSON, South Vietnam, Dec. 6--The commander of North Vietnam's Third Regiment was killed yesterday along with 16 other enemy soldiers in a sharp fight somewhat typical of the skirmishes that occur daily throughout South Vietnam, but particularly in the area assigned to the Army's only air cavalry division.
Secretary of State Dean Rusk said in an interview here yesterday that the State Department did not feel under pressure either to withdraw from Vietnam or "to escalate into a larger war."
CHICAGO, Dec. 6--The Johnson Administration threw its weight today behind abolition of the 6 per cent interest ceiling on Government-backed home mortgages.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 6-- The United States Inter national team for the 1968 world championships was knocked out of the Albert Morehead Cup competition here last night in one of biggest upsets in the history o fthe game.
Joel A. Winston, the former president of a defunct brokerage house, testified in Federal court here yesterday that he had lied frequently while under oath.

Record trading accompanied sharply lower prices for platinum futures yesterday--a weakness that has been noticeable lately as a reaction after a string of sharp price increases. Volume totaled 1,245 contracts, outpacing the previous peak of 1,150 traded on Monday.

Antidraft protesters clashing with the police in the second day of massive demonstrations over the Vietnam war were thrown back again yesterday in attempts to paralyze the armed forces induction center at 39 Whitehall Street.

Steel companies announced higher prices for major products yesterday for the fourth business day in succession. But the pattern was confused and uncertainty arose about whether some of the increases would be made to stick.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6-- Qualified sources confirmed today that a Vietcong agent arrested recently by the South Vietnamese police had been trying to reach American officials in Saigon.

Record trading accompanied sharply lower prices for platinum futures yesterday--a weakness that has been noticeable lately as a reaction after a string of sharp price increases. Volume totaled 1,245 contracts, outpacing the previous peak of 1,150 traded on Monday.

Presiding Justice Bernard Botein of the Appellate Division, First Department, has taken drastic action in suspending all civil trials in the Bronx for at least the month of January to cut the heavy backlog of criminal cases.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UPI)-- Legislation providing for $900million in higher postal rates and a pre-Christmas raise for two million Government workers was approved today by House and Senate negotiators.

World sugar futures attracted interest yesterday with another day of rising prices. The spot price also rose to 2.15 cents a pound, up from 2.05 on Wednesday on the stronger tone of the market. Volume moved at the healthy rate of 3,943 contracts.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 7--The unchallenged ascendency of Nicolae Ceausescu, the dynamic 49-year-old Rumanian Communist party leader, was confirmed today when he was asked to take over as head of state as well as retaining his party post.
Mayor Lindsay has asked Dr. Howard J. Brown to reconsider his resignation as the city's Health Services Administrator.

Conductors pass; orchestras endure. To symbolize this fact of musical life, the concert celebrating the 125th anniversary of the New York Philharmonic last night at Philharmonic Hall ended without a conductor.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 7 --A Poughkeepsie utility company was commended by the Hudson River Valley Commission today for a projected power plant that will have extensive landscaping, with trees and shrubs.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 7 --Labor leaders in industries facing major contract negotiations next year showed no disposition today to heed President Johnson's call for restraint in their wage demands.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7--The Treasury announced today a loss of $475-million of gold as an aftermath of the short-lived bout of gold speculation that followed devaluation of the British pound.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7--Many visitors come to Washington these days from overseas, but few with as cool and clear a mind or as steady an eye on the long future as Jean Monnet of France.

Antiwar demonstrators abandoned their effort to close down the armed forces induction center at 39 Whitehall Street early yesterday. They chose instead to take their protest to Manhattan streets clogged with rushhour traffic.
Paddy Chayefsky has agreed to write an original drama for the Columbia Broadcasting System's "C.B.S. Playhouse" series.

Some seven miles north of St. Patrick's Cathedral, 500 mourners in the Bronx parish of Saint Margaret Mary--most of them schoolchildren-gathered yesterday to say their own good-by to Cardinal Spellman.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 7--Gov. Ronald Reagan wound up a four-day visit to Connecticut today with a barrage at President Johnson and the Great Society, which he called "the end of an era."

With President Johnson and Vice President Humphrey heading a list of distinguished mourners, Cardinal Spellman was buried yesterday in a crypt in St. Patrick's Cathedral, the center of the see he headed for 28 years. Nine Cardinals of the church were among the concelebrants of the first all-English mass ever held for a Cardinal.

Gary Beban of the University of California, Los Angeles, accepted the Heisman Trophy as this year's outstanding college football player yesterday and predicted that O.J. Simpson of Southern California and Leroy Keyes of Purdue were the prime candidates for the 1968 Heisman Trophy.
MUSIC was the thing last night at Philharmonic Hall, where the New York Philharmonic celebrated--to the day--its 125th anniversary, but there also were a few speeches.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 7--Elnardo Webster scored 25 points as St. Peter's College defeated Fairfield University, 88-65; at the Jersey City Armory tonight. It was the second straight victory for the Peacocks.
Investors apparently could not make up their minds yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. As a result, prices closed mixed in moderately active trading.
PARIS--Parisians are staying awake and resenting it. The reason they don't sleep is because they can't relax.
The Board of Estimate, playing to a packed house of theatrical personalities, voted unanimously yesterday in favor of a plan to encourage the construction of playhouses in midtown Manhattan.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Dec. 8-North Vietnamese gunners have shelled the Conthien area with the heaviest barrage in more than two months.

BOSTON, Dec. 7--The Chief and The Kid, who have fired the imagination of Boston hockey fans, helped continue the mythlike resurgence of the Bruins tonight as the former stepchildren of the National Hockey League scored a 3-1 victory over the New York Rangers.

A State Supreme Court justice has ordered the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor to halt its investigation of a marine carpentry con cern that had applied for a license as a limited stevedore employer.
CHICAGO, Dec. 7--The housing industry called today for more public assistance to en able it adequately to shelter the urban poor and to provide suitable accommodations for the rest of the population.

THE totally unexpected sequence of events had to begin with Stan Musial. There is no other logical explanation of the upper-echelon baseball shuffle that whisked Bing Devine from the command post of the New York Mets to the general managership of the St. Louis Cardinals, a move that stunned the baseball world.
Leonard Reisman, president of the City University's College of Police Science and a former Deputy Police Commissioner here, died early this morning, apparently of a heart attack.
LONDON, Dec. 7--The pound dipped today to its lowest level since devaluation on Nov. 18. Trading was light but nervous. The currency closed at about $2.4090, down almost one-fourth cent.

ROME, Dec. 7--Nine Cardinals and scores of other clerical and lay dignitaries attended a funeral mass today for Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York, in his Roman titular Church of SS. John and Paul.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7--The Senate approved today a foreign-aid appropriation of $2.73billion for the current fiscal year.

ATHENS, Dec. 7--The nearwar over Cyprus and the sudden attack on the Greek junta by former Premier Constantine Caramanlis have produced widespread speculation that the time is at hand for a showdown between King Constantine and the military government.
IF skiers follow the fashions, the ski slopes this sea son should look like some sort of crazy (and distinctly indigestible) casserole.

Cardinal Spellman was buried beneath the high altar of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday after a princely requiem that combined the 1,900-year-old traditions of Roman Catholicism with the church's most modern liturgical innovations.

Under fire from alumni and aware that he lacked support within the Columbia University administration, Aldo T. (Buff) Donelli resigned yesterday as football coach after 11 seasons in that job. He had no contract and worked under a series of annual reappointments.
A selective list of restaurants is given on this page on Friday, with the restaurants rated on the basis of four stars to none. Food and service in relation to the cost is the basic criterion.

Price increases continued yesterday to sweep through the steel industry, but there was further evidence of a division among producers on whether to charge more for one major product, hot-rolled sheet.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7-- House and Senate conferees agreed tonight on a compromise Social Security bill with a 13 per cent across-the-board increase in benefits.
VERBENA, N.Y., Dec. 7-- Most of the dukes had left the Dutchess County cooperative hunting area by the time I arrived for the last weekend of the 1967 deer season, which closed Tuesday.
Prices were raised yesterday on a broad range of products. Carpets, chemicals, paper and flooring were among the items affected.
LONDON, Dec. 7--A small crowd gathered in a church graveyard near the Thames to day to hear nice words about Capt. William Bligh of the Bounty.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 7-- Vice President Humphrey faced 12,000 disgruntled farmers here tonight and won round after round of applause for a rousing endorsement of collective bargaining in agriculture.

Sales and earnings of Armour Co. for the fiscal year ended Oct. 28 declined from the previous fiscal year, it was reported yesterday from company's headquarters in Chicago.

A 50-year-old bronze horse found fame in fakery yesterday as it stole the spotlight from the authentic antiquities at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
Senator Thruston B. Morton urged the Republican party yesterday to adopt a 1968 platform keyed to gradual and honorable disengagement in Vietnam and to solving urban problems.

TWO American artists of the older generation--the painter Edwin Dickinson, 76, and the sculptor Reuben Nakian, 70--have been selected to represent the United States at the 1968 Venice Biennale.

The election of Daniel Parker, 42 years old, as chairman of the National Association of Manufacturers was announced here last night.
Changes in top-level management were announced yesterday by companies in the cosmetics, heavy equipment, metals and utilities industries.
The more than 2 million people who are enrolled in the Medicaid program here must be re-certified under state regulations, the city's Department of Social Services announced yesterday.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 7Senator Eugene J. McCarthy will open his campaign in the Wisconsin Presidential primary tomorrow with a speech at the University of Wisconsin, a center of opposition to President Johnson's Vietnam policies.

Mrs. DeWitt Wallace, cochairman with her husband of the Reader's Digest Association, Inc., presented a $300,000 check yesterday to the Metropolitan Opera to pay for a new production of Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunov" for the 196970 season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7--Republican leaders in Congress suggested today that the Johnson Administration had not done all it could to negotiate a settlement of the Vietnam war.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 7-- The Albert Morehead knockout championship, the closing event of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall National Championships here, was won last night by Michael Becker and Steve Altman of New York and Dan Rotman and Charles Peres of Chicago.
New York University passed the $100-million goal of its capital fund drive yesterday, two years ahead of schedule.

PRETORIA, South Africa-- Although South Africa is a prosperous industrial republic whose strongly based Government cherishes vigorous antiCommunist bias, it is in deep trouble with the West as well as with neutral and Marxist states. New York University unveiled a senior-sophomore combination of players last night and Manhattan College gave Coach Ken Norton his first victory of the season as a silver wedding anniversary present.

GRACE, good humor, good manners, a sense of proportion about past and future and ideas and men-these are not much in vogue these days. Perhaps the times are too hurried, too disconcerting and too dangerous for an easy toleration of homespun philosophy.
PARIS, Dec. 7--Authoritative French sources said today that France was on the point of lifting her arms embargo to Iraq and a number of other Arab countries.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 7-- The events of the last few weeks, when Cyprus almost became a battleground, have produced some sober thinking in the Cypriote leadership headed by President Makarios.

George V. McLaughlin, former City Police Commissioner, State Superintendent of Banks and vice chairman of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, died of a heart attack yesterday in his apartment at 610 Park Avenue. He was 80 years old and maintained an office at 630 Fifth Avenue and a summer home in Old Forge.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7-- Revenue freight traffic generated by carloadings on United States railroads in the latest week ended Dec. 2 rose from the corresponding period last Year. Intercity truck tonnage for the same period registered a decline.
The President Van Buren was awarded the Port of San Francisco's Blue Riband yesterday after she logged 25.55 knots on her maiden crossing from Yokohama.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7--Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, leading Senate advocate of draft reform, today attacked recommendations that draft deferments be granted to graduates studying natural science, mathematics, engineering and health.
LONDON, Dec. 8 (UPI)--A blizzard whipped snow into drifts throughout Britain today, paralyzing transportation and leaving a dozen towns isolated.

CAPETOWN, Dec. 8 (AP)-- Louis Washkansky's wife visited him in Groote Schuur Hospital today and said that although he had a new heart his personality had not changed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) --Senator John Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi, said today, that his Senate ethics committee would report a code of conduct to the Senate in January. He indicated that the proposed code would cover financial disclosure, outside activities, gifts and other topics.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (UPI)-- O'Hare International Airport became the first airfield in the world yesterday to record 600,000 take-offs and landings in one year. The previous record, set last year, was 562,975 operations, according to the Federal Aviation Administration

LEICESTER, Mass., Dec. 8 --A Feb. 17 wedding in Worcester is being planned by Miss Susan Hight and Joseph Nichols Rountree.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt. Dec. 8 (AP)--John Wesley Coulter, author of more than 100 books and articles about Pacific islands, died yesterday at his home at the age of 74.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP] --The Navy announced today that it would discharge 34,000 enlisted men one or two months before their normal enlistment periods expired.

The General Aniline and Film Corporation, a company giant working hard to develop a new image and expanded markets, said yesterday that 1967 net income should equal last year's restated earnings of $1.13 a share. For 1968, it predicted "an appreciable rise over 1967 results.

The Charter Oil Company, Ltd., which participates in joint ventures for the commercial exploitation of oil and natural gas, announced yesterday in Vancouver, British Columbia, the dismissal of Paul O. Berliz as president and Avery Stone as vice president, secretary and treasurer.
TOKYO, Dec. 8--"Merry Christmas," say signs newly posted on utility poles all along the bustling Ginza, a shopping and entertainment street often called the Fifth Avenue of Tokyo.

Canada's horse of the year will head the field in the Display Handicap at Aqueduct today. William Beasley's He's A Smoothie, trained by the owner's son Warren, will oppose 11 in the two-mile race, which will have a gross value of $59,000.

The Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation announced yesterday that it would publish a tender offer on Monday for 700,000 of the 1.5 million outstanding shares of the Bunker Hill Company at $56 a share.

The Israel Emergency Fund, begun last June to meet the costs of Israel's humanitarian program, will be continued through next year.
A computerized archive to help art professionals perform studies that are now close to impossible is being planned by 15 museums in New York City and the National Gallery of Art in Washington.

PARIS, Dec. 8 (Reuters)-- France was doing its best to sink the pound since it was de valued but it may well suffer from its action, former French Prime Minister Pierre MendesFrance said in an interview published here today.
Vikki Carr, an ingratiating pixie of a girl who is singing in the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel, and Lana Cantrell, a bundle of enthusiastic energy at the Copacabana, have a great deal in common.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) --Democratic Senators conferred today on how next year's legislative program could best be handled so that those up for re-election would be free to campaign as much as possible.

The over-all subsidy to air carriers declined approximately $7.3-million in the fiscal year 1967, and a further decline of $6.4-million is expected in the current year, the Civil Aeronautics Board reported yesterday.

Sol Strauss, the lawyer for the 20th Century Sporting Club in the heyday of Mike Jacobs' hegemony over major boxing promotions, died of heart failure yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived at 241 Central Park West.

A late-developing 2-year-old, Verbatim of the Elmendorf racing interests, gave an impressive exhibition in winning the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. A strong favorite with the crowd of 27,290, Verbatim scored a 5 -length victory over Railbird, with a long shot, Czar Alexander, next in the field of nine.

Donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have frequently asked how the fund meets the requirements of the destitute who are not among the 100 cases published in the annual Christmastime appeal.

Jordan, the executive vice chairman of the American Joint Distribution Committee, whose body was found in the Vltava River in Prague last August.

Tales of sabotage, attempted bribery, physical violence and intimidation were related before the State Investigation Commission yesterday at a hearing into possible racketeer activity in the air freight industry here.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, now holding a commanding ratings lead over its network rivals, expects to be iri a position to lock-in its programming schedule for next season by mid-January, a month earlier than usual.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan ordered yesterday a review of all pending cases investigated by the three city detectives indicted for selling narcotics to peddlers.
PARIS, Dec. 13--Rumors about international measures to restrict the gold market spurred gold trading near a record level here today.

The Eastern Intercollegiate Football Association expressed a desire yesterday to reestablish some form of limited substitution for college football. TRENTON, Dec. 14--Mayor Carmen Armenti said today that the outbreak of student violence yesterday at Trenton High School that spread for a time through the downtown shopping area had resulted largely from a breakdown in communications between the faculty and the school's large Negro enrollment.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--Senator Eugene J. McCarthy's challenge to the renomination of President Johnson has forced the White House to move up its political calendar by six months.

LUCY SWIGART of Washington, Conn., went skating this week with Santa Claus. The four little Reillys of Baldwin, L.I., zoomed to the top of the Empire State Building. And the Richter children of Eastchester, N.Y., went to the Christmas show at the Radio City Music Hall.

The action of South Vietnam's National Liberation Front in placing its new political program before the United Nations by proxy--having been denied so far a chance to appear in person--may be merely a propaganda gambit, as American officials have suggested. But the front's unusual initiative at the world organization may also represent a serious peace feeler. It should be treated as such until proved otherwise.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14-- Total business inventories rose $410-million in October after showing a small decline of $60million in September, the Commerce Department reported today.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 19--Texas oil wells will be opened wide again in January to meet burgeoning market demand, under a proration formula designed to increase production by 149,107 barrels a day.

The Gillette Company of Boston, which held negotiations last October with Braun, A.G., of Frankfurt, announced yesterday that a controlling interest was acquired in the West German electrical appliance and electronic producer for $50-million in cash and stock.

The interviewers were Ray Scherer of the National Broadcasting Company, Dan Rather of the Columbia Broadcasting System and Frank Reynolds of the American Broadcasting Company.

From Biscayne Bay to Hudson Bay, from San Francisco Bay to Jamaica Bay, 10,000 bird watchers have begun scanning the sky, the water and the land in the 68th annual Christmas Bird Count.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 25-- Forty experts on Asian land reform recently took a long, close look at Taiwan's considerable achievements in that important field. They found much to emulate, even more to admire, but no easy answer to the "we need a MacArthur" lament.
The volume of net new orders for machine tools strengthened slightly in November, an analysis of figures supplied by the National Machine Tool Builders Association in Washington disclosed yesterday.

HONG KONG, Dec. 25--From the Teahouse of the Shining Rainbow, where even a coolie can take a drink, to the bar of the Hong Kong Club, where bankers and businessmen meet, somebody always seems to be grumbling about the water these days.
The property and liability insurance industry fell back into the red in its 1967 underwriting operations, the Insurance Information Institute reported over the weekend.
LONGBINH, South Vietnam, Dec. 25 (UPI)--Bob Hope performed today before more than 25,000 troops, perhaps the biggest audience in 26 years of entertaining United States troops.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 25-- The American Civil Liberties Union has appealed the conviction of Cassius Clay, who has been setenced to five years and ordered to pay a $10,000 fine for refusing induction into the Army.
JACKSONVILLE, Ill., Dec. 25--The engagement of Miss Kathryn Louise Michalson to Jon Peter Gunnemann has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gordon E. Michalson.

THE NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC under the di rection of Leonard Bernstein was the subject of a significant experiment late yesterday afternoon in a marriage of television and frequency modulation stereophonic sound.

The flat and uninformative communique published after last week's meeting of the Czechoslovak Communist party Central Committee papers over, but cannot end, that country's current crisis. The splits in the Prague leadership are too deep and the currents of popular dissatisfaction run too swiftly.

The Felt Forum of the new Madison Square Garden, which opened recently with splendidly disciplined guardsmen, found itself host to another type of showmanship last night, when Judy Garland began a sevenday appearance.

In a hard-hitting contest appropriate to the football-bowl season now upon us, the Boston Celtics defeated the New York Knickerbockers, 134-124, in a National Basketball Association game before a crowd of 17,259 at Madison Square Garden last night.
The Maritime Administration announced yesterday a major reorganization of its office functions and activities, including the creation of a new position--assistant administrator for administration.

WHERE do good little Norell and Galanos dresses go when they've been around for a few years? Some of them wind up in resale shops like Second Rand, to be bought and worn by women who couldn't afford their original four-figure price tags.
BOSTON, Dec. 25--A "truth in lending" law is completing its first year of operation in Massachusetts, but few changes are apparent in either borrowing or lending practices in the state.
BABYLON, L.I., Dec. 25-- Nassau County's first policewoman was killed by a car yesterday as she helped a woman who had been hurt in an earlier accident.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) --The Government's voluntary wage-price guidelines--though feared by business and denounced by labor--apparently did help to curb inflation, a Brookings Institution study indicated today.
Hours after Norwegian seamen held a rollicking Christmas Eve party aboard their freighter in the Hudson River, fire roared through their quarters, killing three crew members and injuring 19 others.
LIKE a lot of other eager and shiny-eyed dreamers, the Green Bay Packers whirled toward Christmas Eve with visions of sugar plums dancing in their heads.
WATERTOWN, Conn., Dec. 25--A father and his four children died early this morning in a Christmas Day fire at their Lake Winnepaug home here.
Charles T. Ireland Jr., president of the Allegheny Corporation, is leaving that organization at the end of the week to join the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.
A $180-million long-term credit agreement, the largest single arrangement for new money ever made in the airline industry, was announced yesterday by Pan American World Airways.

Resistance to the draft reflects a profound and growing opposition to the war in Vietnam. This confrontation is disturbing and damaging, but it is inescapable in a society that values individual conscience.
TORONTO, Dec. 25--New Government figures suggest that Expo 67, the Montreal World's Fair, pulled more than $300-million of American tourist money into Canada.

ROME, Dec. 25--An envoy from the junta in Athens said today that King Constantine of Greece might return to his homeland "in the next few days."

PARIS--There has been a curious coming and going of Vietnamese personalities in Paris, and while no one suspects any serious negotiation is going on, all parties are certainly in a position to learn more about each other's views. Tran Van Do, Saigon's Minister of Foreign, Affairs, is only the latest and possibly the least expected of these visitors.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 26 (AP)--Most top-seeded players in the boys-18 division of the Orange Bowl junior tennis tournament went into the quarter-finals today.

HONG KONG, Dec. 26--Mao Tse-tung, chairman of the Chinese Communist party, was 74 years old today and still the top man in his country despite the arresting of the revolution he launched last year to purge so-called revisionist leaders and tendencies in Communist China.
ATHENS, Dec. 26--Informed sources reported tonight that efforts at conciliation between Greece's King Constantine, and his country's regime had reached a deadlock.
LONDON, Dec. 26 (Reuters) --Manchester United increased its lead to 3 points is the English Soccer League First Division after scoring a 4-0 victory over the Wolverhampton Wanderers today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26-- Rates on nine-month and oneyear Treasury bills rose at today's auction to their highest point since the autumn of 1966, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

Some people who normally spend money for Christmas parties in offices and elsewhere have decided to use the money instead to make contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 26 (UPI)--The mercury hovered at the zero-degree mark today when the Green Bay Packers took the practice field for their first drill for next Sunday's National Football League championship game against the Dallas Cowboys.
With the London Stock Exchange closed yesterday for a holiday, international investors directed their attention to the markets on the Continent, with mixed results.

THE 1967 tournament year is over and the enthusi asts are already looking forward to the 1968 season. The first major event for New York players will be the second Tristate Winter Regional at Grossinger's, beginning Jan. 11 and ending Jan. 14.

A wealthy Londoner who is the key witness in one of three current inquiries into the affairs of James L. Marcus has recently been in the United States and may still be here relatives and associates said yesterday.

The forced resignation in Cairo of Ahmed Shukairy, fiery chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, could mark a significant step toward peace in the Middle East.
Two of three American prisoners who were released by the Vietcong last month in Cambodia have said that they want to re-enlist in the Army, State and Defense Department officials said yesterday.
Investors in issues trading on the American Stock Exchange took a fancy to the higher-priced stocks this year and largely neglected those stocks selling under $5 a share.

Mayor Lindsay's plan to increase the number of police on the streets by more than 40 per cent without adding any patrolmen to the Police Department was denounced yesterday as "shameful, cynical hoodwinking" by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26--Exports rebounded smartly in November after their October decline, the Commerce Department reported today. However, imports also rose, though not as much. The result was a trade surplus--exports over imports--of $296-million in November, much better than October's $167-million but below nearly all other months this year.
Investors edged back into action yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. They left the list looking rather mixed in moderate trading.
Waiter Kidde Co., in a surprise move, announced yesterday a tender offer to purchase 700,000 shares of common stock of the United States Lines Company at $47.50 a share.

PARIS, Dec. 26--The United States will run into trouble if the Congress does not soon raise taxes as requested by the Administration, the nation was warned today by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

THE 23-race 1968 championship car schedule of the United States Auto Club is the most extensive in that organization's history and exceeds the organization's expanded activities of 1967 by five events. A scheduleratification meeting of promoters is set for Jan. 14 in Indianapolis.

FOOD and fun go hand in hand with Hanukkah, the happiest of all Jewish celebrations. The eight-day festival of lights started at sunset yesterday and runs to Jan. 3. It has become a time for exchanging gifts, entertaining and serving foods that have taken on symbolic meaning.

Operations of Schenley Industries, Inc., in the first fiscal quarter ended Nov. 30 resulted in net earnings of $8,703,046, equal after preference dividend requirements to $1.68 a common share the compaay's report disclosed yesterday.

A woman physician at Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn was stabbed to death last night, and the police questioned a male physician at the hospital who was a friend of the victim.

The French pancake or crepe has had a surge of popularity within the past decade that borders on the awesome. Ten years or so ago, we were all familiar with crepes Suzette--and not much else. Today we serve crepes as a first course, a main course and a dessert. Dessert crepes range far and wide from the old standard crepes Suzette.

On the Upper East Side, shopkeepers in boutiques and residents of apartments and stately brownstone houses are taking stricter precautions than ever to protect their businesses and homes.

WASHINGTON. AS one of the most exciting Presidential years in the nation's history draws to a close and all Washington braces for the inauguration, it might prove instructive to look back over the tangled political events of 1968 and see how it all came about.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- There were 200,271,231 Americans on hand to welcome in the New Year, the Census Bureau reported tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (Reuters) -- The Inter-American Development Bank has barred use of its funds by Latin-American countries for purchases in France and 10 other countries, it was disclosed today.

THE president of the American Contract Bridge League for 1968 is Joseph J. Stedem of Wilmette, Ill. The middle initial also stands for Joseph, which Stedem explains by saying that somebody stuttered at his christening.

TOKYO, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- North Vietnamese and Vietcong leaders today broadcast predictions of victory over American forces in 1968 and said that their attacks "without letup and everywhere" would produce fighting more bitter than in 1967.

BOSTON, Dec. 30 -- The secret of making Egyptian faience, the oldest glazed ceramic material known and also one of the most colorful and famous of antiquity, was divulged here today to scholars attending the annual meeting of the Archaeological Institute of America.
An agency endorsed by heavy-construction unions will start a program here this year to recruit Negro and Puerto Rican high school students for apprenticeships in the building trades.
GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 31 (UPI) -- The football fans are rugged up here.
Four of the nation's religious leaders agreed yesterday that the emergence of the hippie movement and the New Left was one of "profound significance" to both church and synagogue.

DUBLIN, Dec. 31 -- Irish Base Metals, Ltd., the wholly owned subsidiary of Northgate Exploration, Ltd., of Canada, announced today that in less than two years it had redeemed its entire bond liability totaling (Canadian) $2,471,000.
MASTER John Curdo of Chelmsford, Mass., scoring 5-0, won the recent Christmas Chess Open in Boston, a five-round Swiss system in which 42 players took part.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Brazil's outlawed Communist party has issued a statement assailing the Government but opposing armed struggle to bring it down.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Many automobile occupants can escape injury in traffic accidents at speeds up to 60 miles an hour, says the director of the national highway safety program.

MADRID, Dec. 31 -- The 19-year-old grandson of a prominent Spanish Republican who went into exile after the civil war quietly enrolled at Madrid University a few months ago with the blessings of the Franco regime.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- A Treasury official has disclosed further details of the Government's thinking in the field of giving more protection to employes covered by private pension plans.

MONROVIA, Liberia, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Vice President Humphrey got a rousing send-off today from tens of thousands of dancing and cheering Africans in the Ivory Coast and came to Liberia, where he heard President Johnson acclaimed.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 31 -- Prime Minister Balthazar J. Vorster attacked Britain today for refusing to supply armaments to South Africa.

Harold Pinter's "The Birthday Party" will be transferred Jan. 23 from the Booth Theater to the Alvin Theater. A major cast change will be made Thursday night when Jordan Charney succeeds James Patterson in the central role. Mr. Charney has been Mr. Patterson's understudy.

The unpredictable Rangers, perhaps entering a new phase of the National Hockey League season, stretched their unbeaten streak to four games last night while manhandling, outplaying, and outshooting the Toronto Maple Leafs en route to a 4-0 victory.

A spokesman for the fleet taxi owners said yesterday that strikes by drivers were inevitable if the City Council adopted Mayor Lindsay's proposal to increase the cost of the average cab ride 15 cents, which he called "insufficient."

An early morning fire yesterday destroyed a row of two-story buildings from 108 to 112 Fifth Avenue at Park Place in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. The blaze destroyed a catering hall, four stores and a bowling alley.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., Dec. 31 (AP) -- A young man who disappeared from an Asbury Park beach last August and was presumed dead for two months was married yesterday to the girl he left behind on the sands.
MIAMI, Dec. 31 -- Agricultural researchers estimate it could cost as much as $46-million to rid Florida of the Caribbean fruit fly because two years ago $2-million was not spent to do the job.
The American Plywood Association, which represents the principal producers of plywood in this country, will direct its chief promotional effort at six markets in 1968.

City Controller Mario A. Procaccino yesterday questioned the "economy and reform" that were supposed to accompany the creation of Mayor Lindsay's superagencies.

It was a lighthearted touch that the singers and dancers ought to demand be kept in the act.

An invitation to all labor unions with waterfront and maritime interests to join the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Maritime Committee is extended by the National Maritime Union president, Joseph Curran, in the January issue of the union's publication, The Pilot.
HONOLULU, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Board of Regents of the University of Hawaii gave a vote of confidence yesterday to the university president, Thomas H. Hamilton, who wants to resign.

The outlook for shipments by the American steel industry is "decidedly favorable," at least during the first half of 1968, the head of the country's largest steel producer said over the weekend.

"Brief Lives," which closed Saturday night at the John Golden Theater after 16 performances with Roy Dotrice in the sole role, may be resuscitated next week at the Forum Theater. The 299-seat chamber theater is in the basement of the Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center.
The use of city parks for automobile parking was proposed yesterday by the Automobile Club of New York as part of a plan to keep the city moving in case of a subway and bus strike.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 31 (AP) -- President Johnson signed a bill today ending the 15 per cent duty on imported bagpipes and parts. "There is no known commercial production of bagpipes in the United States," the Texas White House said.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- About 1,000 employes at the William Tatton textile plant in Golborne, Lancashire, worked through Christmas and their 10-day winter break so that delivery dates could be met for big export orders for Germany and Bulgaria.

CARIBOU, Me., Monday, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Caribou became the nation's northeasternmost city today. At midnight, it shifted to city government after 108 years as a town. In the 1960 census, Caribou had 12.464 inhabitants. It is 10 miles west of the New Brunswick border and 45 south of Maine's northern tip.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- One of the problems facing Administration Democrats when Congress convenes next month is to find a way to get some of President Johnson's most important bills past the Senate Judiciary Committee.

OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 31 -- The Foreign Legion of pro football, the Oakland Raiders, qualified today to challenge the game's monarchs, the Green Bay Packers, in the Super Bowl.

If a Republican Presidential nominating convention cast its ballots today, former Vice President Richard M. Nixon would receive 561 votes, only 106 fewer than he needs to become his party's candidate, according to a survey by Newsweek magazine.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Jan. 1 -- Striking out of the paddy fields at 10 minutes after midnight, while church bells in the nearby delta city of Mytho were still pealing the arrival of the new year, a Vietcong unit savagely mauled the headquarters elements of the South Vietnamese Second Marine Battalion early today.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 31 (UPI) -- President John son's 6-month-old grandson, Patrick Lyndon Nugent, had the sniffles and was running a temperature this week -- but he is fine now an aide reported today.

TARPON SPRINGS, Fla., Dec. 31 -- After nearly 20 years in the doldrums, sponge fishing here has begun a comeback. Playing key roles are experienced divers from Greece, coming here on permanent visas granted by the Immigration Service to help rescue what was once a thriving industry.

ROME, Dec. 31 -- The "star of peace" burns more brilliantly than ever, despite a year of "uneasiness and conflicts," Pope Paul VI said today on the eve of the Roman Catholic Church's recently proclaimed world day of peace Jan. 1.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31 -- The Rose Bowl offers tomorrow for its clientele of 102,000 ticket-holders and millions of television viewers what may prove to be the prize attraction of all the postseason college football games.

SEATTLE, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The San Francisco Warriors withstood a closing drive in which a 12-point lead was all but dissipated and posted a 126-124 National Basketball Association victory over the Seattle Supersonics today.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (Reuters) -- A twin-engine chartered plane crashed into Lake Pontchartrain today, killing all six persons aboard.

SOUTH POLE STATION, Antarctica, Dec. 26 -- The South Pole Station, built as a temporary research base on the geographical pole in 1957, is collapsing under tons of snow and ice.

Frank M. Blunk, a member of the New York Times sports department since 1934, retired today and concluded a newspaper career that started with the Louisville Herald more than five decades ago. He was the motorcar sports editor at the time of his retirement.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 30 -- A collection of massive sandstone faces, egg-shaped, blank-eyed and with gaping, down-turned mouths, has been displayed here as evidence that civilization existed in Europe far earlier than had been believed.

OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Both coaches agreed today that a fake field-goal attempt in the second quarter that brought the Oakland Raiders' their second touchdown was a turning point in the American Football League championship game.

The distinction of publishing the first modern-style encyclopedia belongs to the Chinese, who issued one in the tenth century. The first important encyclopedia in English, the Lexicon Technicum, was put out in 1704. The first volumes of Diderot's Encyclopedie appeared in 1752, were suppressed as injurious to royalty and the clergy -- and helped to provide kindling for the French Revolution.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The question of wage and price controls will have to be faced in 1968 if Congress does not approve a tax increase, Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz said today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 31 -- American officials at almost all levels, both in Saigon and in the provinces, say they are under steadily increasing pressure from Washington to produce convincing evidence of progress, especially by the South Vietnamese, in the next few months.
The nation's railroads ordered 6,221 new freight cars in November, the highest total since June when they ordered 7,314 cars.
PARIS, Dec. 31 -- President de Gaulle suggested tonight that on the strength of his past policies he would one day be able to help bring peace to Vietnam and the Middle East.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Prince Souvanna Phouma, the Premier of Laos, said today that he was losing faith in the 1962 Geneva accord because of the increased "inhuman aggression" by North Vietnam in support of the pro-Communist Pathet Lao rebels.
WHEELING, W. Va., Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Seven children of two families died today in a fire that wrecked a 2 1/2-story frame duplex house on Wheeling Island in the Ohio River.

PERTH, Australia, Dec. 31 (Reuters) -- Mrs. Margaret Court, who as Margaret Smith won the Wimbledon title in 1963 and 1965, was the star for Australia today in a 2-1 victory over the United States in a women's international tennis contest.
