WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- A citizens' committee has recommended substantial raises for dozens of top Federal officials, including one for the Vice President from $43,000 a year to $60,000.

"Far From the Madding Crowd," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's British-made adaptation of the Thomas Hardy novel, has been voted the best movie of 1967 by the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures. The public organization, which has been selecting best films for 47 years, also chose the Swedish romantic drama "Elvira Madigan," as the year's best foreign-language film.
HIALEAH, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) The police seized today 600 pounds of marijuana valued at more than $500,000 on the retail market after springing a trap that took them two months to set up.

MIAMI, Dec. 31 -- Two of the most familiar names in college football bowl games -- Tennessee and Oklahoma -- will meet in the 34th annual Orange Bowl contest tomorrow night. The Vols, appearing in their 13th postseason bowl game, are a slight favorite over the Sooners, who have been in 11 previous bowl contests.

President Tito has underlined the intensity of the current internal struggle among Yugoslavia's Communists by his threat to purge conservative opponents of recent liberal reforms. That Tito felt it necessary to make this threat testifies to the continued power of these opposition elements a year and a half after the purge of their leader, former secret police chief Aleksandar Rankovic.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Former President Harry S. Truman, appearing chipper for his 83 years, greeted his daughter, Mrs. Clifton Daniel, and three grandchildren today when they arrived at Municipal airport for a holiday visit.
EL SEGUNDO, Calif., Dec. 13 (AP) -- After raging for 12 days, a petroleum fire at a Standard Oil Company tank farm burned itself out today. A company spokesman estimated the loss at $1.5-million.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- The nationwide copper strike became the longest today for the Kennecott Copper Corporation's Western Mining Division. The dispute ended its 170th day, one more than the 1959-60 deadlock.
LONDON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Prime Minister Wilson warned in a New Year's message today that Britain faced a year of hardship and sacrifice -- but a year of vital opportunity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Governor Rockefeller of New York is the only major Republican Presidential possibility who would defeat President Johnson if the 1968 election were held today, a national survey of party leaders and observers indicates.
The University of California, Los Angeles, doesn't have to make any resolutions for the new year.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 31 -- Slowly, carefully and quietly, Rumanian and Israeli experts are forging a trade and aviation agreement that is expected to provide political as well as economic dividends for both countries.

GENEVA, Dec. 31 -- The International Press Institute has termed the "overnight abolition" of a free press by the military junta in Greece the "most dramatic suppression" of press freedom in the last 15 years.

An all-star soccer game between the German - American League's under 23 team and the All-Stars of New Jersey State Association is scheduled for today at 2 P.M. at Metropolitan Oval, Maspeth, Queens. This is the only New Year's Day soccer attraction in the metropolitan area.

Sabicas gave one of his customarily impeccable flamenco programs at Town Hall Saturday night. The turn-out of only 700 persons raises some serious questions about what turns on flamenco listeners in New York these days.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The creation of a Youth Advisory Council headed by William G. Kerr of Oklahoma was announced today by the Democratic National Chairman, John M. Bailey.

Jerome Greene, a vice president of Helmsley-Spear, Inc., has been chosen "Man of the Year" by the Realty Foundation of New York. Mr. Greene, secretary of the foundation, will be its guest of honor at its annual dinner next April 24.

PARIS, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Waverley Root, Paris correspondent of the Washington Post, was made an officer in the French Legion of Honor today.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 31 -- Steel mills approached the new year with most signs favorable.

The two public agencies involved directly in the transit dispute are the Transit Authority and its subsidiary, the Manhattan and Bronx Surface Transit Operating Authority. They operate the city's publicly owned bus and subway lines.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 31 -- A half-million dollars and this city's ultramodern theatrical facilities have lured England's Royal Shakespeare Company into its first appearance in Los Angles.
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The Government's New Year's honors list was made public today. There was a heavy emphasis on awards for industrialists who have worked to stimulate exports.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Mike Estep of Dallas led the defending United States team to a 2-1 victory today over South Africa in the Sunshine Cup tennis matches. The United States will meet France in the final tomorrow.

TEL AVIV, Dec. 31 (Reuters) -- Maj. Gen. Haim Bar-Lev, an expert in tank warfare, became Chief of Staff of the Israeli defense forces today, taking over from Maj. Gen. Itzhak Rabin, who led the Israeli forces in the war against the Arabs in June. General Rabin is to become the Israeli Ambassador in Washington.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Dec. 31 -- Michael Myerberg, owner of the Brooks Atkinson Theater, who produced "Waiting for Godot," "The Skin of Our Teeth," "Fantasia" and "Patterns," among other critically acclaimed plays and films, bobbed around excitedly and proclaimed: "I regard this as my biggest contribution."
MOSCOW, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Soviet Government, in a New Year's message, today wished Vietnamese Communists "decisive successes in their heroic struggle."

OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 31 -- Despite the subzero weather at Green Bay, Wis. for today's National Football League championship game, Commissioner Pete Rozelle said he doubted it would prompt a decision to stage league title games in warm-climate cities.

MOSCOW, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- The success of the new profit-oriented management system helped Soviet industry exceed its planned growth rate by nearly 2 per cent this year, the Soviet press agency Tass said yesterday.

The premiere of "Golden Rainbow," the musical starring Steve Lawrence and Eydie Gorme, has been postponed from Wednesday night at the Shubert Theater to an undetermined date in the last two weeks of this month. Until then, previews will continue.
BRISBANE, Monday, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- The Braham Quintuplets were named today.

A luncheon and fashion show for new members of the Women's League for Israel will be held on Jan. 9 at the Plaza. The organization is a voluntary service group that aids young people entering Israel. Mrs. David Berlin and Mrs. Theresa Waldinger are co-chairmen of the event.
TOKYO, Dec. 31 -- Business circles here are optimistic about the future of Japan's trade with Communist China, although Peking let the two nations' trade agreement expire today.
The Green Bay Packers and the Oakland Raiders won their league championships yesterday and set the stage for their confrontation in the Super Bowl.

What Bill Bradley did for Princeton basketball three years ago -- establish respect for it on a national scale -- was done less individualistically for Columbia late Saturday night by Jim McMillian, Heyward Dotson, Dave Newmark and Roger Walaszek. They formed the backbone of a 60-55 victory over St. John's in the final of the 16th annual Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden.
Members of a West Side family sent $24 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, designating it for Jimmy. "the little boy who can't smile."
SAN ANTONIO, Dec. 31 -- "We've decided to unleash Christian," said George Christian with a faint smile and shrug as he contemplated his full-fledged debut on national television today.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- Louisiana State University and Wyoming reported today that they were in peak condition for their meeting in the Sugar Bowl tomorrow before an expected crowd of more than 77,000 fans.

CAIRO, Dec. 31 -- Sheik Hassan Maamoun, the Grand Sheik of Al Azhar, the principal mosque of Cairo, marked the end of Ramadan today with a message denouncing the Israelis as "enemies of Arabism and Islam."

The United States economy, which picked up speed in the final weeks of 1967, will continue to expand vigorously into 1968. After midyear, however, business activity is expected to lose a little of its muscle.

THE Manhattan Festival Ballet got the dance new year underway with two premieres last night in its home at the Theater 80 St. Marks -- Carolyn Brown's "Car Lot" and John Taras's pas de deux "Soiree Musicale."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Defense Department officials said tonight that there had been "a certain amount of quid pro quo" in negotiating the new agreement on offset purchases with Britain. But they insisted that the $100-million increase offered by the United States was "thoroughly justified."

What has been happening to the state arts movements? After the establishment of the Federal Arts and Humanities Endowments in 1966, all the states rushed to join the parade. It is true that some like New York, Missouri, California and Illinois formed their own arts councils before the Federal Council on the Arts came into being, but the big push came after 1965.
WASHINGTON -- Living in a grocery store hardly sounds like the chic thing to do, but a lot of Georgetown residents are doing it. Not that anyone would recognize the stores as such.

The worry on the part of liberal Congressmen at the primary candidacy of Senator Eugene McCarthy, as described by James Reston on Dec. 13, would have existed quite without Senator McCarthy. Your Dec. 20 editorial regarding corruption in handing out city contracts in emergency situations misses an important aspect.

Officials in the Lindsay administration said yesterday that '"substantial agreement" had been reached with state officials on the layout of the vast subway expansion that is expected to begin this year.

Southern California, the nation's top-ranked college football team, scored a 14-3 triumph over Indiana yesterday before a crowd of 102,946 at the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif. O. J. Simpson scored the Trojan touchdowns on runs of 2 and 8 yards.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- Britain's gambling casino operators decided tonight to alter the rules for roulette.

Prices moved up on the American Stock Exchange yesterday in a continuation of the advance begun during the final sessions of 1967.

THE Rangers won't officially complete their first half of the National Hockey League season until Saturday at Montreal, but symbolically the second half starts tonight at Madison Square Garden, against the Boston Bruins, the club that has barred the door and has stopped the New Yorkers from having an outstanding season.

An Athens censor's deletion from King Constantine's New Year message to the people of Greece tells much about the kind of "democracy" the ruling junta can be expected to establish in that unhappy country. The passage struck out of the King's message from his Rome exile said: "We Greeks hold freedom and democratic dearer than life itself."

Americans are eating large amounts of low quality and even diseased fish because of poor inspection procedures, according to Ralph Nader, the auto industry critic.

A musical about James J. Walker, New York's colorful mayor in the late nineteen-twenties, is beng planned for Broadway next November.

For the affluent, this is the week of the payday double-take, the annual January trauma. The vacation from paying the Social Security payroll tax is over. CAPETOWN, Jan. 2 -- Dr. Christiaan N. Barnard performed his second successful heart transplant today, replacing the diseased heart of a 58-year-old retired dentist with the healthy heart of a young man who had died of a stroke. MADRID -- Mrs. Sol Rosenblatt, the wife of a New York lawyer, who has an apartment here, never accepts a dinner party invitation if the menu includes pheasant, boar, rabbit, woodcock or venison, which is often the case right now in Europe. The business community was about evenly divided yesterday between supporters and opponents of President Johnson's program to improve the nation's balance of payments.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 2 -- Representative Robert Taft Jr., Republican, said today that he would not run for the Senate next November.

Postal authorities announced yesterday that they were examining a bomb disguised as a Christmas whisky package that was sent last weekend to David Dellinger, peace advocate and coordinator of the Fifth Avenue Peace Parade Committee.

BONN, Jan. 2 -- Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, the United States Under Secretary of State, flew here today from London to seek West German cooperation for President Johnson's new efforts to reduce the United States balance-of-payments deficit.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- Secretary General Thant held separate consultations today with representatives of Cyprus, Greece and Turkey on the Greek-Turkish tension in Cyprus.

The purchase of General Felt Industries, Inc., in Chicago and three supporting companies, by the Okonite Company, Passaic, N. J., a subsidiary of Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., was announced yesterday in Dallas, home of L-T-V.
Don Meredith, the Dallas Cowboys' quarterback, said yesterday he was considering retirement from pro football. But he said he wouldn't make a decision for another two months.
New York City is in the grip of an influenza epidemic, Dr. Edward O'Rourke, the city's Health Commissioner said yesterday.

Fourth-quarter futility, the affliction the New York Knickerbockers have suffered from all season, struck on schedule at Madison Square Garden last night. Leading the Cincinnati Royals, 94-88, after three quarters, the Knicks produced only four baskets in the next 8 1/2 minutes and went on to lose, 125-119.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway and its 90 per cent controlled subsidiary, the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, reported yesterday a consolidated net income for 1967 of $52.3-million, equal to $6.02 a share on C. O.'s common stock. This compared with a net of $66.1-million, or $7.61 a share, earned in 1966.
STOCKHOLM, Jan. 2 -- Four American sailors who deserted their ship to protest the war in Vietnam will probably be granted political asylum in Sweden, informed sources said tonight.

THE Oakland Raiders will advance into the Super Bowl a fortnight hence with an 11-game winning streak. The Green Bay Packers will reach that same Miami destination with a winning streak of two. But what a two!

The recent upward trend of sales in New York City's department stores was reversed in December, a month that ironically included what is normally the largest shopping period of the year, the Christmas season.

Paul Whiteman was eulogized yesterday as "the King of Jazz" and as a kindly man whom countless musicians called Pops, at a funeral service that seemed like an evocation of the era when collegians flocked around the first big bands.

A new dispute involving ancient Thera arose yesterday when James W. Mavor Jr., who asserted last July that the volanic Greek Island was part of the lost continet of Atlantis, announced his dismissal from an archeological project investigating his contention.

The architectural firm of Sharp Handren has admitted three new partners. They are Arthur D. Greenfield, Marvin K. Geasler and Ray E. Cumrine. The new members, who are joining Robert Handren, senior partner, and J. Stanley Sharp, were formerly associate members of the firm, whose name has now been changed to Handren, Sharp Associates.
An autograph seeker caused a brief commotion at the taping of the National Broadcasting Company's "Tonight" Show last night when she tried to get on the stage with the program's star, Johnny Carson.

The only reason why Roy Eaton, with his training as a pianist and musicologist, is in the advertising business is that when he got discharged from the Army back in 1955, one concert season had just ended and the next was already booked.
Earnings reports for 1967 from the nation s major banks started to pour in yesterday. In the vast majority of cases, they showed record-breaking profits.
BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 2 -- The Earl Warren Legal Center was dedicated at the University of California here today as a facility "so nobly named it should not fail in its mission."
PARIS, Jan. 2 -- Frenchmen showed sharply divided reactions today to President Johnson's financial program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Following are excerpts from a statement by the North Vietnamese Foreign Minister, Nguyen Duy Trinh, at a reception for a delegation to Hanoi from Mongolia. The statement was carried on the Hanoi radio's English-language service yesterday.

Harry Van Arsdale Jr., the head of the city's 29,000 unionized taxi drivers, said yesterday that Mayor Lindsay's proposal for a taxi fare increase was "totally unacceptable" and the result of "just throwing figures into a computer."
Mayor Lindsay's office announced yesterday that the city and Pan American World Airways had reached preliminary agreement on establishing a heliport at 61st Street and the East River.

The architectural firm of Sharp Handren has admitted three new partners. They are Arthur D. Greenfield, Marvin K. Geasler and Ray E. Cumrine. The new members, who are joining Robert Handren, senior partner, and J. Stanley Sharp, were formerly associate members of the firm, whose name has now been changed to Handren, Sharp Associates.

State and city officials are reported near agreement with Pan American World Airways to start development of the world's first STOLport extending out over the Hudson River between 59th and 68th Streets.

England may have its problems of catching up these days, but some of its traditions should remain unchanged, especially for those who use the English language. Prime Minister Wilson does not deserve a full ode, but -- considering that he was under some literary pressure to abolish the office -- he could use a stray iamb or two for perpetuating the post of Poet Laureate.

Those who hunt birds without dogs miss most of the fun because usually they are merely wandering about seeking action with only hope to sustain them. At least that's the belief of Clifton Havener of Patterson, N.Y., the 29-year-old president of the Southern New York Field Trial Club.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Preliminary analysis by the United States indicated today that the latest Chinese Communist nuclear test was a failure.
" Step up on the ladder and when you sing, try to let your voice hit the orange object on the wall," the director told the hesitant young girl.
PARIS, Jan. 3 -- President Johnson's financial austerity program appeared today to have produced an internal political controversy in France.

BONN, Jan. 3 -- The United States plans to demand "full coverage" by West Germany of American costs for stationing troops in this country during the coming years, according to informed sources in the capital.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy announced today that he would expand his challenge to President Johnson by entering the New Hampshire Presidential primary, the nation's first, which will be held on March 12.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 3 -- The politically sensitive question of the future of the occupied Arab territories was raised briefly in Parliament today, only to be beaten back by the Government coalition.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 3 -- For a man used to dealing in such rotund concepts as market organization and transportation economics. Merton Joseph Peck is known around the Yale University campus as a heavy thinker who can take himself lightly.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- President Johnson is reported to be preparing to send a personal envoy to Cambodia soon to follow up indications by Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the chief of state, that he would welcome direct talks with the United States.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz said today his Statement about possible consideration of wage-price controls if Congress does not raise taxes was a mistake.

CAPETOWN, Jan. 3 (Reuters) -- A noted gland specialist who played a vital part in pre-operation tests for yesterday's heart transplant operation lives under a South African Government restriction order.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission warned today of the possibility that the nation's bakery industry might move in a monopolistic direction that could bring higher retail prices for bread and other bakery products.
A New Rochelle father gave his three young sons a lesson in the art of giving, with the result that The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund received a family gift of $143.

A clearer link between the use of the hallucinogenic drug LSD and damage to the genetic material of human beings has been established in recent studies of patients at hospitals here and in California.
A spate of selling moved into the American Stock Exchange yesterday afternoon, halting a morning rally and sending the market into its biggest retreat since Britain devalued the pound.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 3 -- Suffolk County Executive H. Lee Dennison charged today that County Police Commissioner John L. Barry was insubordinate and subject to removal from office.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The transplanting of Mr. Haupt's heart to a white man has caused no controversy in race-conscious South Africa.
Maj. Huber Matos was a teacher who left the classroom and became a revolutionary hero. He tried to be a moderate revolutionary and failed.
The stock market was unable to hold its earlier gains yesterday and finished the session in the minus column in heavier trading.

It's not just the city that is "caught in the middle" on Waterside -- it's the middle-income people who have been waiting and dreaming of living on the river with the sun, light and convenience of walking to their daily work, at a rental within the means of the majority of ordinary folk.
The Transit Authority warned yesterday that if the public continued to hoard tokens it could cause serious problems to the subway and bus systems.
During the current fiscal year and the one preceding it the United States used herbicides in Vietnam on such a scale that the total cost will reach almost $100-million.

The National Broadcasting Company producer who has been preparing a special documentary on heart transplantation operations said yesterday that N.B.C. had arranged to pay Dr. Philip Blaiberg $50,000 "in order to protect the network."

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Jan. 3 -- Jubilant over the presumed qualification of his American Independent party for the California ballot, former Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama said today he expected the party to get on the ballots of the 49 other states as well and possibly to win the 1968 Presidential election for him.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Boys and girls in brightly colored blazers and school ties are as much a part of the British scene as red double-decker buses and Big Ben. But Miss Elizabeth Ackroyd, the head of the Consumer Council of Britain, urged today a revolt of teachers and parents against "the mystique" of the traditional school uniform.

WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 3 -- Impatient for action after an 18-day break, New York horseplayers got back on gait with only one slight bobble here tonight as the 1968 harness-racing season opened at Roosevelt Raceway.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UPI) -- The National Commission on Reform of Federal Criminal Laws today named a 15-member advisory committee to be headed by retired Supreme Court Justice Tom Clark.
THERE is much that is pleasant, if not precisely arresting, in "Love and Let Love." a musical based upon Shakespeare's "T w e l f t h Night" that opened at the Sheridan Square Playhouse last night.

Robert L. Strickman charged yesterday that Columbia University had violated its agreement with him on his cigarette filter and he demanded return of the device, which he claims will dramatically reduce tar and nicotine.
Parker B. Smith has been appointed treasurer of the Canada Dry Corporation international division. He formerly was assistant to the treasurer of the Singer Company.

ROME, Jan. 3 -- The Vatican weekly L'Osservatore della Domenica said today that military escalation in Vietnam was a "blind alley" undermining the United States' "moral and political'' position even with its friends.
SOME bridge enthusiasts get little or no opportunity to play their favorite game for the paradoxical reason that they spend all their time at tournaments.

The merger of two electronics manufacturers -- Laboratory for Electronics, Inc., of Waltham, Mass., and the Cook Electric Company of Morton Grove, Ill. -- was proposed yesterday, subject to shareholder approval. The transaction would involve an exchange of stock valued at more than $32-million.
The election of A. Theodore De Smedt as president of Isthmian Lines, Inc., operator of worldwide ocean cargo services, was announced yesterday.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 3 -- A front-page cartoon in The Times of India this morning depicted a worried administrator ruefully complaining: "The storage problem for food is becoming so acute that we are left with no alternative but to give it to the people to eat."

Ingmar Bergman's "Personna" dominated the second annual voting for screen achievement by the National Society of Film Critics. Of the eight categories, the Swedish-made drama captured three awards -- best picture, best director and best actress categories.

MINEOLA, L. I., Jan 3 -- Nine high school students were arrested today on charges of committing burglaries in 125 Levittown homes in the last seven months to obtain loot that they smashed in sledge-hammer "happenings" at psychedelic sessions.

Congratulations are in order to the Mayor, the City Planning Commission and others if they stick by their guns and insist that the York College site be located somewhere in a socalled depressed area of the city.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Scientists have learned how to prevent a monkey's emotions from affecting his heart rate and blood flow.
The Treasury announced yesterday that the Government would borrow $2.5-billion next Tuesday by selling tax-anticipation bills maturing in June.

HINDELANG, West Germany, Jan. 3 (UPI) -- Edmund Bruggmann of Switzerland, participating in his first major meet of the season, opened the Alpine ski circus today by defeating favored Jean-Claude Killy of France in the giant slalom competition of the sixth Silver Fir Alpine ski races.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 3 -- Two men who led an 11-day strike by the Wood-bridge Federation of Teachers last January surrendered to the Middlesex County sheriff today to begin sentences for criminal contempt of court.
As our nation is now subjected to mandatory capital movement curbs and is approaching restrictive measures on outbound travel, a few comments may be appropriate:

Congratulations to Wallace Turner on his long overdue expose [news series Dec. 18, 19 and 20] of the insurance industry and its deplorable record in the automobile casualty field. Perhaps this would be the proper time to follow through by exposing its practices in other areas, too.
MADRID, Jan. 3 -- Spain is expected to ask the United States for an exemption from the ban on American private investments to avoid a feared economic slump here.
The C. F. I. Steel Corporation announced yesterday in Denver a rise of $5 per net ton in the price of standard rails. The effective date of the increase is next Monday.
Gov. George Romney returned to the United States yesterday prepared to undertake 22 days of campaigning in New Hampshire before the March 12 primary there.

THE most exciting game in the recent Interzonal Chess Tournament at Sousse, Tunisia, was the Alekhine's Defense between Viktor Korchnoi of the Soviet Union and Duncan Suttles of Canada. It was a tactical thriller all the way.

National Presto Industries more than tripled its earnings in the third fiscal quarter ended Sept. 30 over the corresponding period a year earlier, the Eau Claire, Wis., manufacturer of diversified equipment announced yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 3 -- The price of gold dropped sharply in the London market today, evidently reflecting some renewal of confidence in the dollar.

The Westinghouse Broadcasting Company said yesterday that a "high" North Vietnamese diplomat in Paris had clearly confirmed to a Westinghouse correspondent that Hanoi is willing to open peace negotiations if the United States stops bombing and other acts of war against the North.

The seventh annual Dutch Winterfeest will be held at Rockefeller Center on Jan. 16 for the benefit of the Child Study Association of America. About 300 people are expected to attend the party in the skating rink and adjoining restaurants, the French and English Grill.

CAPETOWN, Jan. 3 (AP) -The retired dentist who received the world's third human heart transplant yesterday was reported in "entirely satisfactory" condition today. But a dispute arose over television rights that he had sold for $50,000 to the National Broadcasting Company.
The New York State Association of Trial Lawyers urges legislation to expand the judiciary in both the civil and supreme courts.

Princeton and Dartmouth, who finished at opposite ends of the Ivy League in basketball last year and may do so again, visit Madison Square Garden tonight in a rare double-exposure of Ivy talent in the old and celebrated arena.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Treasury announced today a loss of $450-million of gold, the second large drain on the gold stock associated with the European "gold rush" that followed devaluation of the British pound.

City housewives who have wondered what the packaged meat they bought looks like on the bottom will know in the future.
A group of Roman Catholic, Jewish and Protestant clergymen left here last night on a 22-day peace mission that will take them around the world.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -Bullish statistics for November on consumer credit and manufacturers' new orders were released today by Government agencies.
Following is the text of the statement by Robert L. Strickman asking Columbia to relinquish its rights to his filter:
ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Following are excerpts from the text of Governor Rockefeller's tenth annual message to the Legislature:
DENVER, Jan. 3 (AP) -A Fuderal judge refused today to d,.'clare the Vietnam war illegal. He thus ruled out of proposed defense for two youths accused of refusing to carry draft cards.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Half of the balance-of-payments problem could be erased by the adoption of a new shipping and shipbuilding policy. Representative James J. Howard said today.
A second suitor made a bid yesterday for about one-half of the outstanding stock of the United States Lines Company, whose management announced its thinly veiled approval.
VICTORY, Vt., Jan. 3 -Flood control dams are not usually welcomed by the communities in which they are to be located.

Canadian dollars traded in New York slipped yesterday to a spot rate of 92.45 United States cents -- the lowest level reached in months, and below parity with the United States dollar, at 92.50 cents. The development continued a declining trend for the Canadian currency, which was at the borderline of 92.49 cents in the previous session.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- "Let us harness our chariots to the destiny of history," said Assembly Majority Leader Moses M. Weinstein of Queens, moments after he took the floor for his maiden speech of the 1968 Legislature.
The operator of a giant crane was crushed to death yesterday when his 40-ton rig skidded off a slippery ramp and toppled into an excavation for a midtown office building.

The Girl Scout Council of Bergen County in New Jersey has completed acquisition of more than 660 acres, including a 79-acre lake, near Glen Spey N. Y., for what will be the largest all-girl camp in the Eastern United States.
HAVANA, Jan. 3 -- Gasoline rationing began today in Cuba for the first time since Premier Fidel Castro's revolutionary regime came to power in 1959.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 5 -The Florida Cabinet deplored today a finding by the United States Supreme Court that an inmate of the state prison at Raiford had been subjected "to a shocking display of barbarism."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Federal Aviation Administration proposed today a new rule that would require all airliners and a substantial number of other large aircraft to operate under instrument flight rules most of the time.
The Maritime Administration announced yesterday that it had taken steps in retaliation for "discriminatory" practices by the Dominican Republic against United States-flag shipping.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Five typists in a manufacturing plant have stimulated national interest in what they call an "I'm Backing Britain" campaign. They are volunteering to work an extra half-hour a day without pay to help solve Britain's economic problems.

Taking advantage of the new limit of $10 an ounce, up or down, on trading in platinum futures, traders in that commodity on the New York Mercantile Exchange sent prices down $3.50 to $7.50 an ounce yesterday.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Jan. 3--Dr. Merton J. Peck, chairman of Yale's department of economics, has been selected by President Johnson as a member of his Council of Economic Advisers.
An enclave of old New York in the East Sixties, still nearly as it was 100 years ago, was designated yesterday as a historic district by the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

TEANECK, N.J., Jan. 3 -- The fog-bound and travel weary New Jersey Americans raced off to an 18-point lead in the first-half and managed to muster enough strength to hold on for a 115-111 victory over the Kentucky Colonels at Teaneck Armory tonight.

The board of McCannErickson, Inc., the domestic division of the largest ad agency in the Interpublic Group of Companies, elected Paul Foley, its chairman, to added posts of president and chief executive officer yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- A tally completed today showed 104,893 overdue and stolen books, ranging up to 101 years old and missing as long as 39 years, were returned to the Chicago public library system yesterday, the first day of amnesty in the system's 95-year history.

Forty-one young conductors from 19 countries will compete in the sixth annual Dimitri Mitropoulos Music Competition at Carnegie Hall starting on Monday and running through Jan. 29. The contest is sponsored by the women's division of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York.
MONTREAL, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Gilles Tremblay's goal with less than seven minutes to go gave the Montreal Canadiens a 1-1 tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight in the National Hockey League.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 3 -- The dollar was in demand all over Europe today, rising to its highest point in six months against the major Continental currencies.

The National Association of Manufacturers called on the Government yesterday "to exercise long-needed fiscal and monetary discipline at home" to help meet the nation's global economic responsibilities.

The nonprofit Institute for Advanced Studies in the Theater Arts, which specializes in bringing over foreign directors to teach their techniques to American professionals, will resume operations today after being dormant for a year because of lack of funds.

" Off Off Broadway" stands for a group of coffee-house theaters, church basement-theaters, loft-theaters and theater-theaters more interested in developing new talent -- particularly new playwrights -- than in making money.

The New York musicians' union has called in Zubin Mehta, the outspoken young Indian conductor, to explain remarks he acknowledges having made about the New York Philharmonic and its musicians. "They call him Zubi Baby," said Max Arons, president of Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, "but we will talk to him like an adult, no kid stuff."

ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 3 (AP) -- At his news conference today President Rene Barrientos Ortuno said that any exchange of Jules Regis Debray for Maj. Huber Matos would have to be approved by the Bolivian people in a referendum.
A new squeeze on the supply of credit for home mortgages appears to be developing.
Plans to construct the $60million Chelsea Walk apartment complex over Pennsylvania Railroad tracks on the West Side were attacked yesterday by 17 speakers before the City Planning Commission.
ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Governor Rockefeller told the Legislature today as it opened its 191st session that the state must increase taxes by about $500-million.

THE fourth-and-one club gained two recruits from the ranks of college football coaches during the last weekend of bowl games. One is seeking the presidency of the organization and the other is not sure he wants to remain a member.

NOW that the holidays are over, recreational skiers, who enjoyed some of the best early-season conditions in years, are making way for competitive skiing. The newly reorganized Professional Ski Racers Association will present its first Alpine program of the season at Waterville Va lley (N. H.) tomorrow.
In a major rumble, the Rangers and Boston Bruins played one of the most extraordinary games of the National Hockey League season at Madison Square Garden last night.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 3 -- Barry White's 26 points and 25 rebounds paced Hofstra University to an 89-67 Metropolitan Conference basketball victory over St. Francis tonight. It was Hofstra's seventh victory in 10 games.
LANSING, Mich., Jan. 3 -Legalized wiretapping, stricter gun registration and better trained police forces were proposed for Michigan today by a special Governor's Commission on Crime Control.

The four agencies of the city's Health Services Administration, citing costs "that were escalating at an enormous rate" and the need to provide even broader services, asked yesterday for a budget next year of $671-million, an increase of 30 per cent over the current year.

DETROIT, Jan. 3 (AP) -American Motors Corporation, the only major domestic auto producer with no new national labor contract with the United Automobile Workers, laid a new offer before the union today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UPI) -- The Transportation Department allocated $1.l-billion to the states today for highway construction, leaving unfulfilled an earlier implied threat to trim the program in an economy move.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 3 -- The North Vietnamese Second Division smashed at two American artillery bases in the Queson Valley south of Danang tonight. According to first reports, 241 enemy soldiers were killed in a series of ground assaults that followed an intense mortar bombardment.
" THAT'S a store fixture -- it cannot be sold," Lucille Tomes, Bloomingdale's furniture buyer, said of a pedestal desk in a corner of the furniture department.

TIERRA AMARILLA, N. M., Jan. 3 (UPI) -- The body of Deputy Sheriff Eulogio Salazar, a key witness to the shooting raid June 5 on the Rio Arriba County Courthouse, was found today on a remote mountain road.
Less than an inch of fresh snow fell in the early morning yesterday, laying a slippery patina on already slushy streets and delaying air traffic.

STOCKPORT, England, Jan. 3 -- British trade unions have crushed the efforts of a willful North Carolina industrialist to run his English subsidiary without conforming to rigid but accepted labor practices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Government proposed today more stringent air pollution controls for 1970 model automobiles. The aim is to cut by one-third the amount of exhaust pollutants now permitted for 1968 model cars.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The decision of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy to enter the New Hampshire Democratic primary is expected to have an impact on the Republican contest there as well as change and accelerate Democratic strategy.

ACCRA, Ghana, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Vice President Humphrey arrived in Accra today on the third leg of his African goodwill tour and was welcomed by J. W. K. Harlley, deputy chairman of Ghana's ruling National Liberation Council.

Governor Rockefeller's message to the Legislature charts a reasonable course for New York State in the year ahead. There are some regrettable omissions, and we by no means agree with all the Governor's recommendations. But on balance the message is thoughtful and moderately progressive.
ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Speaker Anthony J. Travia instructed a panel today to find ways of streamlining the cumbersome committee structure of the Democratic -controlled Assembly.
Robert 35 X Smith, a 37year-old Black Muslin convicted of shooting three detectives in Brooklyn "with an intent to kill," was sentenced yesterday to 20 to 40 years in prison.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 (AP)--A Philadelphia couple whose first nine children died in infancy have lost their 10th.

Two of New York City's -and the nation's -- largest banks reported on their 1967 operations yesterday. Both showed record high profits for the full year and for the fourth quarter, improved, profit margins as well as increases in their rate of return on stockholders' investment.

In a match controversially sanctioned by the New York State Athletic Commission for the vacant world heavyweight title, Joe Frazier will oppose Buster Mathis in a championship double-header that will be the first boxing show at the new Madison Square Garden.
The Chicago Tribune Press Service, a news wire service started at the turn of the century, notified its subscribers yesterday that it would cease operations on Jan. 31.
St. John's, the defending champion, took the team lead last night in the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union's junior indoor track and field championships at the 102d Engineers Armory.

THROUGHOUT the nation, the betting line for the Super Bowl lists the Green Bay Packers as a heavy favorite over the Oakland Raiders. But the "number," as the gamblers like to say, varies. Here on Broadway, the Packers have been established as a 13 1/2-point choice.

I have always had misgivings about the law that requires a significant proportion of the populace to have Selective Service registration certificates on their person at all times. It immediately brings to mind totalitarian regimes, where identification papers are issued and must be presented immediately on demand of the authorities. My uneasiness in the past concerning this law has been mitigated to some extent by the lack of its strict enforcement.

RALEIGH, N. C., Jan. 3 -Representative James C. Gardner, who two years ago defeated Representative Harold Cooley, long-time chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, announced here today that he would seek the Republican nomination for Governor.
IRIS MURDOCH'S new novel is a tournament of poses, ranging from London necromancy to a prostitute with a heart of chilled steel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Soviet Union is believed by American officials to have supplied the Arab states with $250million in arms since the ArabIsraeli war last June.

IT'S not as though the international airlines didn't have problems already. The entire airline group has been out of favor in Wall Street for a long time. And, for the overseas carriers again, President Johnson's proposed restrictions on international travel came like a spurt of orange juice in the fuel line.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Men who retire at age 65 will receive the maximum monthly benefit provided by the new Social Security law by the year 2006.
WATERBURY, Conn., Jan 3 -- A contract dispute between the Board of Education and the teachers' association closed Waterbury's 29 public schools today, and kept 17,200 children from classes.

With his appointment of a commission to study all aspects of public welfare, President Johnson is at last openly recognizing that neither the nation nor its neediest citizens are well served by the present relief system, despite its annual cost of $8.5 billion.

MADISON, Wis., Jan. 3 -Gov. Warren P. Knowles refused today to disclose whether he would seek a third twoyear term in November, challenge Senator Gaylord Nelson for the Senate or retire from politics.

ONE of the busiest family kitchens in Manhattan is the bright anti bustling domain of the Myron Simonses. The walls are hung with copper, brass and knives from Dehillerin in Paris, and one of the proudest volumes on the kitchen shelf is that definitive volume on Italian cooking, "Il Talismano" by Ada Boni.
BATON ROUGE, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Gov. John J. McKeithen supported today a campaign to reserve the Democratic ballot position for President Johnson this year in the Presidential race in Louisiana.
A Negro organization, which was ordered this week to stop operating unfranchised bus service in Queens and Harlem, has offered to buy the city bus lines that run through Harlem.

GENEVA, Jan. 3 -- President Rene Barrientos Ortuno of Bolivia tentatively offered today to make a deal with Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba that would free Jules Regis Debray, the 27-year-old French Marxist now imprisoned in Bolivia.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Mayor Lindsay asked today for legislative permission to increase from 5 per cent to 6 per cent the maximum interest rate the city can pay on the bonds it sells. The Mayor's request met swift and favorable response in the State Legislature.

The owner of a Suffern automobile agency, who was arraigned in Federal Court in Manhattan yesterday as the "mastermind" of a scheme to defraud his local bank of $680,000, was arrested last night at his home by Rockland County authorities and charged with grand larceny.
QUESTION: What have "Gone With the Wind" and "Bonnie and Clyde" to do with the hats women will be wearing in the next few months?
A sharp increase in absenteeism because of influenza was indicated yesterday in spot-checks of local industries.
ATHENS, Jan. 3 -- Greece's revolutionary regime today dismissed four leading bankers from their posts with no explanation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The psychiatric fad these days is "identity." Walk into any room full of strangers, lift a glass and two swallows later some sadist whose pleasure derives from slashing other persons' egos will be telling you, "The trouble with you is that you don't know who you really are."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- A new rule banning the practice of "short-tendering" of stock was proposed today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Texas White House said today that $8.5-billion additional life insurance would go into effect Feb. 14 for 2.5 million Federal employes with an option for each to buy a $10,000 additional policy.
PERTH, Australia, Jan. 3 (Reuters)--Three United States women and an Australian reached the semi-finals of the Western Australian tennis championships here today.
The London Stock market moved higher along a broad front in quiet trading yesterday.

The city said yesterday that it had begun the "groundwork for expansion" of its day-care program for children. The action was called for last spring by the City Council as "the opening battle in a war against alarming increases in welfare costs."

An elderly man walked into one of the larger stores at a big regional shopping center in a New York suburb and bought an item that cost $61.15, including tax. He made out a check to the store for that amount, handed it to the clerk and waited to have his package wrapped.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Nearly all of the American combat units due in Vietnam under a 50,000-man build-up ordered last summer by President Johnson will be here by the end of the month, a United States spokesman said today.

A Queens man arrested twice before on charges of stealing cargo valued at $194,000 from Kennedy International Airport was picked up there again early yesterday by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. This time he was accused of taking women's woolen wear valued at $3,500.
The automobile industry as a whole rang out the old year yesterday on an off note with the announcement of final new car sales figures for 1967.

The recent international run on gold is being matched right here in New York's subways by a stampede to buy up tokens as a hedge against a possible increase in transit fares. The resulting queues at change booths have created irksome delays for subway riders -- to no one's advantage and everyone's annoyance.

Any new heliports that are planned along the waterfronts of Manhattan must strike a careful balance between the convenience of travelers and the convenience of the apartment dwellers living hard by the East and Hudson Rivers. The heliport atop the Pan Am Building, which we welcomed, has proved to be a mixed blessing -- convenient but noisy.

The American Newspaper Publishers Association Foundation reported yesterday that it was commissioning a major study to determine what effect, if any, pretrial crime news has on the conduct of the subsequent trial.

Two fellows may have the same incomes and general backgrounds while one is a gregarious spender and the other an aloof non-spender. Wouldn't it be nice for an advertiser to know which reads what magazines?
An effort by Moore-McCormack Lines to get five of its strikebound ships in motion again by arbitration failed yesterday when the union refused to recognize the company grievance.
AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Gordon McLendon, Dallas radio-television executive, announced today that he would be a Democratic candidate in the 1968 Texas gubernatorial race.

The city, on the basis of an accounting firm's calculations, said yesterday that if the taxi industry was granted the fare increase it desired, it would realize a 600 per cent increase in net operating income before taxes and interest payments.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 -- It may sound incredible, but the New York Knickerbockers beat the Philadelphia 76ers tonight in The Spectrum, 129 to 115.

CAPETOWN, Jan. 4 (UPI) -- Dr. Christiaan N. Barnard said today that his second heart transplantation patient, Dr. Philip Blaiberg, "at this stage is in better condition" than was the first, Louis Washkansky.
Prices moved higher for the second straight day on the London Stock Exchange despite the fact that the best gains were somewhat reduced in late dealings.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 4, (AP) -- The United States Naval Academy announced today that Bill Elias, the football coach, has been signed to a new two-year contract.
Industrial companies in the United States had cut $1-billion from their planned investments abroad for 1968 weeks before the President imposed mandatory curbs on such expenditures.
Robert A. Clark, president of the First Federal Savings and Loan Association, has been elected to the board of trustees of the Savings Association Retirement Fund.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Defense Department arms sales will reach a combined total of at least $4.5-billion to $4.6-billion over this and the next two fiscal years, Pentagon sources said today.

THE Packers held a closed practice in Green Bay yesterday after jeeps with brushes had swept four inches of snow off the field. The purpose of the practice, of course, was to prepare for the Super Bowl game on Jan. 14 in Miami where there are no jeeps with brushes -- or snowplows.
The stock market took its worst beating in more than three weeks yesterday as the list declined sharply in heavy trading.

BOSTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Fire killed approximately 12,200 persons in the United States during 1967, and property loss was estimated at some $2.07-billion, the National Fire Protection Association reported today.

The rigorous pruning of the capital budget by the City Planning Commission is another major step in the Lindsay administration's continuing battle to strengthen the city's credit. New York City badly needs schools, hospitals, libraries and bridges, but it also urgently needs restoration of the credit rating it lost during the closing years of the Wagner administration.

RICHMOND, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Federal Judge John B. Butzner Jr. held today that a departmental seniority system at the Richmond plant of Philip Morris, Inc., discriminated by design against Negroes. He ordered that the system be changed.

THOSE who came to Philharmonic Hall last night expecting to become acquainted with the Argentinian pianist, Martha Argerich, were in for a surprise. She had been scheduled to play the Beethoven C major Concerto with the New York Philharmonic conducted by Leonard Bernstein.

" Julius Caesar" was being rehearsed in the auditorium, mixed media was the topic in a classroom above it, acting was the subject in the room next door, while in another part of the school there were groups working on "Under the Sycamore Tree."
The newest bank in town is so new that the tellers must wear construction workers' safety headgear.
A prominent art dealer bought $300,000 worth of paintings at a recent Parke-Bernet auction by putting his eyeglasses in the breast pocket of his jacket, with one side-piece hanging out.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 4 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy said today that he could back President Johnson for re-election this year despite their disagreement over the war in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Post Office Department officials predicted today that the $900-million increase in postal rates starting Sunday -- the most extensive rate change in history -- would cost about $22-million to put into effect.

CAIRO, Jan. 4 -- The United Arab Republic said today that it would proceed with plans to remove 15 stranded vessels from the Suez Canal without consulting Israel, whose troops occupy the Canal's east bank.

Brezhnev, to the United Arab Republic.
THERE have been times during the very active political and diplomatic career of Chester Bliss Bowles when people have asked, "What ever happened to Chester Bowles?"
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Representative Melvin R. Laird, Republican of Wisconsin, said today that Governor Rockefeller would make the strongest race naginst President Johnson.

Digital systems that convert all forms of information -- speech, data or pictures -- into streams of pulses are speeding the day when telephone users will see each other as they talk, or watch figures spewing from a computer, H. I. Romnes, chairman and chief executive officer of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said here yesterday.

WHEN a declarer has all the trump honors except the king, he usually prays that the king will be favorably located in front of the ace and resigns himself to losing a trick if the king is a singleton on the wrong side.
KINSHASA, the Congo, Jan. 4 (AP) -- About 150 Congolese youths carrying anti-American banners charged into Vice President Humphrey's motorcade today.

A Dec. 16 news item from Chicago reported that "about 150 sign-waving residents of a South Side slum burst into the American Medical Association's first conference on health care for the poor today and expressed dismay that poor people were not represented."

BRUSSELS, Jan. 4 -- Belgium, where the heavy weight of American foreign investments has fallen in recent years, will open talks in Washington later this month to try to soften the impact on her economy of President Johnson's dollar defense measures.

The British pound climbed to $2.4089 on the dollar, to close with a 19-point gain above the previous session, when it stood at $2.4070. Activity was generally subdued.

PERHAPS with his tongue in his cheek, some bright spirit at the Lincoln Center Repertory Company has quoted in the program on "Saint Joan" a statement by the author. It says: "Everyone, to my disgust, assures me it is the best play I have written."

MADRID, Jan. 4 -- Prince Juan Carlos de Borbon y Borbon will turn 30 years old tomorrow and, under the Spanish succession law, will become eligible to be King of Spain. His birthday, therefore, could be a significant date in this nation's political calendar.

In his news conference this week, Secretary of State Rusk seemed to place considerable emphasis not only on finding a way to end the war in Vietnam but on achieving a "durable" peace in all of Southeast Asia.
Sentiment is mounting among leaders of the "dump Johnson" movement here, the Coalition for a Democratic Alternative, for running an anti-Administration candidate in the party's Senate primary.
A group that calls itself the Black Caucus in the Unitarian-Universalist Church is preparing for a confrontation with white members over a program formulated by the Negro group.

The one thing that emerges unmistakably from the taxicab financial surveys made by accountants for the taxi fleet owners is that neither provides data remotely adequate to establish what level of fares the city should authorize.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that the United States was trying through diplomatic channels to learn whether North Vietnam, in its latest statement on peace talks, was seeking to move toward negotiations or merely trying to put propaganda pressure on the Johnson Administration.
MIAMI, Jan. 4 -- Ernesto Che Guevara is reported to have failed in a six-month effort to organize a guerrilla movement in the Congo before he went to Bolivia, where he was killed last October.

MOSCOW, Jan. 4 -- A Soviet political commentator, Vladimir Kudryavtsev, said tonight that the United States was planning to send troops into Cambodia and Laos as part of a broad strategy of entrenchment on the Asian continent.
The New York Post Office has turned away four persons who tried to claim a package containing $44,000 in cash that firemen had found after a fire in the Morgan Annex on Dec. 15.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 4 -- Five former Clark Township officials who were sentenced in 1966 for conspiracy to extort $5,000 for a zoning variance surrendered today to Union County Sheriff Ralph Oriscello to begin serving three months each in the county jail.
Manhattan's major office buildings are virtually filled to capacity, with 1967 having the lowest over-all vacancy rate in nearly a decade, according to a study by the Real Estate Board of New York.

Premier Levi Eshkol of Israel arrived yesterday at Kennedy International Airport on a nine-day visit to the United States during which he is expected to seek military equipment and aircraft to offset the flow of Soviet arms to Egypt and Syria.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Government accepted 11 planes and several dozen antiaircraft guns from Communist China today and said once again that it was threatened by the United States.
Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that he would vote against a tax on travelers because it would not affect the wealthy in the same way as it would the "school-teacher" traveler.
CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (UPI) -- Lee Trevino, a professional golfer for only two years, was named rookie of 1967 today by the Professional Golfers' Association.

ADEN, Southern Yemen, Jan. 4 -- The Southern Yemeni Minister of Commerce, Economy and Planning said today that a few American oil companies have expressed interest in undertaking surveys for oil in the territory and that the Ministry was considering the matter.

The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, one of the nation's largest banks, reported record 1967 profits yesterday, continuing the trend established in earlier reports by major banks here and elsewhere.
MOSCOW, Jan. 4 -- Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party chief, is reported to have postponed plans for a visit to the United Arab Republic this month.

HONG KONG, Jan. 4 -- North Vietnam may be trying to "buy" a cessation of United States bombing, in the view of observers here who have studied the comment last Saturday by Foreign Minister Nguyen Duy Trinh.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said today that he had ordered an inquiry into state purchases from five drug companies named in Federal anti-trust convictions Friday.

NEWARK, Jan. 4 -- LeRoi Jones, the militant Negro writer, was sentenced today to two and a half to three years in the New Jersey State Penitentiary and fined $1,000 for illegal possession of two revolvers during the Newark riots last summer.
A change in senior management was announced here yesterday by the National Dairy Products Corporation, a leading producer of processed packaged food.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 4 -- The feeling is growing, even among those who once applauded the idea, that the brief holiday cease-fires in the Vietnam war are almost meaningless.
ATLANTA, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Influenza and other respiratory ailments have spread from the Eastern Seaboard to Colorado, with outbreaks reported in 32 states and the District of Columbia.
Federal, state and city officials reached agreement here yesterday on plans for a $220-million sewage treatment system for Manhattan's West Side.

MOSCOW, Jan. 4 -- Pavel M. Litvinov, a Russian physicist who defied a warning from the Soviet secret police and sent to the West an account of the trial of a fellow dissident, remained at liberty today more than a week after the publication of the material.
CONCORD, N. H., Jan. 4 -- Snow-loaders were struggling today to clear parking space at curbs along Main and other streets in downtown Concord, the state capital.

Hospital Department officials said yesterday that on Jan. 1 several voluntary hospitals abandoned a "gentlemen's agreement" to hold nurses' salaries to a maximum of $200 a year higher than the $6,400 the city pays its nurses.
A full-size mockup of a spacecraft that is to land two American astronauts on the moon descended gently on 58th Street yesterday afternoon.

WATERBURY, Conn., Jan. 4 -- School teachers who walked off the job two days ago in a contract dispute with the Board of Education voted unanimously today to return to work tomorrow.

WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 4 -- Leroy Copeland came to Roosevelt Raceway for this winter harness racing meeting and a second try at the big time. Before he donned his white-and-green silks for the fifth race tonight, the 27-year-old Copeland, who was born in Bad Axe, Mich., picked up a check for $3,970.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Backers of Richard M. Nixon have failed for the second time to find someone to succeed former Gov. Henry Bellmon of Oklahoma as chairman of the Nixon-for-President Committee, Mr. Nixon's main campaign organization.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 4 -- Western diplomats here and in Vientiane discounted today an Associated Press report from the Laotian capital that Nguyen Chan, the North Vietnamese charge d'affaires, had inquired whether Laos would be host to peace talks.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 4 (UPI) -- The All-America Track and Field Games will kick off the Olympic year at the Cow Palace tomorrow night with something for everyone.
Federal Reserve credit policy is continuing to move toward restraint, banking statistics released yesterday indicated.
Acting Police Commissioner John F. Walsh asked yesterday for nearly $3-million to hire civilians to perform tasks now being done by city patrolmen.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Governor Rockefeller's top aides remained closeted at the Executive Mansion for the third straight day, trying to work out a tax-increase plan to balance the Governor's forthcoming record budget.
Prices fell rather sharply yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. Volume was its second biggest in history.

Mayor Lindsay submitted to the state yesterday a revised school decentralization plan that would give the City Board of Education substantially greater powers than those proposed by his advisory panel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Americans cashed in more savings bonds than they bought in December, but because of accrued interest their holdings of E and H Bonds reached a record $51.4-billion at year's end, the Treasury Department reported today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 4 -- Work toward a long-term settlement of the Greek-Turkish crisis in Cyprus appeared today to be paralyzed by disagreement about the extent of Secretary General Thant's powers to act in the dispute.

PARIS -- International sports as practiced nowadays undoubtedly have significance that transcends the field of purely athletic competition. The idea of sports for sports' sake has altered since 1896, when competition resumed among teams from different countries participating in the modern Olympic games.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4 (UPI) -- The Akron Goodyears, the defending world champions, crushed Botafogo de Futbol of Rio de Janeiro, 84-52, tonight to reach the final of the third World Cup championships at the Palestra.

HAVANA, Jan. 4 -- An international cultural congress devoted to the revolutionary aspirations of Asia, Africa and Latin America opened here today, somewhat dimmed by the absence of such scheduled participants as Jean-Paul Sartre and Graham Greene.

LONDON, Jan. 4 (UPI) -- The British Boxing Board of Control said today it would not recognize the bout between Joe Frazier and Buster Mathis for the world heavyweight championship in the new Madison Square Garden in New York on March 8.

THERE'S no one named Gussie or Becky at Gussie Becky. Ruth Graves, designer and owner of the boutique at 20 St. Mark's Place, just likes to play with names. Now there's a new Gussie Becky up one flight at 717 Lexington Avenue (between 57th and 58th Streets).
The sidewalk in front of an East Harlem store where a man was giving away free shoes collapsed yesterday and more than a dozen persons toppled into a rubble strewn cellar.
In a marriage of convenience and necessity, the two major United States soccer leagues officially merged yesterday and agreed to call themselves, simply, the Professional Soccer league.

All the stock of Highland Films, which produced the 1966 Academy Award film, "A Man For All Seasons," for Columbia Pictures, has been acquired by the Realty Equities Corporation of 375 Park Avenue. The purchase price was not disclosed.

Platinum futures prices took a nosedive again yesterday, dropping the new limit of $10 for the nearby January, 1968, contract on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Prices for the other contracts also showed drops ranging from $7 an ounce to $9.50 an ounce.

ROME, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Vatican denied today that there was friction between Pope Paul VI and President Johnson at a meeting on Dec. 23 where they discussed the Vietnamese war. "The cordiality of the meeting was not disturbed by misunderstandings," said a communique printed in the Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano.

Heavy, drifting snows blocked roads in Western Great Lakes snowbelt communities yesterday, and the temperature hit 46 degrees below zero in the upper Midwest.
ATHENS, Jan 4 -- Greek excavations of a prehistoric site on the Aegean island of Thera will be barred to all foreign archeologists this year, Greece's Antiquities Department announced today.

THE cancellation of the merger plans of the American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., and the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation promises to have many repercussions. The A.B.C. hierarchy is determined to go it alone for the immediate future, reduce overhead and arrange new financing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Traffic on the nation's scheduled airlines reached a new high last year, 29 per cent above the 1966 figure, the president of the Air Transport Association of America reported today.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 4 (UPI) -- Negro members of the St. Louis Football Cardinals said today that they had signed a two-page list of grievances and submitted the list to the team's coach Charley Winner.
NEWARK, Jan. 4 (UPI) -- Henry David Thoreau was not a "true hippie," nor was his daily walking companion, William Ellery Channing 2d, a professor at Rutgers said today.

MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 4 -- The Department of the Interior said today that it was prepared to establish a Federal wildlife preserve in an area on the North Shore that has been proposed as the site of a bridge across Long Island Sound.

PERTH, Australia, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Mrs. Margaret Smith Court of Australia defeated Rosemary Casals of San Francisco, 4-6, 8-6, 6-4, today in the women's singles semi-finals of the West Australian tennis championships. The match lasted 105 minutes.
THOSE professional skeptics at the Securities and Exchange Commission have been asking embarrassing questions of organizations that make a business of advising people to buy stock.

Princeton University's Ivy League champions came back to Madison Square Garden last night for the first time since the glorious days of Billy Bradley and raced to a 78-62 victory over New York University.
Bond prices surged to their best gains in a year yesterday as rumors of possible moves toward peace in Vietnam swirled through Wall Street.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 4 -- A committee appointed by Cornell University's board of trustees has recommended separating the university and its Cornell Aeronautical Laboratory in Buffalo, which has a number of classified defense contracts.
Ernest Gallashaw, acquitted in the 1966 fatal shooting of 10-year-old Erie Dean during racial unrest in Brooklyn, was arrested yesterday for allegedly renting submachine guns to bank robbers.

An alleged racket in which people paid proxies $200 or more to take driver tests they themselves could not pass resulted in the arrest yesterday of a Bronx insurance broker and a clerk.

The Maritime Committee of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. urged increased use of United-States-flag ships yesterday to eliminate the country's balance-of-payments deficit. At the same time it took issue with one of President Johnson's suggestions for closing the dollar gap.
The Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, the nation's largest food chain, showed slight gains in sales and earnings in the nine months ended with November, the company reported yesterday.
The Transit Authority received a grant of $170,000 from the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development yesterday to finance a study of new methods for air-conditioning subway cars.

Among the great treasurehouses of American history in Washington is the National Archives. Yet unlike two comparable and revered institutions -- the Smithsonian and Library of Congress -- Archives does not function as an independent agency. The Office of Archivist was lowered in rank eighteen years ago; now it is merely another bureau within the General Services Administration, a housekeeping organization that is not primarily interested in the scholarly burdens of the National Archives.

CAPETOWN, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Dr. Blaiberg's lawyers announced today that he and his wife would share with others any money they were due to receive under a contract they signed last week with the National Broadcasting Company of New York for television rights.

MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 4 -- A 13-year-old boy who has been frequently absent from public school because of illness and participation in peace demonstrations has been charged with truancy. His parents have been charged with negligence.
BOSTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Judge Harry Kalus of Superior Court today banned further showings of the "Titicut Follies," a film made of inmates in Bridgewater State Mental Hospital.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Government has licensed the nation's first live virus vaccine against mumps, a disease believed to strike about 80 per cent of Americans before adulthood.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk defended today the proposed curtailment of foreign travel on the ground that American tourists must "share the burden" in correcting the nation's deficit in international payments.

IN TODAY'S new shelving systems, everything hinges on the knuckles -- those all-important little joints that hold together complete storage units for books or art objects.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 4 (Reuters) -- A new treatment for a painful facial affliction was announced here today, one day after the death of its developer.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 4 (UPI) -- Gov. Lurleen B. Wallace announced tonight that doctors in Houston had found a small, possibly malignant, nodule in her pelvic area. The nodule will require radioactive therapy.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 4 -- Protestant and Orthodox officials and a Rabbi participated today in the consecration of a Roman Catholic Bishop, the Most Rev. Mark J. Hurley, in a sharp break with Catholic tradition.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.
DETROIT, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Two rival Negro groups formed to help rehabilitate Detroit's riot-torn areas have been offered $100,000 matching grants to carry on their work if they keep on speaking terms.
The Xerox Corporation is planning to expand its education division through the proposed acquisition of Ginn Co., the Boston textbook publisher, whose assets exceed $35-million.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Republican gains in the House of Representatives in the November election will probably fall short of forming a majority, a national survey indicates.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 4 (UPI) -- The Pittsburgh Pipers moved to within two games of a professional basketball record tonight by downing the Kentucky Colonels, 107-98.

Sears, Roebuck Co., and the J. C. Penney Company, two of the country's largest retailers, each achieved higher sales in December than in any single previous month in their histories, according to reports issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman, who recently won a fight to put a new road through a national park, now faces an equally emotional road issue.

VIENNA, Jan. 4 -- The German-language premiere of "Man of La Mancha" was a roaring success at the Theater in der Wein here tonight. Judged by the applause and the last 15-minute ovation alone, the production seems assured of becoming the highlight of the theatrical season here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan Jr. turned down today a bid by Pennsylvania officials to keep new residents off welfare rolls.

Daryle Lamonica of the Oakland Raiders, who went from the No. 2 quarterback on the No. 2 team to the No. 1 quarterback on the No. 1 team in one season, was chosen the United Press International player of the year yesterday in the American Football League.
Abraham D. Beame, former City Controller, accused the Lindsay administration last night of bringing on a financial crisis "that means just one thing -- more taxes next year."

CONCORD, N. H., Jan. 4 (UPI) -- The State of New Hampshire filed a petition today for a declaratory judgment in Merrimack County Superior Court against four members of the Robert F. Kennedy for President Write-In Committee.

BOGUE CHITTO, Ala., Jan. 4 (AP) -- This central Alabama community of about 10 whites land 200 Negroes has no telephone service, and the Negro residents are unhappy about it.
PHILIPPE COUSTEAU, now 27 years old, went under water with an Aqualung to a depth of 15 feet when he was only 4, an age at which most children haven't yet had their first swimming lesson.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Defense Department plans to ask Congress for permission to delay or cancel orders for hundreds of millions of dollars worth of low-priority military equipment and facilities so that more money will be available to meet the cost of the war in Vietnam.
LONDON, Jan. 4 -- British quarters view the North Vietnamese statement about negotiations with the United States as a shift from previous comments by Hanoi.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 4 (UPI) -- District Attorney Jim Garrison of New Orleans today subpoenaed a Federal civil service employe he said "may have special knowledge" of the assassination of President Kennedy.

A new 6-cent stamped envelope went on first-day sale yesterday in the office of Postmaster John R. Strachan in the General Post Office, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street. The stamp has the head of the Statue of Liberty embossed in white against a pale green background.
