BEDFORD, N. H., Jan. 4 -- Governor Rockefeller of New York told a group of New Hampshire Republicans tonight that the moderates of the party had a rare opportunity to unite behind Gov. George Romney of Michigan as their nominee for President this year.

MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 4 -- A $50,000 defamation-of-character suit brought by a Negro high school teacher against a 16-year-old white girl student who had accused him of molesting her was withdrawn today in State Supreme Court.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 4 -- Sheik Mohammed Abdullah urged Prime Minister Indira Gandhi today to take up the work of reconciliation between India and Pakistan that was interrupted by the death of her father, Jawaharlal Nehru, in 1964.
Volume remained strong on the American Stock Exchange yesterday and prices came alive, too.

A welfare budget of nearly $1.4-billion -- all of it mandated by rising relief rolls and increasing Medicaid costs -- was submitted yesterday by the Human Resources Administrator, Mitchell I. Ginsberg.

ARTUR RUBINSTEIN, nothing if not indefatigable, started the first of nine recitals last night. These will be shared between Carnegie Hall and Philharmonic Hall, and last night's was at 57th Street. Naturally every seat in the house was taken.
SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 5 -The Government today asked the United States for special consideration in the administration of its restrictions on capital investment overseas.

HONOLULU, Jan. 5 (AP) -A two-page inventory was filed today in Honolulu Circuit Court showing that Henry J. Kaiser, philanthropist and industrialist, left an estate subject to probate in Hawaii of more than $4,156,213.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 5 (Reuters) -- The head of the Nigerian Federal military government, Maj. Gen. Yakubu Gowon, pledged today to halt war operations against the secessionist eastern region if Ibo tribal leaders gave what he termed a positive response to his offer for negotiations.
Christmas sales of retail chain stores were near their all-time high, according to reports received yesterday.
The Maritime Administration said yesterday that 1968 might be the year that determines the course of the United States Merchant Marine.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 5 (AP) -- A special session of the lame-duck Senate was scheduled today for the eve of the opening of the 1968 Legislature. The purpose is to salvage key nominations blocked in the Senate last month. The special session will begin Monday.

NEWARK, Jan. 5, (UPI) -LeRoi Jones, the Negro poetplaywright, will be transferred to Trenton State Prison tomorrow to begin serving a 2 1/2-to3-year sentence for carrying guns during last summer's race riot in Newark.
A controversy has developed over the selection of a superintendent to head a local school district that covers East Harlem and part of West Harlem.

A contract dispute that has idled 1.500 overseas communications employes of the Radio Corporation of America here entered its sixth week yesterday with the parties as far apart as ever, according to a state mediator.
Willie Mays arrived yesterday in New York, where it all began 18 years ago, and said he hoped to be playing baseball long enough to hit his 600th home run.

The Mimi Garrard Dance Theater showed last night that a little undigested exposure to the avant-garde can be a stimulating but unsettling thing on a young artist. The flamboyant Stendhal used to read passages from the Napoleonic Code for the cleansing effect it had on his style, and the rote movement equivalent might have helped Miss Garrard clear her choreographic way.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The war in Vietnam kept the F.B.I. busy last year chasing draft evaders and investigating a rising number of thefts of Government property, Mr. Hoover also reported. He said this was probably related to the increase in military expenditures resulting from the war.

ATLANTA, Jan. 5 (UPI) -- One of the nation's first practical attempts to stem a mumps epidemic through use of a newly developed vaccine will be made in White County, Ga., within the next 10 days, the state Health Department announced today.

PARIS, Jan. 5 -- Pressures are starting to mount for tax cuts in continental Europe as a means of stimulating economies affected by President Johnson's dollar-defense measures and the sterling devaluation.
DANANG, South Vietnam, Jan. 5 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today there had been an improvement in the refugee situation in Vietnam since his visit here two years ago.
Uncertainty, tinged with tentative optimism, hung thickly over the merger of the two major United States soccer leagues yesterday in the second day of meetings at the Waldorf-Astoria.
The Rev. Lauri J. Anderson, in a letter published Dec. 18, takes a curiously shortsighted point of view of expertise.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Jna. 6 (AP) -SAIGON,] South Vietnam, President Ngu-] yen Van Thieu said today that South Vietnam would welcome i"any movement or any informal :talks from any goverument to: bring peace for Vietnam.

New York City has a new gun control law that will take effect Feb. 15. It requires all persons owning or buying "long guns" to obtain a license from a new Firearms Control Board and to register the weapons. Only persons with gun permits will be allowed to buy ammunition.
Pat Cooper, an Italian Sam Levenson, is redressing ethnic imbalance in the stand-up comic field for a few weeks at the Americana's Royal Box, where he shares the bill with Buddy Greco.

Representative William Fitts Ryan, Democrat of Manhattan, protested yesterday against the selection of an Upper West Side site for the city's new Hudson River sewage treatment plant, and said he had been assured that the decision was not yet final.

EVER since Col. Rudolph Abel started the ball rolling a few years ago, a spy who gets caught in the cold goes to prison for a while, is swapped for an opposite number, then returns home and writes a book that trumpets his captor's inefficiency. As both sides play the game, it has become increasingly difficult to tell an espionage agent from a literary agent.

The Metropolitan Opera's fifth and final new production of the season, Verdi's "Luisa Miller," will be introduced Thursday, Feb. 8. The performance will benefit the Metropolitan Opera Guild. The title role will be sung by Montserrat Caballe, Richard Tucker will be Rodolfo and Sherrill Milnes will sing Miller.
The Ford Foundation announced yesterday a $230,000 grant to train Negro ministers in urban leadership and help them start local programs that deal with the crisis of the cities.
Two finance companies, one in New York and the other in Philadelphia, have filed bankruptcy petitions in the last few days.
A ROUNDUP of visionary concepts of the uses of outer space was presented last night by the National Broadcasting Company's news department in a program entitled 'Beyond the Sky.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -Senator William Proxmire listed today the names of 23 defense contractors among thousands that he said were wasting "hundreds of millions of dollars a year" through improper use of Defense Department property.
The seven unions that form the Maritime Committee of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. will undertake a large-scale legislative and political action program this year, it was announced yesterday.

Ralph Berger, whose conviction as a bribery fixer in the 1962-63 liquor license scandal was reversed by the United States Supreme Court, won a $3,716.97 judgment yesterday in State Supreme Court as reimbursement for court costs of his final appeal.
Sampson Knight, a 9-year-old brown gelding, driven by James Callahan, won the featured fifth race -- a $5,000 pace -- in 2:06 2/5. He paid $10.20 for $2 to win.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 5 (AP) -The Florida Land Sales Board was ordered today to remove its disciplinary monitors from the Gulf American Corporation offices, but the board later ordered the monitors back on the job.

Michael Steinberg, who received a master's degree from the Juilliard School of Music in 1964 and played several piano recitals in Europe and Puerto Rico before joining the faculty of the University of Connecticut in September, made his New York recital debut last night at Town Hall.

A proposal to have the state instead of the city take over the 12-acre site of the old Steeplechase Park in Coney Island and convert it to a seafront park has been made by August Heckscher, the City Parks Commissioner.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 5 -- "Why else did they release me?" Sheik Mohammed Abdullah asked a caller last evening after returning from a meeting with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -The Administration came under mounting pressure today to halt the air, ground and naval bombardment of North Vietnam to test Hanoi's latest offer to begin talks.

Eleven firemen and two residents of a West Side hotel suffered from smoke inhalation yesterday in a fire that started in a room on the seventh floor and sent smoke to the upper floors of the 20-story building. No one was injured seriously.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- The "I'm Backing Britain" campaign attracted wider support today despite continuing attacks by union leaders on the idea of working overtime without pay. Representatives of the three major political parties, Conservative, Labor and Liberal, backed the movement at a news conference called by Colt Heating and Ventilation, Ltd., the company where the campaign started.
Retroactive to Sept. 1, 1967, the pay range for full professors in the senior colleges will rise from $15,350 -- $22,000 to $16,230 -- $23,330.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 5 -- Premier Levi Eshkol of Israel conferred for 40 minutes today with Secretary General Thant.
The New York State Nurses Association charged yesterday that "collusion" among voluntary hospitals was the main reason for low salaries for nurses.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Jan. 6 -- The announced loss of five more planes -- four in North Vietnam and one in the South -- has pushed American combat aircraft losses in the war in Vietnam past 1,000.

A fact-finding mission of three clergymen and a layman that visited Spain to inquire into the new religious climate for non-Roman Catholic minority faiths reported yesterday that most Catholic and non-Catholic spokesmen "have serious reservations and misgivings" about one aspect of it.
A shipping industry committee that has been carrying on a heated debate with the Maritime Administration over Federal rate controls plans to carry the dispute to a Government grievance committee.
CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- A stringent gun control ordinance was submitted by Mayor Richard J. Daley to the City Council today and was received favorably by Aldermen.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Revenue freight traffic generated by carloadings on United States railroads in the latest week ended Dec. 30 was below the corresponding period last year.
NEWARK, Jan. 5 -- Milton Sunbury walked out of his house in Newark one morning 19 years ago with a black eye.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -The Government seized today in Denver a large number of thyroid and thyroid-digitalis tablets that the Food and Drug Administration said had been promoted for use in weight reduction programs.

An injury to Erick Hawkins in rehearsal on Thursday has resulted in the cancellation of his modern-dance company's New York season, which scheduled performances Monday through Jan. 14 at the Theater of the Riverside Church.
Dr. Benjamin Spock said last night he hoped "that 100,000, 200,000 or even 500,000 young Americans either refuse to be drafted or to obey orders if in military service."
MOSCOW, Jan. 5 -- The Soviet Union has charged that United States aircraft seriously damaged a Soviet merchant vessel while bombing the North Vietnamese port of Haiphong yesterday.

Thomas Simons, who made his New York recital debut a little more than a year ago, played again in his home town last night, in the Young Artists Series at the Metropolitan Museum. The 24-year-old pianist has a lot of things going for him -- a fluid, effortless technique, a resonant tone, a thorough-going sense of professionalism.

Antiques from collections of young New York socialites will be on display at the 14th annual Winter Antiques Show to be held Jan. 19 to 28 at the Seventh Regiment Armory at 66th Street and Park Avenue.

The masque of dictatorship in Greece serves to illustrate the interplay of the free arts and enlightened government. "The god of war hates those who hesitate," Euripides wrote for ancient Greece. The modern Greek militarists did not hesitate for a moment when they seized power. They immediately banned plays by Euripides, Aeschylus and Sophocles.

A certified public accountant who was said to have cashed more than $16-million in checks over four years for bookmakers, loansharks and businessmen for a fee was convicted by a jury in Federal District Court yesterday of evading $33,000 in income taxes for 1959 through 1962.
HONG KONG, Jan. 5 -- Following is the text of questions cabled to Prince Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia by The New York Times and the prince's answers, in unofficial translation from the French:
As new proof that it often takes money to make money, the city's tax collector asked yesterday for $5.1-million more to defray the costs of collecting personal and business income taxes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- A Florida inventor believes he has achieved a major advance in detecting dangerous and costly leaks from gas pipelines. He makes the escaping gas visible by turning it into a bluish-white smoke.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Following is the text of a letter on the personal effects of President Kennedy gathered as evidence after his assassination and deposited by the Kennedy family in the Archives of the United States:
ALGIERS, Jan. 5 -- President Houari Boumediene said today that the attempted coup against his regime last month had not shaken his determination to continue the development of Algeria.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 5 (UPI) -- The United States Lawn Tennis Association will approve some form of open t nis at its meeting Feb. 3, Ed Turville, U.S.L.T.A. president, said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The United States expressed regret to the Soviet Union today for damage to the Soviet freighter in Haiphong harbor during an American air raid, but said that if American planes were responsible, it was an accident.
CAPETOWN, Jan. 5 (UPI) -- Dr. Philip Blaiberg, the world's third heart transplant patient, ate solid food today for the first time since his operation on Tuesday.

OBERSTAUFEN, West Germany, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Fernande Bochatay, aided by an early start that kept her out of blinding snow, continued Swiss dominance of the early ski season by winning the first event of the women's World Alpine Skiing Cup today.

BONN -- There are two things German men hate to be caught in: Bermuda shorts and the kitchen. Disdain is still the fate of Bermudas, but a growing number of men can now be found in oversize kitchens throughout Germany, slaving over hot stoves in their spare time.

MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 5 (UPI) -- Football fans with a fondness for passing should get their fill tomorrow in the 19th annual Senior Bowl game. Both teams boast passing combinations of record-setting caliber.

A labor union official contributed $10 yesterday to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in memory of C. C. Lane, retired associate business manager of The Times who died on Dec. 27 at the age of 84.

ALMOST a year ago the Catherine Viviano Gallery, 42 East 57th Street, mounted an important exhibition of the paintings of the late Max Beckmann (1884-1950) -- an event that has remained, for this observer at least, one of the high points of the 1967 exhibition calendar.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- J. Edgar Hoover said today American Communists were finding the black power movement tailor-made to their efforts to stir up racial unrest.
Mayor Lindsay's specific modifications of the Bundy panel's report have turned the original proposals for decentralization of the city school system into a far more realistic plan of action.
STOCKHOLM, Jan. 5 (UPI) -- The Government said today that two more United States servicemen had asked for political asylum in Sweden to escape duty in the Vietnam war.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 5 -- Dr. Arnold M. Rose, professor of sociology at the University of Minnesota, died of cancer on Tuesday. He was 49 years old and lived here.

WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 5 -Tom Strong might be an appropriate name for an all-American boy. In the case of Claude Paradis, a French-Canadian harness driver, here for the winter meeting at Roosevelt Raceway, Tom Strong is an equally appropriate name for a horse who enjoys racing in subfreezing temperatures or when it's snowing.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5 -- In the second consecutive victory under Red Holzman, their new coach, the New York Knickerbockers showed that winning breeds winning. After two defeats at the start of Holzman's tenure, the Knicks upset the Philadelphia 76ers here Wednesday night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Five men, including Dr. Benjamin Spock, the author and pediatrician, and the Rev. William Sloane Coffin Jr., chaplain of Yale University, were indicted today on charges of conspiring to counsel young men to violate the draft laws.

PAINTINGS of social consciousness, including the theme of the Negro's struggle for civil rights, have been most successful in this country recently when understated. Melodramatization has been less effective than straightforward illustration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy said today that some public evidence of support from Senators Robert F. and Edward M. Kennedy would be helpful in his primary campaign challenge to the Vietnam war policy of President Johnson.

FOR the last few years, fashionable women have been wrapping their heads in fur during wintry weather and tying abstract-printed silk scarves under their chins in the spring. But most of the time they have been wearing long, straight hair -- as long as they could manage.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UPI) -- All the turboprop airliners grounded because of possible control trouble were able to return to regular service after inspections, the Federal Aviation Administration said today.

Hunt Foods and Industries, Inc., estimated its net income for the six months ended Dec. 31 yesterday at $8,210,000, equal to $1.12 a common share, adjusted for a 5 per cent stock dividend paid last May. This compares with $6,055,000, or 80 cents a share, earned in the corresponding months of the preceding fiscal year.

TEANECK, N. J., Jan. 5 -- Joe Hamood's 20-foot jump shot, followed by a free throw as he was fouled on the shot, broke a tie game with 3 seconds to play tonight and gave the Houston Mavericks a 107-104 victory over the New Jersey Americans at Teaneck Armory.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Vietcong terrorists killed 3,820 civilians in 1967, more than double the 1,618 slain in the previous year, the United States mission said today.

Columbia served notice on the Ivy League last night that the Lions might be the team to beat for the basketball championship. Jack Rohan's poised club almost ran Yale off the University gymnasium court in scoring a 100-72 decision.
LONDON, Jan. 5 -- Britain's horse bettors were unleashed today after a famine of 40 days.
TOKYO, Jan. 5 -- The Bank of Japan decided today to raise the official discount rate by 0.365 per cent, to 6.205 per cent per annum. The new rate will take effect tomorrow.

HONG KONG, Jan. 5 -- Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's Chief of State, said today that improved relations between his country and the United States could result from the visit to Pnompenh next week of Chester Bowles.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 5 -Vice President Humphrey pledged here today continuing United States help to this landlocked country and sharply assailed the "retrogressive policies" of its southern neighbors.

Two nuns seized a woman medical secretary who allegedly was burglarizing an office in their Brooklyn parochial school yesterday. The secretary was trying to get money to satisfy her $40-a-day heroin addiction, the police reported.
VIENNA, Jan. 5 -- Antonin Novotny has been ousted as the Czechoslovak Communist party chief, the Czechoslovak press agency CTK confirmed tonight. However, he will remain as President of the country.

The Canadian dollar eased further here yesterday, dipping to a new low for the currency in recent months, to close at 92.39 United States cents, well below its parity with the United States dollar of 92.50 cents and 6 points below the 92.45 cents on Thursday.
DETROIT, Jan. 5 -- Thomas W. Binford, an Indianapolis industrialist, was re-elected today as president of the automobile competition committee for the United States for a third consecutive term.

MANY collectors complain about the impossibility of finding significant additions to the important collections of early American silver. The story behind the rare 17th-century drinking bowl recently acquired by the Minneapolis Institute of Art should give them hope.

WATERVILLE VALLEY, N. H., Jan. 5 (AP) -- John Clough of Hanover, N. H., celebrated his debut as a professional ski racer today by winning a dual slalom against a strong field of former Olympic medalists from Europe.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., Jan. 5 -Visiting one of the largest Indian schools in the West, Senator Robert F. Kennedy said today that he was dismayed at the nation's "betrayal" of the Indians in failing to provide suitable education for them.

Another installment of the American dream -- owning one's very own business and being a big boss -- went on display at the Coliseum yesterday.
AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 5 (UPI) -Two turbine-powered race cars using a new four-wheel-drive concept will be entered in the Indianapolis 500-mile race this year.

It was unfortunate that the Rev. Eugene S. Callender, the new deputy administrator of the Housing and Development Administration, should have injected race into his recent interview with a New York Times reporter concerning housing in Harlem.
Financing arrangements were announced yesterday for the first large, new United States merchant ships with diesel-propulsion machinery since the end of World War II.

The Freedom House statement on East Asian policy signed by fourteen scholars and published in The Times [Dec. 20] obviously is going to draw many petulant letters from experts on contemporary Asian affairs, who, as a group, seem to display more emotional than professional involvement.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The National Broadcasting Company has sent a letter to the Federal Communications Commission stating that the demand of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy for equal time to answer President Johnson's Dec. 19 broadcast is without merit and should be denied.
MANY years ago the late Edward Hymes Jr. bluffed no less a person than Howard Schenken by brazenly bidding a grand slam when holding two immediate losers in the suit bid by Schenken's side.
Platinum futures prices tumbled yesterday for the third session.
Industrial issues were down yesterday in luckluster trading on the London Stock Exchange.
Simon and Schuster, the publishing house, has lost three key executives to Alfred A. Knopf, a subsidiary of Random House.

The bond market, after some early hesitation, registered another strong advance yesterday and finished the week with gains in every session. Yesterday's gains were not as great as those recorded Thursday even though long-term Government issues rose by 1/4 to 3/4 of a point and corporate issues rose by 1/4 to 1/2.
ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 5 -Charles Gadsden, Yale's No. 1 player, defeated Ed Jordan, 154, 18-16, 15-14 in the opening of the Atlantic Coast squash racquets championship tonight at Chalfonte-Haddon Hall.
PARIS, Jan. 5 -- The election of Alexander Dubcek to replace Antonin Novotny as First Secretary of the Czechoslovak Communist party represents a sweeping triumph for the country's Slovak minority.
Stock prices advanced on a broad front in active trading yesterday, with a number of major blue-chip issues leading the way.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 5 (Reuters) -- Pickets today closed the two main San Francisco newspapers, the Hearst-owned San Francisco Examiner, an evening paper, and the morning San Francisco Chronicle, owned by the D. E. Young family.

TORONTO, Jan. 5 -- The Johnson Administration's new measures to curb American investment abroad have intensified concern in Canada about "American domination" of the Canadian economy.
ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- The State Conservation Commissioner, R. Stewart Kilborne, has sent Governor Rockefeller a report opposing the creation of a national park in the Adirondack Mountains.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 5 (AP) -Lou Brock, the St. Louis Cardinals' triple-threat left-fielder, signed his 1968 contract for a substantial bonus, Bing Devine, the general manager, said today.
PARIS, Jan. 5 -- President de Gaulle has assured the Grand Rabbi of France that it was far from his intention to insult the Jews when he called them an "elite people, sure of itself and domineering."

BUENA PARK, Calif., Jan. 5 (UPI) -- The former United States Open champion, Billy Casper, and Al Johnston, making a pro golf tour comeback, shot four-under-par 68's today to lead the second half of the split first round in the $31,000 Southern California open.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The National Archives made public today the text of the agreement under which autopsy photographs and X-rays of President Kennedy's body will be held secret until Oct. 29, 1971.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) The United States has submitted a bill for $3.3-million to Israel for compensation of the families of 34 Navy men killed June 8 when Israeli planes and torpedo boats attacked an American naval vessel in the Mediterranean.
BONN, Jan. 5 -- West Germany's Social Democratic party, the junior partner in Bonn's coalition Government, called on the United States today to end its bombing of North Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The value of new construction put in place in November rose by $300-million, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $77.2billion, the Commerce Department reported today. Lincoln Seibert, led the way into the quarter-final round of the 33d annual Douglas Medal bonspiel at St. Andrew's Golf Club today by defeating the Norfolk, Conn., Curling Club, 13-7. Edward (Ted) Childs, president of the Grand National Curling Club, skipped for Norfolk.
John Rauch of the Oakland Raiders was named yesterday the United Press International coach of the year in the American football League.

A building boom in giant telescopes bids fair to bring about a new round of discoveries regarding the cosmos. After a long period of quiescence some eight new instruments, all larger than any in existence except the 200-inch telescope on Mount Palomar, are now being projected or built.

EACH year several "new" species or varieties of woody ornamentals are introduced. In most cases, they are improved forms of existing plants. Others are hybrids, which have better flowers, fruit or fall color and which may be hardier in severe northern temperatures.

MOSCOW, Jan. 6 (UPI) -- A leading Soviet surgeon said last night that if he were to perform a human heart transplantation, he would do it by having the patient live for a time with two hearts functioning.
Construction of the Police Department's new 15 - story headquarters building in the Civic Center planned for the City Hall will begin in April, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.
BRUSSELS -- In recent years American corporations have been investing more than $4-billion a year in Western Europe to expand the markets for their products.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Jan. 6 -- This is roundup time for President Johnson in the Texas hill country. A few stray billions of dollars must still be crammed into the budget before he heads back to Washington and submits his legislative wares in the Congressional market.

The Federal Court conviction of seven white Mississippians accused of participating in a Ku Klux Klan conspiracy to execute three young civil rights workers in Neshoba County has confronted the hooded order with another crisis of confidence.

Sunset leaves a glow like a faint blush on the hilltops. It slowly flows down across the valley, a pinkly luminous shadow. The wind, which all day has been re-drifting the snow, filling paths and smothering footprints, eases away. The countryman, booted, mufflered and storm-coated, goes out to do the evening chores.

GEORGE TOWN, Grand Cayman, B. W. I. -- This tranquil British Crown Colony in the western Caribbean is quietly succeeding in its quest for more tourist business. In fact, the present winter season may well be the best one Grand Cayman has ever known.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Jan. 6 -Ceylon will not have any substantial quantities of sheet rubber for sale in 1968 to Rumania, the United Arab Republic and the Soviet Union. She will have hardly anything for sale to other countries such as the United States or United Kingdom.

The Offshore Racing Committee of the North American Yacht Racing Union has set March 15 as the closing date for challenges from this continent, for the One Ton Cup, James Michael, the committee's chairman, said last week.

Reports arose again last week about a possible sale by David A. (Sonny) Werblin of the New York Jets football team. This time a new party was introduced into the old possibility, the Madison Square Garden Corporation.
Every executive likes the challenge of a new and more important job, and Enrico Segni, the Italian Line's new assistant general manager for North America, is no exception.

THE New York grandmaster, Larry Evans, recently participated in the 14-man Venice international round robin. His final score of 10-3 against opposition that included six other grandmasters earned him a tie for second place with world champion Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union.
THE retirement of Harry Goldwater and Marguerite Harris at the end of 1967 deprived the American Contract Bridge League of two executives who cannot easily be replaced.

A big two-in-one ship -- a twin-hulled catamaran -- has been ordered for Columbia University's Hudson Laboratories to help unravel some of the mysteries of ocean depths.
RICHMOND, Jan. 6 -- The publisher of The Richmond News Leader announced today that he had accepted the resignation of Grover C. Hall Jr., as editor.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 6 -- North Vietnamese infantrymen swept out of the hills overlooking the Queson Valley in northern South Vietnam again last night, killing 20 American soldiers and wounding 64 in a three-hour attack on an isolated artillery base.

The Grand Ballroom of the Plaza will be the setting again this year on Jan. 24 for the annual Diamond Ball, which has traditionally drawn a sparkling array of political and business leaders and socialites to aid the Institute of International Education.
THE nation's oldest annual camellia show will open in Boston on Jan. 18-19. Sponsored by the Massachusetts Horticultural Society, the 139th show will feature cut blooms grown under glass.
LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Ascension Island, midway between Africa and South America, is becoming increasingly important as a communications center for Britain and the United States.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 6 -- Vice President Humphrey told an attentive audience here today that the United States intended to "take new leadership in reducing barriers" that restrict the exports of African and other developing nations.
HONOLULU, Jan. 6. -- The North, using a crunching running attack plus a strong defense, outclassed the South, 50-6, today in the 22d annual Hula Bowl game.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- The Rockefeller administration issued a report today that conceded the state's failure to persuade private insurance companies to underwrite adequate fire insurance for slum properties on a voluntary basis.

The Federal Government has decided to end its participation in a $4.3-million training and counseling service for 450 high school dropouts from the Bedford Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn because of a Congressional cutback in funds and a highly unfavorable evaluation of the service.

ALGIERS, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Unofficial but usually reliable sources in Algiers said today that former Premier Moise Tshombe of the Congo might soon be released from prison expelled from Algeria. Official sources said that they had no knowledge of such plans.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 6 (Agence France-Presse) -- The Soviet freighter Pereslavl-Zalessky appeared more severely damaged in the raid on Haiphong than any foreign vessel hit in American attacks on North Vietnamese ports so far, judging from accounts by the ship's master and political commissar in the Hanoi press today.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 6 -- Yale University's strong swimming team captured nine of 13 events today to beat the cadets from the United States Military Academy, 69-44, in the Army gymnasium varsity pool.

The Canadian Women's Club of New York will hold its annual Maple Leaf Dinner Dance on Jan. 19 in the Baroque Suite at the Plaza.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Johnson Administration will probably propose to Congress soon a plan for a small tax rebate on exports and an equivalent tax on imports.

WASHINGTON -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy last Wednesday added New Hampshire to the list of Presidential primaries he will enter. U. S. Plywood-Champion Papers, Inc., announced last week the sale of a tract of 12,000 acres containing some 150 million board feet of timber in western Washington to the Key Timber Company of Portland, Ore., which represents Japanese interests.
The New York Yankees announced yesterday that they would play 31 exhibition games during spring training this year, including four in Mexico City.

Carl Yastrzemski, the hero of the Boston Red Sox, was named baseball's player of the year yesterday by New York's baseball writers.

WASHINTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- An Arizona-based committee has opened a national drive to finance Barry Goldwater's effort to return to the Senate.

Price increases ranging from about 5 per cent to 8 per cent were imposed yesterday on nearly all of the tube-mill products of the Phelps Dodge Copper Products Corporation.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 8 -- Larry River, the American artist, and Pierre Gaisseau, French film maker, were released from prison here today after four days in detention. They apparently had been held on suspicion that they were white mercenaries engaged to fight in Nigeria's six-month-old civil war.

THE name is different and the school's location is different, but the basketball prowess remains the same. That's the story in a nutshell about Archbishop Molloy High, which changed its name from St. Ann's Academy 11 years ago and moved to Jamaica, Queens, from upper Manhattan.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 (UPI) -- A new effort was made today to end the month-long strike of the American Newspaper Guild against the Los Angeles Herald-Examiner. Publication has been halted at two San Francisco newspapers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The heads of four Government agencies announced today approval of $24-million in grants for 11 cities in response to President Johnson's pledge for "the establishment -- in every ghetto in America -- of a neighborhood center to service the people who live there."

DETROIT -- The Detroit institute of Art's "Romantic Art in Britain," opening today, is the latest evidence that if New Yorkers want the best and soundest (as opposed to the jazziest) art-historical exhibitions, they must go outside New York to find them.

President Frei of Chile has finally forced a showdown with the rebellious left wing of his Christian Democratic party and appears to have won a decisive victory.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Jan. 9 -- The world's fourth human heart transplant patient was still in "critical" condition here today, but his doctors saw signs of improvement and reason for hope.

American and Eastern Airlines have started combining their air freight services in Chicago to provide a high-speed containerized service between Los Angleles and Atlanta, as well as other cities in each other's service area.

Stockholders of the Grinnell Corporation were informed yesterday that 35 suits for damages have been filed against the company on antitrust grounds. The suits were filed in the wake of a Federal Government antitrust case against the company that went to the Supreme Court.

Vitriolic, last year's 2-year-old champion, has been assigned top weight of 126 pounds in the 1968 edition of the Experimental Free Handicap for 3-year-olds.

THE third round of the New York Double Elimination Knockout Championship was marked by close matches and the defeat of several favored teams. Edith Sacks, John Solodar, Ralph Chafetz, Jeff Westheimer, Frank Mela and Norman Kurlander upset Sam Stayman, Victor and Jacqui Mitchell and Sol Rubinow by 2 international match points.

TUNIS, Jan 9 - After a whirlwind tour to nine African countries in 13 days, Vice President Humphrey is enthusiastic over the reception he has received, impressed by the African leaders he has met and convinced that the United States has a commitment to the African Continent.

TRENTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- An appeals court upheld New Jersey's controversial gun control law today, declaring that the statute was a "proper and reasonable" exercise of the state's police powers.

TWENTY-YEAR-OLD Marguerite Trenholm Robb -- "Trenny" for short -- is mad about men's neckties that she buys 'for a nickel apiece in a second-hand shop in Milwaukee. BALTIMORE, Jan. 9 -- The Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development has approved a grant of $22.3-million for the first phase of a huge redevelopment program for the city's inner harbor. EUGENE IONESCO is much obsessed by death, and his play, "Exit the King," introduced last night by the A.P.A. Visitors to the American Stock Exchange will number about 400,000 a year, double the current rate, after new facilities, described yesterday, have been completed.

MIAMI, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Ranger II, owned by Mrs. Bill Resseguet, closed with a rush along the inside to win Tropical Park's seventh race today at 28-1.
ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that he was surprised and "sorry" that Senator Jacob K. Javits had stated he might support the Governor for the Republican Presidential nomination.
CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (AP -- A Federal bankruptcy official ordered today that the Edgewater Beach Hotel, once an elegant shoreline landmark, be offered for sale on Feb. 6.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The East spurted in the final 3 1/2 minutes and gained a 126-120 victory over the West tonight in the first American Basketball Association All-Star game.

WAR ZONE C, South Vietnam, Jan. 9 (AP) -- A narrow no-fire zone that American military commanders once observed along the Cambodian border in South Vietnam has vanished under the pressure of enemy military infiltration.
The Automobile Club of New York had this advice yesterday for motorists having trouble in starting their cars because of the cold weather:

James Reston in his Jan. 3 column has pointed out many of the inconsistencies and contradictions involved in attempting to end the imbalance of United States overseas payments by a ban on travel to Europe.

More stringent parking bans, including new "no standing" rules at morning and evening rush periods, will go into effect Monday on Madison and Lexington Avenues in mid-Manhattan to ease traffic snarls.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 10 -- The stepped-up enemy offensive since the New Year's cease-fire has resulted in the heaviest loss of Vietcong and North Vietnamese forces of any week of the war, according to a South Vietnamese spokesman.
Enter C. W. Post, a young college with a lot of catching up to do.

ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today that he would recommend a $10,875,000 grant to help develop a $25-million transportation center at the Republic Aviation Airport at Farmingdale, L.I.
DETROIT, Jan. 9 -- The Ford Motor Company has in effect raised its prices by removing or changing equipment without changing the base price of its cars.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Jan. 10 -- The majestic, antlered head of a whitetail deer and the snarling face of a small bobcat greet the visitor to Jonas Brothers Studios, Inc., internationally known taxidermists.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 10--A nervous bandit tried to rob the North Broadway branch of the County Trust Company here today but after shooting a teller he fled empty handed. The teller, who was taken to White Plains Hospital, is expected to recover.

ALBANY, Jan. 10--A bill to make it easier legally for survivors to donate an organ from a dead person and another bill to require a study of the situation with a view to tighter regulation were introduced today in the Legislature.

" WE entertain very often, very often," Mrs. M. Varadarajan said with the brilliant smile that is characteristic of the woman, "and one more party after this will be the last. There is so much packing to be done."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) --The Small Business Administration anounced today the appointment of Grogan Lord of Georgetown, Tex., as chairman of the National Business Investment Company Advisory Council. Mr. Lord is president of the Texas Capital Corporation, a small business investment corporation.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 10 (Reuters) --India and Poland signed an agreement here today that was expected to increase trade between them to more than $80-million this year from $53million in 1967.
MOSCOW, Jan. 10 (UPI)-The prosecution put Mrs. Lyudmila Ginzburg, the mother of Aleksandr Ginzburg, on the stand today to try to prove that her son had illegal contacts abroad.

BOSTON, Jan. 10 (AP)--Captain John Havlicek came off the bench to spark rallies in the first and third periods and led the Boston Celtics to a 123-110 National Basketball Association victory over the Seattle Sonics tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10-Thomas L. Farmer has resigned as general counsel of the Agency for International Development to return to private law practice.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10-Adam Clayton Powell, who was excluded from his seat in the House of Representatives almost a year ago, told nearly 7,000 U.C.L A. students today that "black power is the saving grace of the United States."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10-The State Department expressed satisfaction today with the results so far of Chester Bowles's talks with Cambodia's Chief of State, Prince Norodom Sihanouk.

LONDON, Jan. 9--A Cabinet minister said today Britain was "disturbed" at the report that the United States was considering an import tax and an export rebate just as Britain was abolishing her own export rebate.

" The Comedy of Ernie Kovacs," a one-hour special culled from a series of programs written, produced, directed and performed by the comedian before his death in 1962, will be televised on the American Broadcasting Company on Tuesday, April 9, at 10 P.M. The television rights were acquired from Edie Adams, Mr. Kovacs's widow. Miss Adams and Milt Hoffman, who worked with the late comedian on his shows, will coordinate the production.

LONDON, Jan. 10--A threeday meeting of the governing council of World Jewish Congress ended today. In a statement Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the council, said that "the key to peace in the Middle East lies in action and decisions in Washington and Moscow."

SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., Jan. 10--More than 1,200 students at the Spring Valley Senior High School here were sent home 15 minutes early this afternoon after two anonymous telephone calls warned that a bomb had been placed in the building. The police failed to find a bomb.

TORONTO, Jan. 10 (UPI)-Frank Mahovlich celebrated his 30th birthday tonight by scoring two goals and leading the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 2-1 victory over the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game.
SUVA, Fiji, Jan. 10 (UPI)-Fiji's first recorded Siamese twins, who shared one heart, died yesterday, nine hours after they were born to an Indian woman, officials said today. The babies were girls.

The appointment of Christopher M. Ballaban, Patrick J. Mastronardo and Andrew J. Rohman as vice presidents was announced yesterday in Mineola, N. Y., by the Franklin National Bank. They had been assistant vice presidents.
Stock prices closed generally with gains yesterday despite weakness in some of the recently popular blue-chip issues.
RICHMOND, Jan. 10--Gov. Mills E. Godwin Jr. recommended today that Virginia change its traditional pay-asyou go fiscal policy and borrow $70-million for higher education and mental health this year.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 96.1 on Tuesday from 96.2 on Monday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 10 (AP)--Three children died from dehydration in hospitals here yesterday as a result of midsummer temperatures that reached 92 degrees. The victims were among 134 children treated for dehydration.

ROME, Jan. 10--Pope Paul VI, receiving Premier Mika Spiljak of Yugoslavia today, said that he would pursue his action for peace despite "the many difficulties, and, sometimes, misunderstanding it seems to meet."

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 (UPI) --The New York Knicks outscored the Los Angeles Lakers, 13 points to 3, at the outset of the final period tonight to overcome a late Laker rally and score a 115-101 National Basketball Association victory.

BOB DYLAN'S first new recording, since his neck was broken in a motorcycle accident in August, 1966--in effect, his first public appearance in 17 months--appears to be an instant hit. It went on sale last Friday.

A Chinese-American teacher from Long Island was nominated yesterday to be principal of a Brooklyn public school by the governing board of a predominantly Negro and Puerto Rican experimental school district.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -Senator Mike Mansfield of Montana said today that he would revive his campaign for a substantial reduction of United States troop strength in Europe in view of the balance of payments crisis.

COATESVILLE, Pa., Jan. 10 (UPI)--Almost all of the 65 children aboard the West Bradford elementary school bus suffered minor injuries today when another school bus sideswiped it on an icy road and sent it crashing into a tree.
The election of John B. Renwick as president of G. T. E. Data Services Corporation, a new subsidiary of the General Telephone Electronics Corporation, was announced here yesterday.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 10-Delegates to the Maryland Constitutional Convention signed today a draft charter that would drastically change state and local governments if approved by the state's voters in a referendum on May 14.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 10 --Harvard's hockey team took the Ivy League lead tonight with an S-3 victory over Brown.

A leading stone-preservation expert will fly today to Lalibela, a village in a remote section of northern Ethiopia, to test a new liquid formula that he has developed to prevent the erosion of important stone monuments of antiquity.

President Johnson's plea to curb foreign travel could materially help the automotive industry here. Glenn E. White, newly appointed general manager of the Chrysler Corporation's ChryslerPlymouth division, said yesterday.

BOSTON, Jan. 10 (AP)--The Christian Science Monitor reported today in a dispatch from John Hughes, its correspondent in Hong Kong, that Foreign Minister Nguyon Duy Trinh of North Vietnam had unequivocally confirmed that peace talks with the United States would follow cessation of bombing and other acts of war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The sinking of the Israeli destroyer Elath last October by Sovietmade ship-to-ship missiles set off an examination of United States Navy defenses against such weapons, Navy sources said today.

BOSTON, Jan. 10 (UPI)--A youth burned what he said was his draft classification card today outside the Boston Army base's main gate while some 300 demonstrators protested the scheduled induction of two other youths.

SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 10 (UPI)--The police have arrested 40 fishermen who have returned from detention in Communist North Korea, the Government announced today. The fishermen, kidnapped as they worked in waters near the North-South military demarcation line, were charged with fishing in restricted areaas.

Studebaker-Worthington, Inc., a company formed last November by the merger of the Studebaker and Worthington corporations, expects its 1967 earnings to approximate $4.65 a share compared with $4.21 a share on a combined basis in 1966. Frank J. Nunlist, president of the new company, made the estimate before the St. Louis Society of Security Analysts yesterday.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 10 (UPI) --The Cincinnati Royals scored 76 points in the first half tonight and coasted to a 133-117 victory over the Baltimore Bullets in a National Basketball Association game.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 10-Talks began in Amman today between the Jordanian Government and the first Soviet economic delegation to visit Jordan since the established diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union in 1964.
PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 10 --A mechanical difficulty developed late today when scientists started to put the Surveyor 7 spacecraft to work sampling soil on the moon.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 10 (UPI)--The Minnesota North Stars, sparked by Wayne Connelley's three goals, moved into second place in the Western Division of the National Hockey League tonight by defeating the first place Philadelphia Flyers, 6-4.
HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The Drummondville Eagles of Canada defeated the Finnish national hockey team, 3-2, tonight.
The nation's electric power production rose 11 per cent in the week ended Jan. 6 from the level in the corresponding 1967 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Jan. 10 (Reuters) -- President Johnson sent a congratulatory message to the new Australian Prime Minister, John G. Gorton, saying he was "strengthened" to know that close United States-Australian relations would be maintained under his leadership, it was disclosed today.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 (AP) --The St. Louis Hawks made 15 of 20 shots in the third period and went on to beat the Philadelphia 76ers, 134-122; in the National Basketball Association tonight.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Jan. 10 (AP) -- A Roman Catholic priest said today that he had mailed his draft card to Secretary of State Dean Rusk in protest against what he says is the immorality of United States policy in Vietnam.
The nation's social problems go far deeper than the physical decay of the central cities and the Negro protest, a bureaucrat and former professor told some 500 businessmen yesterday.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Jan. 10 --President Johnson is now in his third week at his ranch and, besides getting a lot of work done on his new year's legislative and budget proposals, he has been screened off by the Texas hills from the agitation in Washington about the value of another gesture for peace in Vietnam.

The series of recent hearttransplant operations has touched off an international debate among doctors on the advisability of such drastic surgery on humans without more research into the body's ability to accept another person's organs.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 10--Israel today extended compulsory military service from 30 to 33 months, the longest in the nation's history.
SAN QUENTIN STATE PRISON, Calif., Jan. 10--The inmates here are displaying a lively interest in cultural activities --graphic arts, performing arts and the fine arts.
NASSAU, the Bahamas, Jan. 10--From a Roman Catholic church deep in the Negro quarter, unfamiliar sounds were heard last Sunday evening.

OTTAWA, Jan. 10 (Canadian Press)--A sharp decline in jobs, most of it in agriculture, increased unemployment by 22 per cent between November and December, the Government's monthly employment survey reported today, a total of 353,000 persons were unemployed in mid-December, representing 4.6 per cent of the labor force, the highest December rate in four years. The figures represented an increase of 64,000 over November, when 289,000 were jobless.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 10 --The threat of the Teamsters Union to organize and adopt the players was what prompted the National Football League Players Association to declare itself an independent union, said John Gordy today. Gordy, a guard for the Detroit Lions, is the newly elected president of the players association currently meeting here.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (UPI)-Deaths on the nation's highways the first 11 months of 1967--numbering 47,810--were nearly equal to those during the similar period a year before, the National Safety Council announced today. Traffic deaths compared with vehiclemiles of travel have gone down, however, the council said.
LANSING, Mich., Jan. 10-Gov. George Romney today played down the importance of the New Hampshire primary to his political future.

OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 10 (UPI)--Ted Hampton, obtained yesterday in a trade from the Detroit Red Wings, scooped up a loose puck in the crease and scored in the third period tonight to give the Oakland Seals a 2-2 tie with the St. Louis Blues.

Theophilus Ebenhaezer Donges, a short, portly man with a dignified bearing was, by turns, an editor, lawyer, member of Parliament and Cabinet Minister before he was elected President of the Republic of South Africa last year.

MOSCOW, Jan. 10--The concern of Soviet intellectuals about a trial of four persons accused of anti-Soviet activity was reported today to have led 31 writers, scientists and others to appeal for legal safeguards and full information in the case.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -The nation's unemployment rate dropped last month to the lowest level since April as employment increased more than usual.

Thomas J. Mackell, the Queens District Attorney, will be honored as man of the year by the Community Boys Club of Cambria Heights, Queens, at a dinner at 8 P.M. tomorrow at Leonard's Restaurant, 555 Northern Boulevard, Great Neck, L. I.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 10 --President Tito of Yugoslavia arrived in Rawalpindi, Pakistan's interim capital, today, and was greeted by President Mohammad Ayub Khan.

HOUSTON, Jan. 10 (AP)-Sixteen judges participated in ceremonies today opening a two-day session of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. All but one of the judges then began hearing the first of six cases.
THE Phillips Petroleum Company, which has been eyeing Purex Corporation for five years, appears ready to ease itself out of the picture.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 10 -- Golf's 1968 national pro circuit opens here tomorrow under rules other than those set by the United States Golf Association. The 1967 code will be in effect for the Bing Crosby pro-amateur tourney here because the Professional Golfers' Association has not yet determined what procedure to follow.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Jan. 10 --Middlebury College scored with 2 minutes 15 seconds remaining to beat a heavily favored Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute hockey team, 4-3, tonight.

Midwinter optimism, that safest of all baseball feelings, took some of the chill off Yankee Stadium yesterday as the entire Yankee organization wound up several days of meetings to evaluate its talent situation.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association modified yesterday its controversial 1.6 regulation governing academic requirements for student athletes. The change seemed to be agreeable to the Ivy League, whose eight member institutions fought the original 1.6 rule for the last three years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--For politicians and their wives here, family and social life is always intertwined with business, but Mrs. Eugene J. McCarthy, who has been part of such a life for 20 years, doesn't find that the sensitive combination has hurt her.

REDWOOD CITY, Calif., Jan. 10 (AP) -- On the California Highway Patrol's recommendation, a judge dismissed today a traffic citation that had been issued to Mike Kasperak, the heart transplant patient.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (UPI)-Camille Henry's first and second goals of the season brought the New York Rangers from behind twice tonight to produce a 3-3 tie with the Black Hawks, ending a nine-game home ice winning steak for Chicago.

PNOMPENH, Jan. 10 (AP)-Cambodian officials said today that the first meeting of Chester Bowles and Prince Norodom Sihanouk has been "frank and cordial," and that "useful points of view were exchanged."

" Man of La Mancha," now in its third year at the downtown ANTA Washington Square Theater, will move uptown to the Martin Beck Theater on March 19. The transfer will be accompanied by an increase in the top price at night from $8.50 to $9.90. Walter Fried, general manager, attributed the new scale to added costs, among them the engagement of 10 more musicians.

LANSING, Mich., Jan. 10 (UPI)--Gov. George Romney said today that Maj. Gen. Ronald D. McDonald would be "promptly removed" as Michigan's Adjutant General as soon as the State Supreme Court orders him back into office.
PALO ALTO, Jan. 10--A transplanted heart continued to beat strongly today in the chest of Mike Kasperak, a 54-year-old steel worker.
Barry Brown, who has been practicing lately in a tunnel, tried something different last night.

Louis F. Laun has been elected chairman of the Man-Made Fiber Producers Association, Inc. He is the president of the Celanese Fibers Marketing Company. Claude Ramsey, president of the American Enka Corporation, was elected vice chairman of the association.

The Franklin Life Insurance Company disclosed plans yesterday to acquire control of the Channing Financial Corporation, a holding company and mutual - fund complex, through an exchange of stock valued at an estimated $60million.

BLOEMFONTEIN, South Africa, Jan. 10 (Reuters) -- Marty Riessen, the fifth-ranking United States player, beat Jose Edi son Mandarino of Brazil, 6-4, 6-1, in the third round of the Organge Free State tennis championships today.

TRENTON, Jan. 10 (AP)-Brendan T. Byrne was sworn in as president of the State Public Utility Commission today at a private ceremony at Morven, the Governor's executive mansion in Princeton. Mr. Byrne, who was prosecutor of Essex County, was confirmed for the $22,000-a-year post Tuesday by the State Senate.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 10 -The American artist Larry Rivers, who was released from prison here on Monday after four days in detention, left Nigeria today by air for the Congo to complete the filming of a television program.
Frank Navarro, who guided Williams College to an unbeaten record last season, will be named the new football coach at Columbia today.

Henry Fried, the contractor who was indicted along with former Water Commissioner James L. Marcus and others in a $40,000 kickback conspiracy, refused yesterday to sign a waiver of immunity from prosecution on testimony he was asked to give before a New York County grand jury.

Hays T. Watkins Jr., vice president of finance of the affiliated Chesapeake Ohio and Baltimore Ohio railroads, reaffirmed yesterday that the share-exchange ratio between the C. and its proposed merger partner, the Norfolk Western Railway, "is fair and equitable to the stockholders of each company."
MOSCOW, Jan. 10 (Reuters) --Tass, the official Soviet press agency, marked its 50th anniversary today with a celebration in a Moscow concert hall.
The New York State Banking Board approved yesterday the proposed merger of the State of New York National Bank of Kingston and the Fallkill Bank and Trust Company of Poughkeepsie.
Marion Sadler, president of American Airlines, plans to step down because of ill health.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -The chairman of the President's National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders warned today that the panel's report "is going to be uncomfortable for the people of the United States."
Trading was light but prices managed to make modest advances yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

PARIS, Jan. 10 (UPI) -- France called on the United States today to open bilateral talks with its trading partners before enacting new measures to reduce the United States payments deficit. Failing this, the French Government called for talks within international financial organizations. The In formation Minister, Georges Gorse, said the Cabinet heard a lengthy explanation of the Administration's steps at its weekly meeting.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Jan. 10 (UPI)--Lafayette post office employes complained today that customers were putting too many stamps on their letters.
This is data-gathering time, or should be now that Christmas is over, final thank-you notes written, and the New Year greeted. It's gathering time for income tax information.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -The Census Bureau made official today what many merchants had suspected: Retail sales in December were disappointing.
J. P. Hansen was elected a director yesterday of the City Stores Company. It operates a chain of retail outlets, including Franklin Simon and W. Sloane here.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Jan. 10-Julius Klein, a former convict who has been denounced by Suffolk County police officials as a major source of corruption, was indicted today on charges of bribing a juror in a 1966 trial in which he was acquitted of forgery and grand larceny.
The New York County chapter of t.b.e National Multiple Sclerosis Society has arranged a membership tea and fashion show for Jan. 25 in the Plaza's Persian Room.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association increased the tension in its running battle with the Amateur Athletic Union yesterday by declaring it would insist upon the right to certify all track and field meets in which N.C.A.A. athletes competed after Nov. 1.

Ticket buyers for Broadway's weekend shows now definitely favor Saturday night over Friday, according to a canvass of producers, theater executives and ticket agencies. Formerly, the demand was equal for both nights.

BOSTON, Jan. 10 (AP)--Dr. Benjamin Spock, Mr. Coffin Jr. and the three others indicted last week for counseling draft evaders are to be arraigned Jan. 29 in the Federal District Court here, the Justice Department said today.

PALO ALTO, Calif.,_Jan. 10-Within just the last six weeks three teams of surgeons on two continents have transplanted five human hearts. The first and third of these historic operations were performed in Capetown, South Africa, on Dec. 3 and Jan. 2; the three others, in the United States. The patient in the most recent case died early today at the Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn less than a day after the surgery was completed.
Prices of platinum futures, which had been dropping for some time, bounced back yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 10--Gov. Ronald Reagan firmly dashed today the hopes of his backers in other states that he would campaign in Presidential primaries this year.

The Consolidated Edison Company said yesterday that it would build its fourth and largest nuclear power generating station "somewhere outside the city" and planned to put it in service in May, 1973. Con Edison and Orange and Rockland Utilities, Inc., plan to share the cost and output of the plant, with Con Edison paying 80 per cent and taking 80 per cent of the plant's 1,115,000-

Here we are in the booming age of marketing with both manufacturers and agencies on the lookout for bright guys with experience. But Robert Carley, former ad agency president and food company marketing vice president, has been out of a job for more than a year. Robert Carley, you see, is 55 years old. And youth is the keyword today.
Mayor Lindsay promised yesterday to see that new and tougher regulations were drawn up for the use of long-boom cranes.
Shivering apartment dwellers climbed over roofs and fled down fire escapes into the icy streets yesterday morning as four fires broke out in Harlem. Two children suffered minor injuries:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission's new chairman, Paul J. Tierney, indicated today that the future of the passenger train was bleak.
A professional diver yesterday recovered from the 12-foot depths of Dyker Park Pond, Brooklyn, the bodies of two boys identified as those missing since last Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The Federal Housing Administration announced today a new policy under which families displaced by Government action or a major disaster will be given first chance to buy houses owned by the agency.

A special meeting of Peabody Coal Company stockholders, called to consider merging the company into the Kennecott Copper Corporation, was adjourned yesterday in St. Louis because Government approval of the merger plan had not yet been received. The meeting will resume Monday.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 10 (UPI) --Jean Claude Tremblay scored with 41 seconds remaining tonight to give the Montreal Canadiens a 4-3 National Hockey League victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 10--Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's Chief of State, announced today that he and Chester Bowles, President Johnson's special envoy, had agreed to seek a strengthening of the International Control Commission to police Cambodia's borders and prevent incursions from South Vietnam.
Columbia University announced yesterday that it was lifting its ban on campus military recruitment.
The Bell System, in the first major test of the capital market this year, sold $100-million of debentures yesterday at an interest rate sharply below that on an issue marketed early in December.
The Collegiate School, the oldest independent day school in the country--it was founded in 1638--has made a major addition.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 10--A $14-million capital fund campaign, the largest ever attempted in its 98-year history, was announced today by Chatham College.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 10--An informed source said today that the failure of the South Vietnamese Government to make a start on its program of domestic reform was causing concern to the United States Embassy.
Motorists traveling the northern end of the New Jersey Turnpike are mystified these days by overpasses running into the sides of embankments and by mounds of colored sand flanking the roadway.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Jan. 10--Fairleigh Dickinson University made 32 of 37 foul goal attempts tonight to defeat Seton Hall University in a Metropolitan Conference game, 7866. The Knights have a 2-2 won-lost record in the league and the Pirates are 0-3.
DOVER, Del., Jan. 10 (AP)-A Delaware reapportionment plan quickly became law tonight as the General Assembly enaced it in special session and Gov. Charles L. Terry Jr. signed it immediately.
Premier Levi Eshkol of Israel asserted here yesterday that President de Gaulle, despite "all his greatness," did not understand the meaning of Israel and Zionism.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Jan. 10 (AP)--Mark F. Ethridge, who became a college journalism professor after 55 years in the newspaper business, was named today to receive the William Allen White Foundation's 1968 national citation for journalistic merit. The 11th annual citation will be made at the University of Kansas Feb. 12 when Mr. Ethridge, longtime publisher of The Louisville Courier-Journal and Times, will deliver the annual William Allen White Lecture.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 10 -- The president of the University of Michigan, Robben W. Fleming, says that he believes the university should take a "general position against classified military research."
CAPETOWN, Jan. 10 (UPI) Dr. Christiann N. Barnard said today he might move to the United States with his 30member heart transplant team.
MOSCOW, Jan 10 (UPI) --A Soviet astronaut said yesterday the Soviet Union may "in the near future" send as many as 10 men to Mars or Venus.
The temperature here moved up to 17 degrees yesterday, the highest reading since Sunday night.
Ten electronic systems that weigh coal cars in motion have been sold to the British Coal Board, Samuel H. Levinson, president, of Railweight, Inc., maker of the equipment, announced yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 (AP) --A petition asking the removal of Police Commissioner Frank L. Rizzo has been dismissed by a three-judge Federal court.
TOKYO, Jan. 10 (UPI))--The father of a young American marine who faces trial for having gone AWOL is planning to return home to Larchmont, N. Y., soon.

Investors snapped up 166,600 shares of Software Systems, Inc., common stock, offered publicly yesterday for the first time. By the close of trading, the stock had risen to $15 1/2-$16 from the original price of $6. The concern, based in Falls Church, Va., performs systems analysis and supplies computer-programing services. McDonnell Co., Inc., managed the sale.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--A storm of protests forced the Navy tonight to change course and order that the names of officers and crewmen not be provided New Orleans organizations planning segregated Mardi Gras parties.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) --Senator Frank J. Lausche said today he would welcome re-election support by the Ohio Democratic Executive Committee and by the steering committee of the Ohio Democratic County Chairman's Association.

ASWAN, United Arab Republic, Jan. 9--The hammer and sickle of the Soviet Union and the twin stars of the United Arab Republic fluttered today on poles and lampposts in Aswan and on the road to the High Dam four miles out of town as two of the dam's big generators were activated.
Harold Macmillan, former Prime Minister of Britain, visiting New York for publication of the second volume of his memoirs, talked lightly yesterday about people who write personal histories.
The appointment of Henry P. Morales as a vice president of the First National City Bank was announced yesterday. He has served since 1965 as an assistant vice president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The Government announced today that it had issued a revised guide for model cities program applicants to get away from a long list of plans many of which the cities will not be able to carry out.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The President's reallocation of antipoverty funds appropriated by Congress for the Office of Economic Opportunity will mean a reduction of the projected legal services money from $42-million to $36-million and the migrant program from $27-million to $25-million. Much larger cuts were erroneously reported in The New York Times today.
ROCKFORD, Ill., Jan. 10 -Backers of Senator Charles H. Percy for President or Vice President conceded today he was having "grave problems" nailing down Republican favoriteson status in Illinois.

The decision of Wimbledon tennis officials to open their title competition this year to professional players, after a history of only amateur participation, deserves applause for its courage as well as the assurance the action provides of an open contest based on skill and staying power.
MALTON, England, Jan. 10 (Reuters) -- A giant anteater was born at the Flamingo Park Zoo here today -- the first such long-nosed mammal to have been bred in captivity outside the United States.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 10 -- The Vietcong continued their new year's offensive today with a series of attacks from the central highlands to the Mekong Delta.

MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 10--The board of directors of the Nassau County Bar Association overruled its judiciary committee last night and declared that Sol Wachtler was qualified to be a State Supreme Court justice.

A double-decker bus, retired from its regular Fifth Avenue run more than a dozen years ago, took off on its own yesterday morning and ended up crashing into Juan Abarca's living-room window at 463 West 43d Street, near Tenth Avenue.

THE rising demand for pure-bred dogs, partly attributable to the success of dog shows, has led to new business and services, new jobs and greater responsibilities for the American Kennel Club, said Mrs. Lois Meistrell, who runs the Great Neck (L. I.) Dog Training Center, yesterday. She spoke at the monthly luncheon of the Dog Fanciers Club at the Overseas Press Club, 54 West 40th Street.
An anonymous gift of $10,000 from a Larchmont, N. Y., woman helped to establish a record high in the 56-yearold history of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday.
BIG, feathery snowflakes were falling Tuesday night outside Lord Taylor, but inside it was all tropical flowers and small, tea-colored women in sarongs.

The Police Department is investigating the possibility that a typed list found in a detective's notebook is an accounting of payoffs made by 147 East Side restaurants, stores and other businesses to the police.
MASTIC, L. I., Jan. 10--Four persons were fatally injured last night when their auto and a railroad train collided at a grade crossing here.

The Ogden Corporation announced yesterday it has agreed to acquire the $193-million Shaker Savings Association of Shaker Heights, Ohio. About 90 per cent of Shaker's stock is owned by Alexander Mintz, chairman, and his family.

Max Factor Co., cosmetics producer, announced yesterday in Los Angeles the appointment of Alfred Firestein, 43 years old, as president and chief executive officer. MOSCOW, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- A puppy's head, grafted onto an older dog's neck, has developed the habit of nipping playfully at the older dog's ear, the Soviet press agency, Tass, reported today.

There are any number of recordings of Mozart's Clarinet Concerto, that radiantly beautiful work, but it seldom turns up in concert. Last night in Philharmonic Hall it appeared on the program of the Festival Orchestra of New York conducted by Thomas Dunn.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 12 -- Negotiators reached agreement today that could end the musicians' strike that has closed the san Francisco Symphony for the first seven weeks of its 56th season.

SAIGON, Saturday, Jan. 13 (AP) -- A big United States Marine helicopter that vanished five days ago with 32 passengers and a crew of five has been found in a mountainous area, the United States command reported today.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 10 -- This is the big year for Mexico City. There is not a resident who is not conscious of it. Come October, the Olympic Games will make this city the world capital of sports.
Mayor Lindsay warned yesterday that the country "stands in danger of an increased polarization between the races rather than the reverse."

MIAMI, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Six Cuban exiles were sentenced today to prison terms ranging from six months to three years for hijacking a ship off Miami Beach last June. Testimony at their trial showed they wanted the vessel for a mission against Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 12 -- "I suggest that this Administration is afraid to negotiate," Senator Eugene J. McCarthy said today in a speech at the University of California at Los Angeles.
A special commission will study the procedures for handling disruptive children in the city's school system, the United Federation of Teachers said yesterday.

The cold wave here rolled on yesterday, with a low of 2 degrees in early morning, bringing with it fires, homes without heat, emergency shelter problems and a crisis over whether girls may wear slacks to school.

The public is entitled to understand better the reasons why several private nursing homes in the city do not participate in the Medicaid program, or participate to a limited extent. In truth, more private nursing homes and nursing-home beds are presently dedicated to welfare or Medicaid purposes than ever before in the city's history.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 12 -- South Korean marines have been shifted northward to help protect the important Danang area, a Korean spokesman disclosed today.

LIBERTY, N. Y., Jan. 12 -- Outside temperatures of 20 degrees below zero did not disturb the players in the tristate regional championship, which began yesterday at Grossinger's. They were absorbed in contemplation of their own unpleasant zeros, of match point variety.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Southern Californa's Earl McCullouch and Bob Seagren made up for the absence of their teammate, O. J. Simpson, tonight and produced the highlights in the opening meet of the East's indoor track season.

THE New York City Ballet, spartan, lovely and sea- green incorruptible, has very few ballets any fair person might call decadent. In fact, it has only one -- it's fun, if only for a change -- and it was revived last night at the New York State Theater.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- A Harvard professor of psychology has invented a method of teaching children to write. A series of pamphlet-bound books, with special pens, was offered this month to schools.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 12 -- Archbishop Makarios, the President of Cyprus, announced tonight that there would shortly be a presidential election and offered to serve another term.

The Department of Parks announced last night that it would not hire Robert S. Collier, who was convicted two years ago of a conspiracy to blow up the Statue of Liberty. It said it had discovered "after careful examination" that he was not qualified to be a city recreation leader.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 12 -- The Spyglass Hill golf course has a romantic name taken from the pages of Robert Louis Stevenson's novel, "Treasure Island." It also has severely contoured greens and Johnny Pott, an Eastern pro, said he "aged a bit" playing the intriguing layout today.

ATHENS, Jan. 12 -- "Informal" top-level diplomatic contacts between the United States Embassy in Athens and the new Greek Government were resumed this week. All the embassies in Athens suspended contacts with the Government of Premier George Papadopoulos, set up Dec. 13 after King Constantine failed to topple the Athens regime.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Jan. 12 (UPI) -- Mike Kasperak, who sat in a chair last night for the first time since his heart transplant operation, showed some improvement today in overcoming a liver abnormality.

THE story of Lizzie Borden and the murders of her father and stepmother has become an odd if minor cultural phenomenon. It has intrigued the minds and nagged the consciences of three generations of Americans. Since the crime was committed in 1892 it has provoked an uncounted number of books and studies.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 12 -- A three-nation committee on Yemen issued an appeal today for an immediate cease-fire in Yemen and for the end of all outside interference in Yemeni internal affairs.
A member of the Civil Aeronautics Board expressed support yesterday for higher air-travel fares in the early nineteen-seventies if rising costs to operators were not offset by increased revenues.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- A large exhibition of the works of James McNeill Whistler (1854-1903), the most internationally renowned American artist of the 19th century, opens tomorrow at the Art Institute of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- The Communications Workers of America announced today that substantial wage increases would be sought in contract negotiations next month with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
LANSING, Mich., Jan. 12 (AP) -- The bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Lansing today defended a Michigan priest who turned in his draft card to Secretary of State Dean Rusk.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- Governor Rockefeller is reported to have decided to make two new appointments to the Court of Claims -- Milton Alpert, a Republican who is deputy commissioner of the state's Office for Local Government, and James H. Glavin Jr., a Democrat whose son is Democratic chairman of Saratoga County.
