A Protestant will preach in the pulpit of St. Patrick's Cathedral for the first time during the 1968 Week of Prayer for Christian Unity, which begins Thursday and continues through Jan. 25.

Housing Administrator Jason R. Nathan said yesterday he would ask for funds to hire 600 new building inspectors, an increase that would almost double the number of men who now enforce the city's housing maintenance code.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Jan. 12 -- President Johnson intends to nominate Dr. Edward D. Re to become Assistant Secretary of State for educational and cultural affairs.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 12 -- A move by the Rhodesia Constitutional Association, the "shadow" white opposition to the Government of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith, to bring about a British-Rhodesian settlement got under way here today.
Taxi union leaders will meet tonight to discuss whether to call a strike of the 29,000 fleet drivers here.

If there were an aristocracy in the world of Calypso, Lord Burgess would be one of the reigning figures. The singer guitarist and prolific composer nearly filled Carnegie Hall last night with another of his bumptious, rollicking programs.

The bond market declined a bit in early trading yesterday, then staged a comeback and finished with modest gains.
ATHENS, Jan. 12 -- The Greek Archeological Service revoked its ban today on all foreign archeologists from the excavations of prehistoric remains on the Aegean island of Thera.
LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Britain came under heavy pressure from her allies today to change tentative plans for cuts in her forces east of Suez and in her orders for military equipment.
Expenditures for world highways reached $32-billion last year, more than double the outlay of a decade ago, the International Road Federation said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk has indicated that the Administration still has no firm sign from North Vietnam that would justify a halt in the bombing campaign, but that Washington expects to know soon whether recent statements from Hanoi are genuine peace overtures.
The International Business Machines Corporation -- the first of the giants to report 1967 results -- showed new highs in gross and net earnings last year, with gains the sharpest in recent years.
The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. called yesterday for a large-scale antiwar rally in Washington early next month by clergy and laymen to protest "one of history's most cruel and senseless wars."

HERBERT ITKIN, the 41-year-old lawyer who has been mentioned as a murder target in the kickback case involving former city Water Commissioner James L. Marcus, is described by a friend as a "superb story teller, fast mover and wheeler."

Officials in the silver-using industries said here yesterday that they were encouraged by a statement by Robert A. Wallace, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, who said that the Government "stands ready" to melt silver coins and offer the metal to industrial users.
Prices advanced and volume soared through the roof yesterday on the volatile American Stock Exchange.

HOLLYWOOD BEACH, Fla., Jan. 12 (UPI) -- Dick Van Raaphorst of the San Diego Chargers won the professional football players golf tournament today at the Hollywood Beach Hotel Country Club with a low handicap total of 142 for 36-holes.
SEATTLE, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Price increases ranging up to $400,000 a plane were announced by the Boeing Company today for its Model 737 Twinjet planes.

HAVANA, Saturday, Jan. 13 -- Premier Fidel Castro offered today to free 100 political prisoners if Bolivia would surrender the body of Ernesto Che Guevara, the slain revolutionary leader.

The resolution approved by the Democratic National Committee at its meeting in Chicago represents a substantial gain for racial equality in politics. WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Stokely Carmichael appeared today to have strained a fragile coaltion of militant and moderate Negro leaders here by calling for Negroes to "take over" in Washington.

WASHINGTON -- The Pentagon is celebrating its 25th anniversary this week. A wartime baby, it was, and still is, with more than six million gross square feet of space and a mile of enclosing walls, the largest office building in the world.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 16 -- County officials in this anti-Medicaid stronghold conceded today that their health budget had decreased slightly during the first year of Medicaid because the state and the Federal Government paid for services previously financed by the county.
The Lindsay Administration and taxi fleet owners, spurred by a 24-hour strike of taxi drivers, reached agreement on a taxi-fare increase yesterday.

ROME, Jan. 16 -- Messages of sympathy and offers of aid flowed into Italy today from all over the world as the nation heard a preliminary official report on the earthquakes that destroyed several towns in western Sicily.

A memorandum urging general scaling down of military activity in Vietnam, even without the hope of early peace talks or other reciprocation, has been transmitted to President Johnson on behalf of a group of Americans experienced in military and diplomatic affairs.
Mrs. Svetlana Alliluyeva said last night that the Moscow trial of four persons accused of anti-Soviet activity was "a wild mockery of justice."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The United States said today that it did not intend to use American forces to fill the vacuum that will be created by accelerated British withdrawal from military bases in Asia and the Middle East.

A Manhattan Supreme Court jury last night found Bernard Kalisky, a labor organizer, guilty of conspiring to obstruct justice by trying to bribe a judge to give lenient sentence to a convicted extortionist.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The Supreme Court struck down today the Government's procedure for keeping potential saboteurs from getting jobs on United States merchant ships.
LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 16 -- Zambia changed to decimal currency today in a transition that seemed generally smooth despite initial long queues at banks and stores.

THESE two novels have certain things in common. They are reasonably short; they are well constructed; they are pleasantly satisfying. Both are set in the West: "The Edge" in California, "Hail Hero!" in Arizona. Both are about young men of college age who are in revolt against the values of their society.

Time Inc. has always meant national magazines -- Time, Life, Fortune, Sports Illustrated. But increasingly, Time Inc. has meant other things. It is radio and television broadcasting, book publishing, and the manufacture of printing equipment, paper and paperboard products for tabulating cards, folding cartons, milk containers and drinking cups.
High winds shattered windows in the greenhouses of the New York Botanical Gardens in Bronx Park early yesterday morning.

Those flashing blades on the ice at Madison Square Garden this week mean that the Ice Follies is back in town for its annual visit. And while the skating, the music and the hoopla are designed to entertain the customers who fill the seats at the arena, it is more than just entertainment to the owners of the extravaganza.
MIAMI, Jan. 16 -- Peter Piper picked up a peck of United States currency today by winning the $63,600 Tropical Park Handicap, the closing feature at this palm-studded horse park.

ATLANTA, Jan. 16 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said here today that the "massive mobilization for Washington" he plans to lead this April would be kept militant but non-violent by a trained corps of 3,000 from six Southern states and nine Northern cities.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- Two of Britain's most costly current projects -- the Concorde plane and the Channel tunnel -- escaped today's economic ax. At least Prime Minister Wilson made no reference to them in his speech to Commons.

BONN, Jan. 16 -- The Soviet Union has offered a new deal on the status of West Berlin, approaching the West German Government on the subject directly for the first time, it was disclosed today by authoritative sources.

New Yorkers accustomed to the adversities of transit strikes, traffic jams and blackouts took the taxi strike yesterday with typical resourcefulness and aplomb -- and even managed to find some unexpected benefits in it.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 16 -- A majority of Harvard University and Radcliffe College undergraduates have signed a statement calling on President Johnson to de-escalate the war in Vietnam.

Thirty years ago last night, Benny Goodman, stiff and resplendent in tails, walked out on the stage of Carnegie Hall with his clarinet in his hand. He bowed formally to the audience that filled the hall and overflowed onto the stage.

Criminal Court Judge Seymour B. Quel denied yesterday H. Rap Brown's application for a summons charging a patrolman with menacing and harassing him during an incident here last week at the Cuban mission to the United Nations.

ONE of the most notable collections ever offered as a gift to the Museum of Modern Art -- the Sidney and Harriet Janis Collection -- goes on view today in the museum's first-floor galleries at 11 West 53d Street.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 (UPI) -- Governor Rockefeller, in his annual budget message to the State Legislature, proposed today that the pari-mutuel tax in New York be increased from 15 to 16 per cent and that half the increase be used to raise purses for horsemen.
The Vatican and the World Council of Churches have established three joint working committees in the areas of world economic development and peace, a Vatican official disclosed yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- The cutbacks in the state's Medicaid program proposed by Governor Rockefeller today could immediately disqualify about 600,000 people now receiving medical services under the program.
Three persons were arrested in the Bronx yesterday on charges of having reported their welfare payments lost or stolen after cashing them.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The gross national product -- the dollar measure of the nation's total output of goods and services -- rose by more than $16-billion in the fourth quarter of 1967 to an annual rate of $807.6-billion, the Department of Commerce reported today.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Bobby Burnett, a running back with the Buffalo Bills and the American Football League's rookie of the year in 1966, was among 20 Eastern Division players who went to the new Cincinnati Bengals today in the league's expansion draft.

SEATTLE, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Unions representing 12,000 workers in 13 major West Coast shipyards from San Francisco to Bellingham, Wash., have been asked to submit contract proposals by April 2, union sources said yesterday.
Bart Starr said yesterday that the Green Bay Packers had a "feeling" that this could have been Vince Lombardi's last season as coach, although Lombardi had not disclosed his plans to the players.

South Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu is right in saying his Government should play a central role in any move toward peace in Vietnam. As Governor Romney has pointed out, the Saigon regime, together with the National Liberation Front, has a "basic responsibility" to negotiate the internal settlement that is an essential ingredient of any solution in Southeast Asia.
Following is the text of a statement made available to The New York Times last night by Mrs. Svetlana Alliluyeva.

ROME, Jan. 16 -- Women who swear that they simply cannot carry off the new, long coats that plunge to the ankles, or dresses that flop around the shins, haven't felt a single stab of pain this week watching the Italian couture collections for spring-summer.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- Governor Rockefeller sent the Legislature a record $5.5-billion budget today, balanced by a liberal use of transportation bond money, a severe cutback in Medicaid and a $494-million increase in state taxes.

Vladimir Horowitz has agreed to appear in a television recital for the Columbia Broadcasting System, it was announced yesterday by Thomas H. Dawson, the network's president. The program will be taped in color before an audience at Carnegie Hall on Feb. 1 and subsequently televised as a one-hour special.
A new earnings record and an increase in dividend payments were announced yesterday by the Sinclair Oil Company.
Liquidation at the market's closing weakened most grain and soybean futures yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade and they closed mixed.
The proposed $475-million merger of Signal Oil and Gas Company and Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company has been terminated.
A grand jury is investigating whether there has been bribery in the city's Department of Marine and Aviation and whether its agents have taken "unlawful fees."

John P. DeSantis, who was ousted last fall as vice chairman of the Franklin National Bank after a dispute with the bank's chairman, Arthur T. Roth, was named yesterday president and chief executive of the $52-million Underwriters Trust Company, a Wall Street bank.

PARIS -- Politically, King Constantine of Greece is trying to capture the high ground of democratic support which he failed to take militarily by his unsuccessful countercoup last month. But to make this strategy effective he will require diplomatic help.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 16 (UPI) -- The Cincinnati Royals, hitting on 58 per cent of their shots, built a 29-point half-time lead, increased it to 40 at the three-quarter mark and coasted to a 148-121 victory over the San Francisco Warriors tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

Fredell Lack, the concertmaster of the Little Orchestra Society for its first concert on Oct. 20, 1947, and for two seasons thereafter, was its guest soloist in a concert at Philharmonic Hall last night.

Following is the text of a memorandum on Vietnam sent to President Johnson by prominent Americans who participated in a meeting sponsored in Bermuda last month by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.
Rudolf Serkin was appointed yesterday director of the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia. He will assume his duties in September.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Bill Shoemaker triumphed aboard Pass the Brandy and Model Fool in the two divisions of the $40,000 Camino Real Handicap today at Santa Anita.

Members of the Spanish Government charged with administering the new law on religious liberty are trying to work out solutions to the problems of the country's minority faiths satisfactory to all parties, according to Rabbi Arthur Schneier, president of the Appeal of Conscience Foundation.

MONTEVAGO, Sicily, Jan. 16 -- Western Sicily began today its long, slow climb out of earthquake disaster, with indications that the dead will total about 200, instead of the 300 to 500 of earlier estimates.
A petition asking for a role in the selection of a successor to the late Cardinal Spellman has been signed by 563 priests of the New York Roman Catholic Archdiocese and sent to Pope Paul VI.
Following is the text of the petition to Pope Paul VI signed by 563 priests of the New York Archdiocese.

PARIS, Jan. 16 -- Mai Van Bo, Hanoi's chief representative in Western Europe, suggested in a statement here tonight that after an unconditional cessation of American bombing attacks and "other acts of war" against North Vietnam, "the two sides will meet to reach agreement" on the agenda and level of future talks.

David Rockefeller, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, called on the city's Negroes and Puerto Ricans yesterday to develop a "do-it-yourself" philosophy in order to achieve better jobs and higher salaries.
ALAN JAY PIFER, president of the Carnegie Corporation of New York, is a master of the low-key approach.

The Supreme Court's agreement to rule on the constitutionality of the New York law that provides public funds for textbooks "loaned" to parochial school pupils ends the Court's twenty-year silence on an issue of basic principle.

A tangle of legal problems was depicted by lawyers and physicians yesterday as obstructing the use of human organs for transplant operations, despite the willingness of most Americans to make such donations.

BOULDER, Colo., Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Air Force has agreed to provide $183,155 to extend for nine months a study of unidentified flying objects by a team at the University of Colorado, the project coordinator, Robert J. Low, reported today.

Jackson Pollock's painting entitled "One" (1950) has been acquired by the Museum of Modern Art for a price reported to be $350,000. It was formerly in the collection of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Heller in New York, and is now hanging with the Sidney and Harriet Janis Collection at the museum.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 16 (UPI) -- Thomas C. Dilbeck, a country and western song writer facing a divorce trial involving $250,000 in property, fired a pistol in a crowded courtroom corridor today, killing his wife and wounding three other persons, the police reported.
DETROIT, Jan. 16 -- The United Automobile Workers union struck a General Motors Corporation parts plant in Defiance, Ohio, today, making 3,000 workers idle.
ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- Governor Rockefeller asked the State Legislature in his budget message today to allow the state to sell its lottery tickets at a wider variety of outlets.

A plan for the consolidation of Armour Company with Gulf Western Industries, Inc., involving securities valued at more than $400-million, was announced yesterday by William W. Prince, chairman of Armour and Charles G. Bluhdorn, chairman of G. W.
THEADORA VAN RUNKLE, a 5-foot-9-inch flash of lightning in the Hollywood design firmament, streaked into New York yesterday. She thought it was pretty cold, despite her taupe suede boots.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- European financiers expressed general satisfaction today with Prime Minister Wilson's long-range spending cuts to restore financial confidence and make devaluation succeed in resolving Britain's balance-of-payments crisis.

The Waterfront Commission ordered yesterday the temporary suspension of the registrations of three Brooklyn longshoremen. At the same time it started proceedings to determine if the registrations should be revoked or canceled altogether.

In your issue of Jan. 10 Robert Halsband, president of the American Center of P.E.N., undertakes to speak for the whole membership when he says, of the sentence of LeRoi Jones: "P.E.N. vigorously protests the impropriety of any judge imposing a sentence the severity of which is based upon his disapproval of a literary work of the accused."

The United States Track and Field Federation will not ask the Amateur Athletic Union to sanction its meet at Madison Square Garden, Feb. 9, thus putting all athletes involved in jeopardy of losing their right to compete in international competitions, including the Olympic Games.
The stock market registered its first definite decline in eight sessions yesterday.

Governor Rockefeller's proposed budget provides perhaps only $60-million to $65-million toward closing the $440-million gap Mayor Lindsay has estimated for the city's fiscal year starting next July 1.

The president of one of the most influential foundations warned yesterday that the nation's colleges and universities would be unable to meet the demands for higher education unless the Federal Government accepted "the principal part" of the financial burden.

GENEVA, Jan. 16 -- Washington's determination to curb the outflow of dollars has further clouded the already uncertain outlook for the second United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, scheduled to be held in New Delhi next month.
The Consolidated Edison Company of New York announced yesterday plans to reduce prices for some heating services.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UPI) -- Representative Joseph Y. Resnick, Democrat of upstate New York, today branded as "a barefaced fairy tale" the Navy's denial of any connection between the transfer of Capt. Richard G. Alexander as skipper of the battleship New Jersey and the part he played in the so-called "Arnheiter affair."
SOME YEARS ago, it was the in thing for can companies to round out their lines by adding glass containers. Trends change.
The Board of Education voted at its meeting last night to name a new high school in the southeast Bronx after the lte Adlai E. Stevenson, former Chief United States delegate to the United Nations.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 17 -- "It is up to the American Administration to show us one clear stand, not two or three," a responsible Cambodian remarked here yesterday.

" The expense you incur for the prescribed amount of whisky is a deductible medical expense." This statement comes straight from the Government's 1968 edition of "Your Federal Income Tax." Such a prescribed dose may, or may not, be pleasurable medicine for many people, but quite a few elderly persons, especially those with angina pectoris and other heart conditions, apparently are supposed to take a little whisky daily on doctor's orders.
Recently several newspapers in this country published a dispatch by U.P.I. from Moscow about the "Communist view on heart transplants."

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- Speculation against the dollar erupted on the London gold market again today as hoarders rushed to turn in their dollars for gold in advance of President Johnson's State of the Union Message tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Alaska Airlines denied today that Alaska Coastal Airlines was little more than a helicopter shuttle service and urged the Civil Aeronautics Board to approve a merger of the two carriers.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 17 -- Dr. Allan M. Cartter, chancellor of New York University, called today for substantial state support of private colleges and universities. He held that "much of private higher education cannot survive until 1980" if trends of the last 10 years continued.

WITH the exception of wine, there is nothing in the world of food and drink about which partisans will wax more rhapsodic than cheese. Even the most laconic and taciturn will use such poetic words as lusty, humble, chaste and naive, blended with such earthy words as rich, salty, basic and bland.

CONCORD, N. H., Jan. 17 -- Republican supporters of Richard M. Nixon believe they can help defeat Gov. George Romney of Michigan in the New Hampshire primary by making him out to be a temporary stand-in for a timid Governor Rockefeller.

HOUSTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Two Houston specialists said today that they had built and tested a model of a mechanical heart pump that they believe is three times as efficient as the human heart. It has been tested a short time on a dog.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 17 -- The New York Knickerbockers staved off the Baltimore Bullets in the final quarter tonight in Civic Center to win the National Basketball Association game, 111-109.

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Roy Jenkins, said today that he would soon raise taxes to clamp down on private spending in Britain. He gave that grim preview of the budgetary measures that will follow the massive reshaping of Government policy announced yesterday by Prime Minister Wilson.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced the adoption today, with a few amendments, of its previously proposed rule broadening slightly its definition of corporate insiders.

As the tattered threads of the Marcus case unravel, the need becomes clear for a better system of gathering information about prospective city officials. If public office is truly to be considered a public trust by the community at large, those holding high positions must willingly disclose pertinent facts about their background and especially their financial interests.

Maurice O. Hunt, the city's Acting Commissioner of Social Services, is resigning from city service effective Feb. 2, the day after Dr. Jack R. Goldberg takes over as welfare chief. Mr. Hunt has been First Deputy Commissioner since Dec. 5, 1966.

THE rhetoric of theater criticism in New York has become so absurdly inflated by meaningless superlatives and triple exclamation points that a description of a play as merely "good" is immediately interpreted to mean: Don't waste your time on it.
THE recent Europa Cup Heat at Copenhagen was staged among five-man teams from Denmark, West Germany and Ireland. Each team played three five-board matches with the two other teams.
HAMPSTEAD, N. H., Jan. 17 (UPI) -- Gov. George Romney of Michigan ended a six-day visit to New Hampshire today by calling for the appointment of "better men" to the United States Supreme Court.
LONDON, Jan. 17 -- Lee Kuan Yew, Singapore's Prime Minister, said today that he was going home to develop "Israeli-style" armed forces.

Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes announced yesterday that he had canceled a $5.9-million contract with the Sperry Rand Corporation for the initial installation of the "brains" of the city's long-delayed electronic traffic control system.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- President Johnson's State of the Union Message was received by Congress in almost complete partisan spirit tonight. Democrats called it wise and practical and Republicans said it amounted to the opening of the President's campaign for re-election.

" Laird, Inc., is our version of a private investment," Sidney A. Staunton said yesterday in explaining the operations of an unusual -- and eminently successful -- member firm of the New York Stock Exchange.
Stock prices wobbled uncertainly in active trading yesterday.
MOSCOW, Jan. 17 -- Pavel M. Litvinov, who sent testimony at a Moscow trial last year abroad for publication in defiance of a warning from the secret police, has been dismissed from his teaching job.
In rather active trading sessions, metals futures turned firmer here and in London yesterday.
PENNSAUKEN, N. J., Jan 17 (AP) -- A 21-year-old Camden man was arrested and charged tonight with slashing and heating two Camden girls the night before.
The Port of New York set new records again last year for international travel volume and duty collected on imported merchandise.
GUATEMALA, Jan. 17 -- This capital went through a second day of terrorism today with the killing of a leading conservative businessman.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 17 -- According to reports that are causing deep concern in diplomatic circles here, Chinese Communist advisers have been infiltrating into upper Burma to assist insurgent groups there.
In an expansion of its retail facilities in Greenwich Village, Bon Marche, Inc., a furniture specialty company, has leased two additional stores at Fifth Avenue and 13th Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The National Council of Churches urged the Supreme Court today to bar large housing developers from refusing to sell homes to Negroes.
PALERMO, Sicily, Jan. 17 -- Earthquake damage and the fear of additional tremors have turned 600 square miles of west central Sicily into a huge refugee encampment.
MINOT, N. D., Jan. 17 (UPI) -- An Air Force jet tanker crashed and burned while taking off in fog today, killing a general and 11 of 12 other persons aboard.
The New York Yacht Club, a symbol of international sailing supremacy, provided the setting yesterday for a ceremony honoring the world's top offshore powerboat driver.

Terrorism from left and right is a frequent intruder on the Guatemalan scene, but the cold-blooded, cowardly murder of two American officers at midday on the streets of the capital city suggests a new dimension and an ominous one.

MIAMI, Jan. 17 -- For the first time in 41 years of racing at Hialeah, the track was forced today to cancel its opening program. Track officials then resolved their purse dispute with horsemen and announced that racing would begin tomorrow.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Jan. 17 -- A force of 198 detectives and uniformed policemen swooped down on the campus of the State University Center here this morning and arrested 33 young people -- 25 of them students -- for violations of narcotics laws.

RALEIGH, N. C., Jan. 17 (AP) -- While antiwar pickets marched outside the Raleigh Induction Center, George Vlasits refused today to answer several questions during his processing, and his induction was stopped.
CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- The Percy Group, born three months ago, died today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- I. W. Abel, president of the United Steelworkers of America, asked today for a Federal antitrust investigation of the proposed merger of the Kennecott Copper Corporation and the Peabody Coal Corporation.
Some tardy donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund express the hope that their gifts are not too late to be included in the 1967-68 holiday appeal.

Tuition fees will be increased in all but four divisions of Columbia University next September. It will be the fifth major increase at Columbia in nine years. In most divisions of the university the rise will be $150 to $200 for the academic year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The United States called on the Soviet Union tonight to use its influence to strengthen international policing of Cambodia's frontiers and urged it to drop its opposition to such moves.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell asked the Justice Department today to send a "strike force" to the New York City airports to help combat organized crime.

The top executive team that has guided the fortunes of Bobbie Brooks, Inc., of Cleveland for the last 14 years is breaking up. The resignation of Jack Landis, executive vice president, is set for the end of this month.

Gov. Ronald Reagan asserted here last night that the "New Economics espoused by the Johnson Administration had pushed the nation into insolvency, despite an unmatched level of productivity and seeming prosperity."

CLEVELAND, Jan. 17 -- Miss Geraldine Williams, executive assistant to Mayor Carl B. Stokes, was dismissed from her $15,600 job today because of a connection with an illegal East Side liquor operation.

TORONTO, Jan. 20 (Canadian Press) -- Emphysema, the lung disease that often suffocates its victims, strikes earlier and pushes them faster toward death in air-polluted industrial cities than in nonindustrial, unpolluted communities, experts said here this week.
It has recently been urged, in the interest of "economy," that the Post Office Department eliminate all place names from postmarks; they feel that the ZIP code is enough.

The creative people at Smith/Greenland who were assigned to do the advertising for Flying A had a lucky break -- they found that the product difference the gasoline should have to make it sell was already in it.
Weight Watchers, a monthly magazine devoted to the problems of obesity, is reaching newsstands today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- The National Catholic Conference for Interracial Justice and 24 Roman Catholic bishops will file a brief with the United States Supreme Court tomorrow in the first open-housing case to be heard by the high court.

BAHREIN, Jan. 17 -- Saudi Arabia and Bahrein have agreed to go ahead with plans for a causeway linking Bahrein Island with the Arabian Peninsula following talks between King Faisal and Sheik Issa Bin Salman al-Khalifa, ruler of Bahrein, who returned today from Riyadh.
Another aviation pioneer stepped down yesterday when C. R. Smith, 68 years old, relinquished his post as chief executive officer of American Airlines, Inc.

Perhaps because she is supposed to be "a celebrated singer,'' Puccini's Floria Tosca is a heroine in whom an unusual mixture of elements clash, and are not resolved. Grand-lady arrogance, girlish innocence, impetuosity, tenderness, and even the ability to kill (in hot blood) are the most obvious traits.

BAD GASTEIN, Austria, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Olga Pall, a 20-year-old Austrian who helps her mother run a gas station, won the first international downhill race of the season for women today at the opening of the Silver Jug ski meet.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 17 (UPI) -- A campaign was under way today to collect a million signatures to petitions urging the impeachment of President Johnson for "high crimes" in the Vietnam war.

The patchwork settlement of the one-day taxicab strike leaves the industry in as chaotic a state as ever, with no prospect of improvement in service in return for the higher fares and profits now awarded it under a "compromise" agreement.
The prolonged cold spell here has reduced the supply of such foods as fish and vegetables and sent prices soaring.

VIENNA, Jan. 17 -- A major Cabinet shuffle, designed to improve the political chances of Chancellor Josef Klaus's Government, was finally decided upon tonight by Austria's conservative ruling People's party. Four men holding five posts were replaced.

A SPECTER is haunting the capitals of sport -- the specter of unionism. Athletes are groping seriously toward some kind of representation more effective than the present players' associations, and established unions, such as the Teamsters, have shown enormous interest in putting locals in the locker room.

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- The French Government said today that Britain's moves to trim foreign and domestic commitments "seem to mark a certain progress" toward participation in the European communities. But it renewed its advice that Britain seek associate membership in the Common Market.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Soviet Union has agreed to carry French equipment in a Russian satellite that will orbit the moon.

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- The last two big British-owned companies in the motor vehicle industry are merging into a giant with sales of $1.9-billion to compete with United States and other foreign competitors at home and abroad.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- A broad scale consumer-protection program, including "a major study of automobile insurance," was proposed tonight by President Johnson.

A Federal commission studying discrimination against Negro and Puerto Rican white collar workers charged yesterday that the communications industry was giving Americans "a false image of the society in which they live."
BEDFORD, N. H., Jan. 17 -- Danny Meadow Mouse and Bambi would have enjoyed the Northeast Fish and Wildlife Conference here at the Sheraton-Wayfarer Motor Inn this week.

WILMINGTON, N. Y., Jan. 17 -- "Americans learn to ski faster than Europeans," said Karl Fahrner, the Austrian-reared ski school director at the big Whiteface Mountain complex here high in the Adirondacks.

The two title fights pitting Joe Frazier against Buster Mathis, and Emile Griffith against Nino Benvenuti will be held March 4 at the new Madison Square Garden, Harry Markson, the director of boxing at the Garden, announced yesterday.

Lou Carnesecca, the St. John's basketball coach, nervous before each game and even more so during the games, weathered another tough one last night as his Redmen defeated St. Joseph's of Philadelphia, 80-72, at Alumni Hall.

The logic of New York Times editorials is such that you had me nodding in agreement to "Freedom of Theater -- Here" (Jan. 6) until I reached the reference concerning Actors' Equity's action concerning Roy Dotrice and his most exceptional one-man play "Brief Lives."

THE American Contract Bridge League does not permit artificial systems, of the type played by many European experts, in normal tournaments. Such methods can be used in head-to-head team matches, but few serious players are willing to experiment with systems of the Italian type if their use is restricted.
RICHARD RODNEY BENNETT is a 32-year-old British composer who in recent years has become a prominent member of the avant-garde there. His music, however, has had very few hearings in this country.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 16 (AP) -- A five-year-old dispute erupted into violence today at St. Sara Serbian Orthodox Church in suburban Parma, where opposing factions traded punches and threw chairs.

GBATALA, Liberia, Jan. 17 (AP) -- In a clearing hacked out of the forest in central Liberia, Jewish Negroes that fled America's racial struggles is trying to create a new life in a republic founded by freed American slaves.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Jan. 18 -- Troops of the Americal Division killed 80 Vietcong soldiers in a clash yesterday. Two United States soldiers were wounded.
The Hungarian Catholic League of America will hold its 14th annual Hungarian Charity Ball on Jan. 27 in the Pierre's Grand Ballroom.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- New York State's noted 27th Armored Division will reach the end of its long, battle-scarred career on Feb. 1 when it will be deactivated under a drastic countrywide reorganization of the Army National Guard.
The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and major stockholders of listed companies.
Seven office employes of Local 365 of the United Automobile Workers have walked out and are picketing the local in a bid for higher wages.

PORTSMOUTH, N. H., Jan. 17 -- A group of supporters of Governor Rockefeller of New York, undaunted by his demurrers, is preparing to open a write-in campaign for him in the New Hampshire Presidential primary.

CHARLESTON, S. C., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Fewer than a dozen white person attended the funeral today of retired Federal Judge J. Waties Waring, who had said that his Charleston friends had deserted him for ruling in favor of Negroes in civil rights cases.

Ed Kranepool, the youngest senior citizen in the baseball world, signed his 1968 contract with the New York Mets yesterday and remained the only human being to grace the active roster of the Mets in each season of their existence.

Rudolf Firkusny's appearance in the Great Performers Series at Philharmonic Hall last nigt just missed being an anniversary event. The Czechoslovak pianist made his American debut at Town Hall on Jan. 13, 1938.

BONN, Jan. 17 -- Eastern European sources suggested today that the weekend trip of the three top Soviet leaders to Warsaw and East Berlin concerned a new initiative on the German question as well as the forthcoming Budapest conference of Communist parties.
City elementary schools will give more class time to reading starting next month as part of a new systemwide effort to overcome reading retardation among pupils.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Government spending will rise by $10.4-billion in the coming fiscal year to $186-billion, President Johnson disclosed tonight.
Earnings of the Caterpillar Tractor Company declined sharply last year, the company's report from Peoria, III., disclosed yesterday.

The New York City Council on Port Development and Promotion yesterday asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to suspend a proposed motor carrier rate increase which, it is estimated, would add as much as $65-million to annual freight bills here.

" Alzira" has been called Verdi's worst opera. The composer himself referred to it as "really ugly" and "thoroughly bad." Last night in Carnegie Hall it was presented for the first time in this country, in a concert version, by the American Opera Society, and the performance was enough to make one agree with the composer.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 17 (UPI) -- A 30-year-old assistant professor of history at the University of Maryland, ordered to do janitorial work in lieu of military service after he turned in his draft card, charged today that the draft was being used "to repress opposition to the Vietnam war."

Police agencies in the United States are purchasing armored cars and stockpiling such equipment as tear gas grenades, other nonlethal weapons, and shotguns because of the possibility of riots in the months ahead.

Moscow, Jan. 16 -- Yevgeny Yevtushenko has published a new series of poems about the United States, including one in which he seems to liken himself to a rare blue fox on an Alaskan animal farm, "born in captivity," but unwilling to escape his cage.
A small Dutch freighter was foundering in a North Atlantic gale some 1,300 miles east of here last night in weather bad enough to prevent the 16-man crew from abandoning the listing ship.

Former Water Commissioner James L. Marcus and Herbert Itkin, Manhattan labor lawyer, have been ordered by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan to appear at his offices today for questioning concerning an alleged $10,000 bribery conspiracy in which a Brooklyn salesman was arrested yesterday.
Investors kept the pot boiling yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, where volume soared above the nine-millionshare mark for the first time in the exchange's history.

TRENTON, Jan. 17 -- The Hughes administration offered in effect today to guarantee the relocation of families threatened with eviction by the proposed New Jersey College of Medicine and Dentistry in Newark.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office said yesterday that the misuse of stolen First National City Bank credit cards, issued unsolicited by the bank last summer, might cost the bank hundreds of thousands of dollars.

Some excellent athletes from the South will have their first big night in New York competition at the 43d annual Millrose Games in Madison Square Garden next Thursday. The strongest contingent will come from the University of Tennessee.

CHICAGO, Jan 17 (UPI) -- Phil Goyette and Camille Henry scored last-period goals tonight to give the New York Rangers a 4-2 triumph over the Chicago Black Hawks, ending an 11-game unbeaten string for the Hawks on home ice.

THE ideal dance program, like the ideal meal, is not easily attained. Perhaps, to a significant extent, it depends upon the state of the weather, the state of the digestion, even the state of the union. Yet at the New York State Theater last night, the New York City Ballet came up with a program that, if not ideal, would certainly serve a turn while the Platonists argued. It was, after all, marvelous.

A new real estate firm specializing in consulting services and in realty investment and development has been formed by William Zimmerman and Harry J. Scanlan. The firm will be known as Zimmerman Scanlan and will have offices at 200 Park Avenue.
IN a tiny, bright yellow shop on the Lower East Side, two young mothers and a single girl have joined forces in a sort of private antipoverty project for mothers with meager budgets.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -The Washington Urban League this city's largest civil rights organization, said today that its board of directors had voted unanimously to "defer" joining a new black power coalition of Negro groups being formed here by Stokely Carmichael.

Zoe Caldwell filled in for Anne Bancroft in "The Devils" two seasons ago. Then she got a Tony for her work in Tennessee Williams's "Slapstick Tragedy," which ran about a week. Now she is a star in "The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie," which opened Tuesday at the Helen Hayes Theater.

Dr. Detlev W. Bronk, president of Rockefeller University, said yesterday the university feared that a proposed heliport operation a block away, at East 61st Street and the East River, "may well result" in injury to the school's hospital patients and to the accuracy of its research.
The National Women's Division of the American Jewish Congress has announced that its annual Mass Media Award will be presented this year to The New York Times.

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- Mai Van Bo, the North Vietnamese envoy who elaborated on several aspects of Hanoi's position in a statement yesterday, acted with the approval of his Government, it was disclosed today.
Consumer spending for apparel should advance at a faster rate this year than consumer expenditures in general, a leading economist said yesterday.
DETROIT, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company confirmed today that it had been quietly raising prices of automobile parts. The three other major car makers declined to offer immediate comment.

ONE of today's paradoxes is that the more anti-war the young become, the more fond they get of dressing up in uniforms. However, an 18-year-old who "flipped" over a WAVES uniform says war has nothing to do with it -- it's all fashion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Stronger controls over the billions of dollars of speculative trading in farm and food commodities could result from a bill sent to the Senate today by its Agriculture Committee.
Reduce the buying price of gold to $33.50 an ounce and end much of the world gold speculation, Senator Vance Hartke counseled yesterday.
Twenty-two suspended agents of the Internal Revenue Service, four former agents and a certified public accountant were arrested yesterday on charges of having bribed an undercover tax inspector.
WHEN two liver-colored field spaniels called Twiggy and Mac became best brace in show at the recent American Spaniel Club national specialty at the Hotel Roosevelt, the award was sensational.
Acquisition-minded Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., is now interested in the pulp and paper business.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- President Johnson gave a harder definition tonight of his position on peace talks with North Vietnam, and outlined an expanded program of legislation for the cities and the hard-core unemployed, in his 1968 State of the Union Message.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 17 -- A local agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation disclosed yesterday that he placed a listening device in a gambler's office here in 1962 because he had been ordered to by J. Edgar Hoover, director of the F.B.I.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- President Johnson asked Congress tonight to repeal the last remaining "gold cover" behind the nation's currency so that all the $12-billion in gold remaining in the Treasury would be freed for international settlements.

" Fellow citizens, we cannot escape history," Abraham Lincoln observed in his State of the Union message on Dec. 1, 1862. "We of this Congress and this Administration will be remembered in spite of ourselves. No personal significance or insignificance can spare one or another of us. The fiery trial through which we pass will light us down in honor or dishonor to the latest generation."

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- Mrs. Francoise Jordan, former wife of the leader of the British Nazi movement, was found guilty today of conspiracy to set fire to synagogues and was sentenced to 18 months in prison.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 14 -- Pressure is building up to end Nigeria's six-month-old civil war and to reunite the nation by March 31, the date set by the chief of state, Maj. Gen. Yakubu Gowon, for ending the war.

Pacific Far East Line of San Francisco asked the Maritime Administration yesterday to exchange two 5,966-ton freighters for two larger World War II-built troopships for nonsubsidized service between the West Coast and Guam.
ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- Governor Rockefeller is expected to appoint former Assemblyman Paul J. Curran to the State Commission of Investigation.
A leading New York banker asserted yesterday that President Johnson's recently announced program to bring the nation's balance of payments into line amounted to foreignexchange controls.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Besides being a report to the nation on achievements and a call to Congress for action, a President's State of the Union Message is invariably a revelation of his own state of mind.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UPI) -- Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut, said today that top United States officials in Saigon wanted to import United States narcotics agents to crack down on American servicemen using marijuana and other illegal drugs.

DETROIT, Jan. 17 -- Henry Ford 2d, Ford Motor Company chairman, has sent a 600-word letter to 10,000 Ford supervisory employes asking for "your active support" in the company's efforts to aid Negroes.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Cookie Gilchrist, the American Football League's No. 4 career leading rusher; Chris Burford, a top pass catcher, and a placekicker, Dick Van Raaphorst, were among the 20 Western Division players selected by the Cincinnati Bengals and announced today.
Taxi drivers here began circling Jan. 26 on their calendars yesterday as the date higher cab fares are expected to take effect.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Lyndon B. Johnson went to Capitol Hill tonight for the 182d observance of the Constitution's instruction that the President of the United States shall "from time to time give to the Congress information of the state of the Union, and recommend to their consideration such measures as he shall judge necessary and expedient."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- President Johnson stopped working on his State of the Union Message for five minutes this afternoon to look at a dozen new pictures of his grandson. Then he plunged back into polishing his final draft of the speech to Congress that was to become the outline of his program for 1968.

The controversial and restrictive college punt rule of 1967 was repealed yesterday by the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Football Rules Committee, which voted once again to permit any member of a kicking team to charge downfield at the snap of the ball.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The wooden door on Room 2161 of the Rayburn House Office Building is locked most of the time to discourage curiosity seekers and photographers, some of whom have tried to poke their cameras through the brass mail slot.

The city Department of Investigation will make detailed checks of the personal finances of future mayoral appointees for the first time as a result of the indictment of former Water Commissioner James L. Marcus and continuing investigations of several municipal departments.

THE television networks -- commercial and noncommercial -- gave varied coverage last night to President Johnson's State of the Union Message. The text was carried in full over the three commercial chains and the one noncommercial hook-up, but a random sampling of the subsequent analysis reflected a generally cool response to the President's remarks.
State Supreme Court Justice J. Irwin Shapiro in Queens yesterday dismissed the indictment of 17 Negroes as criminal anarchists. They are members of the Revolutionary Action Movement.

NAPA, Calif., Jan. 17 -- Plastic covers are being used to protect the greens before the start of the $125,000 Kaiser international open golf tournament here tomorrow. This is an innovation against the nocturnal frost that has settled over the tourney site, the Silverado Country Club course.

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- Following, in translation from the French, is the transcript of an interview with Mai Van Bo, chief North Vietnamese representative in Western Europe, conducted by a reporter for the French radio and television network and made available yesterday by the North Vietnamese mission here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Congress, back in town only three days, is already complaining about the vast challenge to inaction it must face in the year ahead. Not since 1962, when Congress came close to achieving total paralysis, have members had their genius for doing nothing so sharply challenged.
A hormone-like extract that may prevent hardening of the arteries has proved to be effective in its first test on a small number of persons, three California scientists reported yesterday.

SASEBO, Japan, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Eight hundred leftist students of the militant Zengakuren student organization were beaten back by the police today when they tried to invade the United States Navy base here.
Following is the transcript of President Johnson's State of the Union Message to Congress yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 17 -- A loan of nearly $1,874,000 to finance housing for low-income families in the predominantly Negro North Side area of Atlantic City was announced today by the Prudential Insurance Company of America.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 17 (UPI) -- Gov. Raymond P. Shafer held firm today in refusing to give names in the reported sun blinding of six college students who had taken LSD.

The 10 "roll-on roll-off containerships" that Atlantic Container Line, Ltd., will have in operation next year will do the work of 35 conventional vessels now in service on the Atlantic by the line's member companies, according to O.I.M. Porton, general manager in North America.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- President Johnson indicated tonight that he was not yet satisfied that Hanoi had met his requirements for a halt in the bombing of North Vietnam and an opening of peace talks.
FOR Lee Kuan Yew, Singapore's Prime Minister, chess -- a favorite pastime -- is an extension of the political life. It requires the ability to plan ahead.
The New York State Dormitory Authority, which canceled a $48.1-million bond sale on Dec. 19 because interest rates were too high, sold the issue yesterday at a cost above 5 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Federal tax collectors who treat citizens roughly often reflect pressures from their superiors, a Senate Judiciary subcommittee was told today.

Listening to a poetry reading by Louis and Allen Ginsberg is very much like going to a recital concert by Birgit Nilsson and Lena Horne -- each has her own distinctive qualities but you don't think of them together.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Industrial production moved up strongly in December for the second straight month, but house building fell to its lowest level since early summer, the Government reported today.
THE phone rang at the house of an American correspondent in a capital crowded with royalty for a ceremonial occasion. The correspondent's 8-year-old daughter answered it.

Mayor Lindsay made public last night a memorandum estimating that 1,250,000 New York City residents would be "adversely affected" by the Medicaid cutbacks proposed this week by Governor Rockefeller. About 100,000 would be dropped and the rest would have to bear more of their medical bills, the Mayor asserted.
Stock prices rallied at the opening of trading yesterday, but the advance quickly ran out of steam and most of the early gains had vanished by the close.

Musical historians, should there be any such creatures in the future, may look back and choose John Cage and Iannis Xenakis as the two most radical composers of this century. Not the best, but polarizations of our esthetic thought.
The board of directors of Time Inc. announced yesterday the election of Henry Luce 3d as publisher of Fortune magazine, effective April 1.
A jeweler was shot and killed yesterday in a shop a block from Times Square when he tried to press an alarm button during a holdup by two armed youths.
Two small male and two small female white whales met in a pool at the Coney Island Aquarium yesterday amid sighs, squeaks, moans, clicks, clacks and baby-chick-like peeps.

CANTHO, South Vietnam, Jan. 18 (AP) -- A United States infantryman captured by the Vietcong has been dramatically rescued in the Mekong Delta by an Army helicopter gunship that attacked his guerrilla captors, an American officer said today.

The Marine Midland Corporation, the largest bank holding company in the state, reported yesterday that its net income in 1967 came to $33.1-million. This was a rise of $2.9-million from the income for 1966.
The nation's leading securities markets will shorten their trading hours, starting next Monday, in a move to reduce the mounting backlog of paperwork in brokerage offices.

Former Water Commissioner James L. Marcus, who is under indictment in a Federal kickback case, was arrested in a new case yesterday and charged under New York State laws with bribery, conspiracy and taking $10,000 in illegal fees.

MOSCOW (UPI) Jan. 18 -- Three Russian designers dazzled an audience of Western women and Muscovites today with pop-art dresses, miniskirts, lounging pants and slim-line evening dresses cut from Western fabrics.
JAKARTA, Indonesia -- Indonesia has been finding out that economic housecleaning is easier to talk about than to achieve.

VIENTIANE, Laos -- The Lao Air Force C-47 transport rolled gently to halt on the parking apron at the Laotian royal capital, Luang Prabang, disgorging a horde of scruffy Lao army men who proceeded to unload sack after sack from the aircraft.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 18 (Agence France-Presse) -- President Tito of Yugoslavia has called on the United States to recognize the National Liberation Front of South Vietnam and halt the bombing of North Vietnam "definitely and unconditionally" to open the way for negotiations.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Jan. 18 (UPI) -- Mike Kasperak, the heart transplant patient, underwent emergency surgery today to stop bleeding in the gastrointestinal tract, believed caused by an ulcer condition.
McMURDO STATION, Antarctica -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is studying Antarctic microbes to learn how to detect life on Mars.
STONY BROOK, L. I., Jan. 18 -- "I think someday we'll look back on this raid like our parrents looked back on police raids of Prohibition the Era."
BANGKOK, Thailand -- Burma faces continued economic disarray and political uncertainty after a sharp decline in farm production and suddenly strained relations with Communist China.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand -- To reap the maximum benefit from devaluation, New Zealand must make an all-out export drive in 1968. Emphasis is likely to be placed on a new deal for dairy exports.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia -- Cambodians are undergoing a period of unaccustomed austerity.

Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange fell by 857,048 shares in the month ended Jan. 15 from the record total reported a month ago. Short interest, the exchange said yesterday, declined to 20,107,917 shares from a revised 20,964,965 shares in the month ended Dec. 15.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia -- The Government warned Malaysians early last year that 1967 would be the start of a decade marked by "an uphill struggle."

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- Lobbyists representing farmers and large corporations, podiatrists and liquor dealers, trade unions and employer associations have registered with the Department of State for the 1968 session of the Legislature.
Bond dealers, who had a vague hope that President Johnson would say something in his State of the Union Message Wednesday night to benefit their market, were disappointed.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 -- Tim Wood, a 19-year-old college student who began ice skating at the age of 2 1/2 by "pushing a chair around the Detroit Skating Club," got the national figure-skating championships off in surprising fashion this morning by placing first in the senior men's compulsory figures.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- President Johnson today ordered United States embassies and other agencies to cut their overseas staffs by 10 per cent in an effort to stem the flow of dollars out of the country.

PARIS -- The collapse of Britain's last imperial pretensions in Asia is bound to produce major new American policy decisions. In one or another way these will affect the Western Pacific and Indian Ocean power structure for years to come.
An expressive and expensive world of antiques will be unveiled today at the 7th Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 66th Street, as the 14th annual Winter Antiques Show gets under way.

The city is wrestling with the problem of how to word most simply and accurately a sticker or card that will soon be attached to taxi meters adjusting fares upward.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Eartha Kitt, the singer, stunned other guests at a White House luncheon today when she angrily told Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson that American youth was rebelling because of the Vietnam war.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 18 (Agence France-Presse) -- The North Vietnamese Consul General here said today that the United States must guarantee a withdrawal of American troops from South Vietnam if Hanoi-Washington talks were to be productive.
A former Park Avenue art dealer pleaded guilty yesterday to having sold $15,500 of paintings that he falsely represented as work by Marc Chagall, Pablo Picasso and Henri Matisse.

To a nation pervaded, as the President rightly said, by "a certain restlessness," a nation longing for leadership, a nation whose "will . . . is being tried, not its strength" -- to this nation Lyndon B. Johnson in his State of the Union message offered little inspiration.
A call for resignation of the entire board of directors of the major citywide Puerto Rican antipoverty agency has been made by some influential members, following a city order to overhaul the agency.

TOKYO -- Despite adverse influences at home and abroad that led to a stern admonition for restraint in the surging domestic economy last year, Japan has made further gains in her progress from complete ruin two decades ago to the front rank of industrial nations.
Two priests of the Maryknoll Fathers, a Roman Catholic missionary order, have been suspended from their priestly functions for alleged involvement in the leftist guerrilla movement in Guatemala.
A group of community leaders asked Mayor Lindsay yesterday to find a city job for Robert S. Collier, who has served time in prison for his role in a bomb plot.

BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 18 -- The new president of the University of California was on record today as being against a "double standard" by legislators and the public in condemning certain actions on campuses.

FOR those aging theatergoers who can still remember weeping with Maurice Schwartz and Celia Adler or discovering the timeless qualities of Jewish humor with Menasha Skulnik and Molly Picon, Channel 13 presented at 9 last night a nostalgic hour of reminiscences of the Yiddish theater in New York. The journey down the Yiddish memory lane was called "The Golden Age of Second Avenue," and Herschel Bernardi was the sentimental guide.
PARIS, Jan. 18 -- Andreas Papandreou, leader of the Greek left now in exile, warned the Greek military junta today to restore democratic rule promptly or risk civil war.
The most recent attempt by Mayor Lindsay to trim the Lindsay-Bundy school decentralization proposals reveals the bankruptcy of the Mayor's approach to the problem of effective education.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Administration officials indicated today that President Johnson's program to build six million housing units for low and moderate income families would depend initially on the expansion and modification of old programs, and not -- as widely expected -- on any major new legislative thrust.
TOKYO -- According to economic analysts, every Japanese aspires to own the "Three C's" -- color television, car and cooler (air-conditioner).
BAD GASTEIN, Austria, Jan. 18 (AP) -- French and American women skiers made a strong showing today in the slalom windup of the Silver Jug Alpine meet.
SEOUL, South Korea -- Continued economic growth, marked by expanded investment activities, rising industrial output and increased exports, is bringing a better life to many South Koreans.
President Johnson's State of the Union observations on the state of the world offer small comfort to those at home and abroad who look to the United States for leadership in international affairs.

A 34-year follow-up study of 200 California teen-agers has shown that those who became cigarette smokers were generally more aggressive and rebellious, less motivated to achieve and less appreciative of mature values as adolescents than those who did not become smokers.
SYDNEY, Australia -- Australia's economic helmsmen are preparing to ride out the storm of Britain's devaluation and the United States' restriction on foreign capital investment.
GUATEMALA, Jan. 18 -- Informed observers here expect prolonged violence in this Cen tral American capital for an indefinite period.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The decline of civil rights as a prime political issue was apparent last night when President Johnson devoted only one sentence to it in his State of the Union Message and the sentence failed to arouse a ripple of applause.

Recent upheavals in the international economic and monetary worlds have dimmed prospects for significant progress toward liberalized global commerce at the second United Nations Conference on Trade and Development at New Delhi next month. But hopes still flicker.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -- Jan. 18 -- Secretary General Thant made a new appeal today for the United States to halt the bombing of North Vietnam as a first step toward peace, even without any hope of a halt in the fighting in South Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- A prominent Alaska Democrat paid off a high-interest bank loan with disaster funds lent by the Small Busines Administration after the Fairbanks flood last August, a Congressman charged today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Government urged the Supreme Court today to permit a speedier merger of the Pennsylvania and New York Central railroads by quickly forwarding to a lower court its decision approving the deal.

KARACHI, Pakistan -- The Pakistani economy made energetic progress last year after recovering from the adverse effects of the 1965 war with India, two consecutive years of drought and natural calamities, and a reduction of foreign economic aid.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Government announced today plans to reduce further the production of plutonium for nuclear weapons by closing down one reactor each at its atomic plants at Aiken, S. C., and Hanford, Wash.
PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Jan. 18 -- The political brigade backing George Romney in the New Hampshire primary campaign is considerably encouraged by the five-day swing their candidate ended here last night.
Contemporary plays by leading Swedish authors will be presented in dramatized readings in English by the Swedish Embassy, in cooperation with the New York Public Library.

ATLANTA, Jan. 18 -- A two-day conference to settle differences between a liberal and a conservative faction of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. -- the Southern Presbyterians -- ended today with both sides resolved to pursue their separate courses.

The Franklin National Bank, which for the last 2 1/2 years has periodically announced its intention to form a bank holding company, disclosed a detailed share-exchange proposal yesterday at its Mineola, L. I., headquarters. It would create a concern with combined assets of $2.7-billion.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 18 (AP) -The International Control Commission has visited the area in Cambodia where American correspondents reported having found an abandoned Vietcong camp in mid-November.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- The State Commissioner of Social Services indicated today that his department would interpret liberally the new Federal legislation designed to force mothers receiving public assistance for their children to go to work.
SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 18 -- Mail service in Australia was paralyzed today when sorters joined a week old strike by drivers because the Government began to recruit volunteer drivers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Administration hailed the agreement today on a draft treaty to ban the spread of nuclear weapons, but warned that a long and difficult process lay ahead before its purpose could be realized.
KABUL, Afghaniston -- The Afghan economy continues to benefit from what amounts to a joint Soviet-American aid program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission censured and took disciplinary action today against Laird, Bissell Meeds, Inc., a New York Stock Exchange member firm, and one of its vice presidents.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UPI) -- Selective Service headquarters killed today a Nevada draft board's order assigning a job swabbing floors to a history professor who had turned in his draft card to protest the Vietnam war.
MANILA -- Six-lane highways now stretch out from many Philippine cities to remote towns, and feeder roads reach most of the 30,000 rural villages.

" I Am Curious," a Swedish film directed by Vilgot Sjoman, which was acquired by Grove Press for distribution here, has been seized by the United States Customs Service on the ground that it is obscene. Barney Rosset, the president of Grove Press, said yesterday that he was instituting legal action to contest the seizure.
SKI area operators throughout the Northeast were wondering yesterday whether the much dreaded January thaw was about to leave its mark on their carefully manicured slopes and trails.
The Korean National Railroad freight system should show a marked improvement in performance in the next few years.

THERE was a world premiere at the concert of the New York Philharmonic last night, but the real excitement came after intermission when Andre Watts, backed by Leonard Bernstein, played the Brahms B flat Piano Concerto.

A Congressional investigation of a decision by the Maritime Administration to allow Lykes Bros. Steamship Co., Inc. to withdraw $35-million from special reserve funds was asked yesterday by Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union.

An off-duty patrolman on a shopping trip and a police sergeant responding to a false holdup alarm teamed up yesterday to foil a $30,000 robbery of a savings and loan association in the Flushing section of Queens.

SASEBO, Japan, Friday, Jan. 19 -- Policemen battled with several hundred leftist students this morning near the main entrance to the United States naval base here as the nuclear-powered aircraft carrier Enterprise arrived.
BANGKOK, Thailand -- Thailand's economic progress slowed down in 1967.
SAPPORO, Japan -- Contemplating the undeveloped potential of Hokkaido, Japan's northernmost main island, a Japanese might well paraphrase Horace Greeley by saying, "Go North, young man!"

Zero Mostel, absent from the stage since he left "Fiddler on the Roof" in 1965, is to return in Paddy Chayefsky's comedy "The Latent Heterosexual." The play is to open March 12 in Dallas under the direction of Burgess Meredith.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 18 (UPI) -The Cincinnati Royals opened an 11-point lead after three periods tonight, then held off a San Diego Rocket surge in the closing minutes and triumphed, 129-126, in a National Basketball Association game. It was the fifth consecutive victory for Cincinnati.

Regina Resnik took over the title role of "Carmen" in last night's performance of the Bizet work at the Metropolitan Opera. In bringing to the part a quiet, mature authority and beautiful musicianship, she gave the production, new this season, an artistic weight at its center that was badly needed.
MIAMI, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Hialeah Park opened its 41st season belatedly today, pelted by rain and plagued by mechanical problems.

HAVANA, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Interior Ministry announced today that Cuba shot down a small plane and captured its United States pilot, a former paratrooper, on Dec. 29 after he dropped some arms over central Cuba.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 18 (AP) -- A soldier from Michigan has been arrested at Fort Meade, Md., and charged with the theft of 20 machine guns and 74 pistols last weekend, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today.

The Ogden Corporation, a fast-growing conglomerate company, and Charles Luckman Associates, the real estate, architectural and engineering operation of the former chief executive of Lever Brothers, said yesterday that they had agreed to merge.
