BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 18 (AP) -The Philadelphia Flyers defeated the Minnesota North Stars, 4-2, tonight in a penalty marked game to strengthen their hold on first place in the West Division of the National Hockey League.
CLOVIS, N. Mex., Jan. 18 (AP) -- A general court-martial was ordered today for a Cannon Air Force Base officer who wants to be classified as a conscientious objector to the Vietnam war.

LONDON, Jan 18 -- When massed antiwar protesters assaulted the United States Embassy, the diplomats carried on with aplomb. When machine-gun bullets pierced the embassy's glass doors, upper lips remained stiff.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.

HONG KONG -- United States plans to discourage Americans from traveling abroad and to reduce personal spending by servicemen overseas have come as an unpleasant surprise to the Asian tourist industry.
NEW DELHI -- Two years after starting a massive birth-control campaign, India is still baffled by her population problem.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The gold rush slowed markedly today in a positive reaction to President Johnson's plan to throw all of the United States gold reserves into the fight to hold the price at $35. Dealers in the London gold market characterized demand today as "very small," following yesterday's exceptional buying.

The Russian-made "War and Peace," which will run seven hours and is the most expensive film ever made, will be shown here on an unusual two-part schedule at the highest admission scale ever set for a movie.
Bargain prices and liberal, low-interest mortgage loans from the city will be conditions of sale at a Feb. 14 auction of 123 city-owned properties.
NASHVILLE, Jan. 18 (UPI) -- A black power advocate, Fred Brooks, lost a Federal Court fight today to gain readmission to Tennessee Agricultural and Industrial State University.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 (AP) -- A revolutionary approach to the problem of sonic boom was reported today by two scientists.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 18 -- The banker of Western Europe is a confused man these days as he tries to weigh the question of the dollar and the pound.

GENEVA, Jan. 18 -- President Johnson's decision to seek Congressional removal of the gold cover was hailed by Swiss bankers today as a blow to speculators who were gambling against the dollar by betting on an increase in the official gold price.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

SAIGON, South Vietnam -- A considerable number of the newcomers to the ranks of the United States aid mission will be assigned to auditing and supervising the use made of American goods and funds by Vietnamese officials in the provinces.
Chas, Pfizer Co., Inc., attained the second highest earnings in its 119-year history in 1967, John J. Powers Jr., president, reported yesterday.
DETROIT, Jan. 18 -- A high powered sports car will go on sale in March and it could revive Detroit's interest in an almost forgotten body style -- the two-seater.

A 14.4 per cent increase in the number of reported major crimes here during the last six months of 1967, over the comparable period of 1966 was announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary.
HONG KONG -- Revolutionary turmoil caused widespread damage to the economy of Communist China in 1967 and there seems to be little chance of setting things aright this year.
HONG KONG -- Considering that Hong Kong had to cope with a Communist uprising, it would not have been surprising if its social and economic fabric had been severely damaged last year.

The "No Tax on Pilgrims" proposal of Poale Agudath Israel (letter Jan. 16) is patently unconstitutional. It would require religious tests to prove that the "pilgrim" to Rome (is Rome holy, or is it Vatican City?) is a Christian; a "pilgrim" to Jerusalem is Jewish; a "pilgrim" to Mecca is a Moslem.

SAMUT PRAKAN, Thailand -- Six days a week after a lunch of rice curry and green vegetables, Boonthom Chaidet walks to the highway where the bus picks him up in time for the shift at Firestone's modern, four-year-old tire factory here, south of Bangkok.

SAIGON, South Vietnam -- Speaking of the performance of the Vietnamese economy, Charles A. Cooper, the United States mission's economics specialist, found himself able to describe 1967 as "a remarkably good year."
NAPA, Calif., Jan. 18 -Darkness prevented completion of the first round of the $125,000 Kaiser international open golf tournament today after freezing conditions delayed the start.

Reports of a mini-skirted damsel in distress on the East Side last night, the police reported, led to the discovery of a maxi-arsenal in her jacket and what was believed to be a $200.000 cache of cocaine in her hat.

ATHENS, Jan. 18 -- Greece's strictly censored press accused the American Embassy in Athens today of having engineered King Constantine's abortive attempt, on Dec. 13, to topple this country's junta leadership.
Four college girls said yesterday they knew of students who pooled their money to help pay for abortions for co-eds in need:

BOSTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -The Toronto Maple Leafs tightened the National Hockey League's East Division race tonight by defeating the Boston Bruins, 4-2, on second-period goals by Ron Ellis and Jim Pappin.

STYLE in a musical is a very precious but intangible thing. "The Happy Time," which opened at the Broadway Theater last night, is not, perhaps, going to win a very long mention in any history of the American musical, but it has a certain style, a certain charm, even a certain distinction that put it above the rest of this season's so far sadly sparse crop of Broadway musicals.
The Federal Reserve moved on several fronts in the latest statement week to tighten its credit policy, figures released by the central banking system disclosed yesterday.

HOUSTON, Jan. 18 (UPI) -- The Government said today that Cassius Clay, the deposed heavyweight boxing champion, used his religion as a last-ditch excuse to escape the draft after several other claims were rejected.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The United States and the Soviet Union have clashed over the issue of military intrusions and operations in Cambodian territory.
Businessmen, bankers and brokers reacted with aplomb yesterday to President Johnson's State of the Union Message.
WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 18 -- Definite driving assignments for tomorrow night's twin features, the first two preliminaries in the Early Bird Pacing Series at Roosevelt Raceway, were made today.
Nipper, probably the best recognized but least-known-by-name dog in the world, was sent to the doghouse yesterday by the Radio Corporation of America.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Administration officials let it be known today that their "San Antonio formula" for Vietnam negotiations still stood and that President Johnson's slightly stiffer rendering of it yesterday involved no change of terms.
THROW a couple of positive facts into the fire along with a reasonable conclusion drawn from a pipedream and you may start a raging trading blaze.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Representative Frank Thompson Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, said today he would seek action in Congress to require that all Government cargoes bound overseas be shipped in United States-flag vessels.

Assemblyman Bertram L. Podell won the Democratic nomination for the House of Representatives in Brooklyn's 13th District last night at a county committee meeting. The vote among the 800 committee members present was virtually unanimous.
City College announced yesterday the suspension of 46 students from classes for taking part in a series of demonstrations last year against the construction of a prefabricated building on the campus.
NEW DELHI -- After two years of the worst drought conditions in India in more than half a century, the country started last year to harvest the biggest crops she had ever seen.
HONG KONG -- For the half of the world's population that lives in Asia, economic progress is often measured by small victories in the continuing struggle for survival.

A wholesale meat company and two of its officers were charged yesterday in Federal Court here with selling inferior, ungraded meat bearing counterfeit Department of Agriculture seals to the United States Military Academy at West Point.
In your Jan. 7 issue you carry an interview with Theodore Kheel recommending amendment of the Taylor Act prohibiting strikes by public employes.
The 311-foot Coast Guard cutter Absecon reached the side of the sinking Dutch freighter Ocean Sprinter shortly before 6 o'clock last night about 1,300 miles east of here.
GENEVA, Jan. 18 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of draft article III for the treaty on the nonproliferation of nuclear weapons agreed on by the Soviet Union and the United States:
BILOXI, Miss., Jan. 18 (AP) -- A Federal Court jury convicted all seven defendants today in the Government's conspiracy case against racketeering and gambling on the Gulf Coast.

TORRANCE, Calif., Jan. 18 -- A metal plaque on the desk of the president of Wallis Engineering Company identifies him as "Ken Wallis, chief engineer, bicycle shop." In its sly irony, the sign epitomizes the gulf between the cerebral concepts required to design a race car today and the old-time method of chalking out lines on a dirty garage floor.
THE vigor and variety available in the modern idiom is demonstrated by the furnishings that go on view today at Macy's.
FONTANA, Calif., Jan. 18 -- Employes of the Kaiser Steel Corporation have approved revisions in the plan under which they share in the cost savings achieved by higher productivity.

Avery Brundage, the president of the International Olympic Committee, warned yesterday that the United States Government should stay out of the continuing dispute for control of this country's amateur sports. If the Government interferes, he said, the United States may be barred from the Olympics.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 18 -- Gov. Raymond P. Shafer of Pennsylvania labeled as a hoax today the report that six college students were blinded by the sun while they were under the influence of LSD.
Citing a "potential health hazard," the Board of Health announced yesterday it would outlaw the installation of septic tank systems in the city at the end of the year.

COLLINS, Miss., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Samuel Holloway Bowers Jr. of Laurel, Miss., imperial wizard of the White Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, was cleared last night by a biracial jury of a charge of illegally possessing a submachine gun.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The International Brotherhood of Teamsters has agreed to stop spending its money to defend officers against allegations of personal wrongdoing or misuse of union funds.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Senate leisurely settled down to legislative business today and immediately became mired in what promised to be a protracted debate on civil rights.
The developer of the turbine car that nearly won last year's Indianapolis 500 went to court yesterday in an effort to restrain the United States Auto Club from restraining his controversial machines.

Toffenetti's restaurant, a Times Square landmark and gustatory haven for millions of tourists since it was opened in 1940, has been bought by real estate investors who plan to buy adjoining property to make way for a new skyscraper.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Johnson Administration indicated today it would welcome an immediate assurance from the steel industry and the United Steelworkers union that there would be no steel strike this year, as an aid to the nation's balance of payments.

TRENTON, Jan. 18 -- The Appellate Division of Superior Court ruled today that defendants receiving prison sentences for violation of probation were entitled to legal counsel. The court said that its ruling applied retroactively to any prisoner who did not have a lawyer at the time of sentencing.
GAINESVILLE, Fla., Jan. 18 (UPI) -- A Circuit Court judge was ordered by a Federal judge today to set a hearing for two civil rights workers who had been jailed for contempt of court.

BEDFORD, N. H., Jan. 18 -- New Hampshire's little known program of cooperation between its highway and fish and game departments drew praise this week at the Northeast Fish and Wildlife Conference at the Sheraton-Wayfarer Motor Inn.
MOSCOW -- Siberia, a vast treasure house of oil, coal, timber and minerals, is on the verge of opening its doors to the Japanese for joint development -- if the price is right.

The American Stock Exchange, which has been setting volume records every trading day since last Friday, did it again yesterday as turnover soared above the 10-million mark for the first time in the exchange's history.

HONG KONG -- One of the most picturesque aspects of Hong Kong is coming to an end. The boat people are gradually coming ashore. If the swarms of men, women and children now living aboard thousands of junks and sampans keep moving ashore at the present rate, the anchorages of Hong Kong will, in a decade or so, be installed on land.
MOSCOW, Jan. 18 -- The Soviet Government acted tonight to put a tight lid on unofficial sources of information about last week's trial of four persons convicted of anti-Soviet activity.
Late buying caused a reversal on the London Stock Exchange yesterday and the list closed on a firm note.

" Finland has never been so secure as she is now," President Urho Kaleva Kekkonen declared last month on the fiftieth anniversary of his country's independence. A solid majority of Finnish voters obviously agrees, and has just elected Mr. Kekkonen to his third six-year term as chief of state.

DAYTON, Tex., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Pfc. Roger D. Anderson, visiting his mother and stepfather here, said today that his rescue had come after guerrillas had held him prisoner for 10 days, moving him mostly at night.
COLOMBO, Ceylon -- Ceylon is conducting a highspeed drive toward private enterprise in a move to cut exports by producing more goods at home.

DAYTON, Tex., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Pfc. Roger D. Anderson, visiting his mother and stepfather here, said today that his rescue had come after guerrillas had held him prisoner for 10 days, moving him mostly at night.
COLOMBO, Ceylon -- Ceylon is conducting a highspeed drive toward private enterprise in a move to cut exports by producing more goods at home.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The president of the World Bank announced tonight that he "expected agreement" among the rich countries on a new formula for replenishing the bank's funds for "soft" loans to the less-developed countries.

GENEVA, Jan. 18 -- The United States and the Soviet Union submitted the complete draft of a treaty to ban the spread of nuclear weapons to the United Nations disarmament conference here this afternoon.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 18 (UPI) -- The president of the three-million member Lutheran Church in America has sent a message to the 7,300 pastors of his denomination urging them to help awaken Americans to "a racial emergency of gigantic proportions."
Three alumni of the Yale School of Music appeared in Carnegie Recital Hall last night to present a program of Italian and German Baroque music.

AT a time when seemingly boundless sums of money and energy are being expended to conquer outer space, the developing nations of Asia are waging their own space race -- namely, to house and feed their burgeoning numbers in an area that barely provides subsistence levels of livelihood for many of its present inhabitants.
LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The Government's program to reduce Britain's world role and cut domestic spending won formal approval from the House of Commons tonight after a two-day debate.
KARACHI, Pakistan -- The world's largest irrigation network -- the $2-billion Indus Basin project -- will take a long stride forward when work starts in May on the $850-million Tarbela Dam.

The chairman of the Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said yesterday that he was considering seeking Government action against companies here that discriminate against Negroes and Puerto Ricans.

BAMAKO, Mali, Jan. 17 -- Thirty-six American doctors and administrators and 1,100 West African doctors, administrators and technicians are laboring on a project to immunize some 110 million people in 19 countries against smallpox and measles by the middle of 1971.
BANGKOK, Thailand -- Whenever non - Communist Asian statesmen get together, the subject of "regional economic cooperation" comes up, and the press sometimes even mentions a "common market."

New York City's new contract with the Rand Corporation will bring modern management principles into operation in four important sectors of the city's business. It will permit the introduction of program budgeting in the Police Department, the Fire Department and in two new super agencies, the Health Services Administration and the Housing and Development Administration.
SINGAPORE -- A scarcity of jobs for a fast-growing labor force is posing a major problem for Singapore's expanding economy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Revenue freight traffic generated by carloadings on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Jan. 13 were both below the volume in the corresponding 1967 week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Republican Congressional leaders asked President Johnson today "to make known to the American people the background and political character of British writer and cameraman Felix Greene."

CONCORD, N. H., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Two more New Hampshire Republicans filed today as candidates for national convention delegate favorable to Governor Rockefeller of New York for President, raising the total to five.
Dr. Harold S. Diehl was honored here last night on his retirement as senior medical officer of the American Cancer Society.
The New York Daily News announced last night it had abandoned plans to publish an afternoon newspaper here.
SYDNEY, Australia -- Australia has had so many mineral discoveries in the last five years that economists are still assessing the changes they will make in the country's economy.
General Foods is moving its Instant Maxwell House Coffee from Benton Bowles, where it has been since its introduction in 1950, to Ogilvy Mather, which does the regular Maxwell House advertising.

FOR those without food, statistics are poor substitutes for a wellfilled rice bowl, but the data now on hand suggest that, at least for the coming months, Asians on the whole will suffer fewer hunger pangs than in the last few years.

SANTA MARIA DEL ROSARIO, Cuba, Jan. 17 -- Cuba's small private farmers, many of them freed from rent payments by the Castro revolution, are coming increasingly under state control in the interest of higher productivity.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Jan. 18 (AP) -- A cloudburst struck San Antonio today, sweeping three and possibly five persons to their deaths. Hundreds of miles to the northwest, stiff winds whipped heavy snows into four-to-five-foot drifts.

Irving Stone, the author, and Jean Stone, his wife, editor and business manager, have set up two prizes for the work of other authors. Doubleday Co. announced yesterday that it would administer the Stones's $1,000 annual awards for the best biographical and historical novels.
Most commodities futures declined yesterday in quiet trading but a few showed some advances.
A leading mutual fund announced yesterday that it planned to seek a new manager following action by the Securities and Exchange Commission against the head of the concern that had managed the fund.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Administration said today that it would seek to channel $300-million to $400-million more in the next fiscal year into its new program to enlist business aid in reducing hard-core unemployment.
ROME, Jan. 18 -- There were lots of laughs in the Italian haute-couture collections for spring-summer shown here this week, but the trouble was that no one meant to be that funny.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 -- Gov. Ronald Reagan spoke with whimsical scorn today of President Johnson's State of the Union Message, accusing him both of lacking direction and of lifting "fundamentally Republican ideas."
BELGRADE, Jan. 19 -- The Serbian Communist party replaced its ailing leader, Radivoje Radosavljevic, today with Petar Stambolic, a former Premier of Yugoslavia.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 19 -Official sources said here today that 12 North Vietnamese battalions were pursuing 2,000 Laotian Government soldiers fleeing from Namhac in what appears to be degenerating into a rout.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Clark McAdams Clifford, who was selected today to be Secretary of Defense, was first called to the White House in 1946 as a naval aide; he has not been out of its shadow since. Three Democratic Presidents have been summoning him there since he planted his law firm, with one of the most lucrative practices in town, a block and a half away.

MEGAN TERRY, whose antiwar musical, "Viet Rock," was a success scandal of the 1966 theatrical season, continues to present her audience with a critical dilemma. Miss Terry is obviously capable of writing draamtically, even compell ingly at times, but whether the drama is really her proper metier is still open to question.

The Supreme Court has agreed to rule on the constitutionality of efforts by the states to bar new residents from public welfare. The Court's decision on that issue could provide a foundation for acceptance by the Federal Government of its proper responsibility for establishing national welfare standards.
Thirty-three United State Representatives have protested plans to show on television a film made in North Vietnam because they believe it serves as "enemy propaganda."
A five-man State Supreme Court appeals panel has upheld a lower court ruling that ended the 16-day Brooklyn waterfront strike in November.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Defense sources discounted today reports that the Soviet Union had supplied Hanoi with a surface-to-surface missile that could threaten United States ships patrolling the North Vietnamese coast.

ABOARD U.S.S. Kittyhawk, off North Vietnam, Jan. 14 -- On that chilly morning in August, 1964, Comdr. Henry Urban Jr. was sitting in the ward room, starting breakfast, when a duty officer walked over and whispered: "Start planning an attack on Vinh."

The bells of tragedy ring again for Sicily, that beautiful but ill-fated island that has been plagued by natural and human disasters for centuries. Earth tremors have destroyed a half-dozen hill towns between Palermo and Trapani, with possibly two hundred dead and tens of thousands homeless. As if this were not enough, families in tent shelters have now been washed out by violent storms.

LISBON, Jan. 19 -- The police arrested today Urbano Tavares Rodrigues, a prominent Portuguese novelist and newspaper columnist. He was the third leading figure of the Social Democratic opposition to be arrested in recent weeks. Francisco Sousa Tavares, a liberal Catholic leader, was taken into custody yesterday and Mario Soares, leader of the Socialists, has been held by the police since Dec. 13.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Senator John L. McClellan said today that it would be four or five years before president Johnson's safe streets bill would be of any substantial help in halting rising crime and lawlessness.
TRENTON, Jan. 19 -- Dr. Virgil W. Gillenwater announced his resignation today as president of Trenton State College amid a continuing struggle for control of public higher education in New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -President Johnson announced today that he had chosen Clark M. Clifford, his friend and an intimate adviser to three Democratic Presidents, to succeed Robert S. McNamara as Secretary of Defense.

STONY BROOK, L. I., Jan. 19 -- Reliance on one or more rehabilitated drug addicts to gain students' confidence will be a major part of the new narcotics control program here at the State University Center.
The Sun Oil Company of Philadelphia and the Sunray DX Oil Company, Tulsa, Okla., agreed in principle to a merger yesterday involving an exchange of stock valued at more than $763-million.

" La Guerre Est Finie," Alain Resnais's French drama about an aging Spanish revolutionist was chosen last night winner of the Joseph Burstyn award, the prize given annually to the best foreign-language film of the year by the Independent Film Importers and Distributors of America.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) -- The Army acknowledged today that a colonel here solicited free liquor from Washington area distributors, in violation of regulations, for a Valentine's Day ball.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -The Department of Transportation has been given the primary authority and responsibility for conducting the exhaustive investigation of automobile insurance that President Johnson proposed in his State of the Union Message.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Jan. 13 -- In the old sultan's palace in Zanzibar, behind massive, ornately carved, brass-studded doors, an African policeman sat alone in a cavernous reception hall that was empty except for his battered desk and a half-consumed bottle of Snowflake Beer from China. He wiped his brow in the moist pitiless heat and tried to answer questions.

Miss Tammy Lee Grimes, who was once described as "the most picturesque young lady ever to enroll at Beaver Country Day School" (Chestnut Hill, Mass.), is now giving poetry recitals twice nightly at the Plaza Hotel.
DETROIT, Jan. 19, (AP) -Labor problems and inclement weather trimmed auto production this week, Automotive News said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -Federal financial assistance to collegese will be reduced sharply, but financial aid to primary and secondary schools in poverty areas will not be cut at all, under the budget-reducing program that has been adopted by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

Several city commissioners have been called to appear before the New York County grand jury in District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's expanding investigation of the alleged kickback scandals involving former Water Commissioner James L. Marcus.
LAS VEGAS, Jan. 19 -- The ancient game of backgammon has attracted 128 competitors here for a four-day world championship tournament at the Sands Hotel.

BOSTON, Jan. 19 -- The last time the New York Knickerbockers beat the Boston Celtics here in a regular season National Basketball Association game was on Dec. 22, 1962. That was 24 games ago. The Knicks are still seeking a way to stop that streak.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 19 -- The Soviet Union and Columbia signed a formal agreement here today for resumption of diplomatic relations after a 20-year lapse.
The stock market closed the week on a downward note yesterday.
The North American Rockwell Corporation and its consolidated subsidiaries reported a decline in earnings yesterday for the first fiscal quarter ended Dec. 31.
In an editorial on Jan. 4 The Times urged people not to hoard tokens, stating that the next fare rise, if it comes, will be to a quarter and turnstiles can easily be adapted to take that coin.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Treasury Department said today it would consolidate 16 laboratories of the Internal Revenue Service and Customs Bureau into seven locations -- Philadelphia, Cincinnati, San Francisco, New York, Boston, Baltimore and New Orleans.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Jan. 20 -- The Vietcong attacked two United States headquarters last night and this morning with rockets and mortars.
AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 19 -- Two major candidates got into the Democratic primary race for Governor today, making a total of five who seek the job that Gov. John B. Connally Jr. is leaving open.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19 AP) -- Eartha Kitt said today when asked if she would do it again, "Yes, I would."

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 19 -- The national space agency has submitted a detailed accounting of its efforts to improve the safety of the Apollo spacecraft since the fire that killed three astronauts a year ago.
Brig. Gen. Elias Wessin y Wessin, once the most powerful military leader in the Dominican Republic, said here yesterday that he would seek the presidency of his country.
PARIS, Jan. 19 -- The gold boom has subsided for the moment, but the art market is more bullish than ever, according to dealers here.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 19 -- Alabama's chief welfare officer said today that his agency had signed a new qualified agreement with the Department of Health, Education and Welfare to comply with the nondiscrimination provisions of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.
NASSAU, the Bahamas, Jan. 19 -- Total and immediate independence from Britain was demanded by a Government minister during a debate yesterday on constitutional reform in the Bahamas Assembly.

Sonata recitals where two players think as one in matters of tone, taste and temperament are as agreeable as they are rare. It was, therefore, a pleasure to hear just such a concert given at the Metropolitan Museum last night by the cellist Zara Nelsova and her pianist-husband, Grant Johannesen.

HOUSTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) -Lew Alcindor of the University of California, Los Angeles, received permission from eye doctors today to play tomorrow night when the top-ranked Bruins meet the second-ranked University of Houston Cougars.

KANSAS CITY, Jan. 19 (UPI) -- Jerry Proctor, of the University of Redlands, Calif., set an National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics indoor and Municipal Auditorium long-jump record tonight with a leap of 25 feet 2 inches in the opening trials of the third annual N.A.I.A. track and field classic.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Government canceled today certification of capsules of the antibiotic drug chloramphenicol made by nine companies -- but allowed two other concerns to continue distributing theirs.
HONG KONG, Jan. 19 -- After subsiding somewhat in late 1967, confusion and disorder are on the upswing again in Communist China.
High pay is not the way to attract the brightest college graduates, the National Industrial Conference Board's session on "Managing the New Work Force" was told yesterday.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 19 -- The agreement to renew diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union does not come as a surprise to the public here though the timing was a well-guarded secret. President Carlos Lleras Restrepo has consistently advocated diplomatic relations with Eastern European countries as a means of expanding Colombian foreign trade.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The three branches of American Judaism called on the Supreme Court today to ban housing discrimination and thereby alleviate "the concomitant anguish and despair in the Negro ghettos."

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Jan. 19 (Reuters) -- One of the world's toughest auto events -- the Monte Carlo Rally -- got under way tonight as cars were reported on their way here from Greece, France and Norway.
Damascus, the 1967,Horse of the Year, looms as a 1-5 favorite to win the $50,000 added San Fernando Stakes at Santa Anita today, according to the Associated Press.

IN the portion of the new exhibitions that fell to this reviewer this week, the museums were much more satisfying than the galleries. Asia House, at 112 East 64th Street, has installed 117 pieces of Chinese art selected from several thousand in the Avery Brundage Collection.
A 31-year-old actor was fined $3,545 in Manhattan Traffic Court yesterday for 141 unanswered traffic summonses.

The top three executives of Lord Taylor, New York, are being advanced to higher posts, effective Feb. 1, in a realignment of management approved by the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, the parent concern. Lord Taylor is Associated's largest store division.
The General Electric Company has followed the lead of the Westinghouse Electric Company in setting maximum prices for steam-turbine generators.

PLAYERS of considerable experience do not always give enough thought to the situation when a contract seems very likely to succeed and there is a question of additional safety. South had an unusual discarding problem on the diagramed deal, and the reader should test his technical skill by covering the East-West hands.
NAPA, Calif., Jan. 19 -- A helicopter was called into service in the predawn hours today so that the $125,000 Kaiser international open golf tourney could be resumed early.

Giant pink balloons emblazoned in dark red with the number 55 were hung over the stage last night in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom, where the Yorkville Community Association marked its 55th anniversary at the annual benefit ball.

Regine Crespin will assume the role of Brunnhilde in Wagner's "Die Walkure" for the first time with the Metropolitan Opera on Feb. 21, in the 23d week of the company's season. John Macurdy will appear as Hunding for the first time with the company, and in the same performance Leonie Rysanek will sing the part of the Sieglinde for the first time this season.

BERLIN, Jan. 19 -- Mayor Klaus Schutz said here today that he expected a protracted period of discussions between the Russians and the West Germans following the Kremlin's new approach to seek to redefine the status of West Berlin.

The strong opposition that has emerged among Ohio Democrats to the renomination of veteran Senator Frank Lausche is another instance of the steady drift toward ideological coherence in the nation's majority party. As a result of a trend that has been under way for thirty years, Senator Lausche is the only conservative Democrat in the Senate from a state outside the Deep South.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (Reuters) -- The State Departmerit said today the United States was investigating tile alleged incursion of American and South Vietnamese troops into Cambodia.
HONG KONG, Jan. 19 (UPI) -- Riot squads and 300 Communists battled today outside police station on the Hong Kong waterfront in the worst outbreak of violence in the Crown Colony in weeks.

Good taste and intelligence were omnipresent in the recital given by Gaelyne Gabora in Carnegie Recital Hall last night. The Canadian soprano, making her New York debut, had planned a choice program that included Elizabethan songs, lieder by Schubert and Richard Strauss and two notable song cycles, Mussorgsky's "The Nursery" and Bartok's "Village Scenes."
THOSE computer leasing stocks that have caught the imagination of traders and have just never stopped going up, could be in for some unwelcome competition -- or so a specialist in leasing believes.
The United States Department of Labor and the New York State Department of Banking are investigating a service fee that the National Maritime Union is charging retired seamen receiving pensions.

BONN, Jan. 19 -- Britain's Foreign Secretary, George Brown, gave his approval today to plans by the West German Government to explore in Paris the possibility that France may agree to some formula for British participation in the Common Market.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Earl McCullouch of the University of Southern California tied the meet and Sports Arena record of 7 seconds flat tonight in the 60-yard high hurdles at the Los Angeles invitation track meet.

HOT CREEK VALLEY, Nev., Jan. 19 (AP) -- An underground nuclear explosion with the force of nearly a million tons of TNT -- perhaps the mightiest yet in this country -- swayed buildings hundreds of miles away today after being set off deep under a lonely desert valley.
Prices of metals, both basic and precious, advanced yesterday on the commodities futures markets.
BETHPAGE, L.I., Jan, 19 -- Three children died in an early morning fire here after flames and smoke prevented their mother from reaching them.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Los Angeles exploded for four goals in the second period and outplayed the Rangers the rest of the way to post a 5-2 victory tonight in a National Hockey League game.

A 27-year-old secretary to an official of the New York Civil Liberties Union and an actor friend were picked up in the East Village early yesterday and charged with possession of hashish, marijuana and amphetamine pills.

SASEBO, Japan, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The nuclear-powered United States aircraft carrier Enterprise arrived today for a visit that Japanese leftist students have protested with three days of rioting and bloodshed. But her crewmen went ashore on liberty unmolested.

PALERMO, Sicily, Jan. 19 -- Rain, hail and cold winds turned the tent camps and improvised shelters of some 80,000 Sicilian earthquake refugees into quagmires today and brought urgent warnings of possible epidemics.
BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 19 -- Charles J. Hitch, president of the University of California since Jan. 1, experienced the oral displeasure of several members of the Board of Regents today.

YONKERS, Jan. 19 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy outlined today an anticrime program calling for expanded intelligence networks, higher police salaries and closer ties between the police and communities.
The Port of New York Authority confirmed yesterday that it had authorized the Soviet airline, Aeroflot, to operate in and out of Kennedy International Airport.

Four men with Afro-style haircuts and wearing Black Muslim crescent symbols on gold chains knocked down the principal and two officials of Brooklyn Junior High School 117 yesterday in a fight over whether pupils had been locked out in last week's freezing weather.

MRS. WANDA METTERMAN is a casework supervisor in Brooklyn for the New York City Department of Social Services. Her yearly income is "well into five figures." She holds a bachelor's degree in Spanish from Brooklyn College, and is working on her master's degree in social work.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 19 (Agence France-Presse) -- Political observers here regard the remarks made in Paris on Tuesday by Mai Van Bo, the North Vietnamese chief representative in Western Europe, as a more restrictive stand on the question of peace talks with the United States.

Maharishi Mahesh Yogi sat cross-legged on a deerskin, caressing a wilting flower, at a news conference yesterday and discussed sharing his teachings on transcendental meditation with a suffering world.

Nelson Rockefeller, a millionaire, is considering legislation that might nip out yet another penny from each dollar bet at the race track. Avery Brundage, a millionaire, is talking very tough about the professionalism inherent in college athletic scholarships. And Andy Granatelli, a millionaire, is pressing litigation that may someday make your car obsolete,

" ANIMATIONS: ZAGREB", a series of programs being shown this weekend at the Museum of Modern Art, is a selection of cartoons from the work of Yugoslav animators over the last 10 years. It uses a technique the Zagreb school calls "reduced animation" -- a minimal number of frames drawn to suggest each movement.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -A 10-year plan to make the nation's airways safer and its airports less crowded will be handed to Congress by April 1, high Administration sources said today.
A motor lifeboat from the Coast Guard cutter Absecon yesterday rescued the 16-man crew of the foundering Dutch freighter Ocean Sprinter. The rescue took place 1,300 miles east of here.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Jan. 19 (UPI) -- Mike Kasperak, the heart transplant patient, survived his second major operation Within 24 hours today. His condition was "extremely critical."

PARIS, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Jean Chamant, French Minister of Transport, said today that delay in delivery of two Olympus engines had forced change in the target date for the firs flight of the French-British supersonic Concorde transport plane.

PRAGUE, Jan. 9 -- Czechoslovak party leaders were so anonymous in the past that when in December rumors began circulating that Alexander Dubcek was leading the fight that ousted the Communist party leader, Antonin Novotny, few Czechoslovaks even knew what Mr. Dubcek looked like.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Personal income and new orders for durable goods ended 1967 on a strong note, rounding out a series of largely bullish economic indicators for December, the Commerce Department reported today.
For the first time, a Roman Catholic priest will preach at St. Thomas Episcopal Church. He is Msgr. Austin B. Vaughan, a seminary professor.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Board of Higher Education adopted today a new admissions policy for New Jersey's six state colleges. It will become effective with the 1969 fall semester.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Maryland Racing Commission reversed a previous decision, today and said Kathy Kusner would get a tryout in her bid to be licensed as a jockey.

DOBBS FERRY, N. Y., Jan. 19 -- Three 17-year-old girls at the Masters School, a fashionable preparatory school here for girls, were arrested last night and charged with the "possession of a dangerous drug."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Administration officials, in their exultation over the agreement with Moscow on a treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons, are presenting this picture of how a compromise was reached on the critical clause involving safeguards: that the Soviet Union was an obstructionist that relented in the face of a statesmanlike, flexible position assumed by Wash ington.
ATLANTA, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Deaths from influenza and pneumonia were nearly double the expected number last week, the National Communicable Disease Center reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson said today she was sorry that the constructive things discussed at a White House luncheon panel on crime in the streets were not heard, "only the shrill voice of anger and discord."
In naming Clark Clifford to succeed Robert McNamara as Secretary of Defense, President Johnson has replaced a brilliant doubter with a competent confidant.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The initial operational deployment of the most advanced American intercontinental ballistic missile has been postponed for nearly a year because of the cost of the Vietnam war and a desire to improve the missile's reliability, Defense Department officials said today.

GALLUP, N.M., Jan. 19 (AP) -- A decision on proposed restrictions on information about criminal trials should be delayed at least a year by leaders of the American Bar Association, a spokesman for the American Society of Newspaper Editors said today.
LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Groups of British teachers marched in and out of a hotel room here this week to be interviewed by an American team trying to attract them to California.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Representative William F. Ryan urged Senator Kennedy today to seek the Democratic nomination for President as part of "a strategy to find new leadership in 1968."

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- A controversy over the proper date for the observance of Epiphany led to violence today in the rectory of St. Nicholas Ukrainian Catholic Cathedral, the largest of five Greek rite churches in Chicago in communion with the Holy See.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -The Administration intends to ask Congress to vote the 10 per cent surcharge on individual income taxes to be effective April 1 and to make the 10 per cent surcharge on corporate income taxes retroactive to Jan. 1.

The Eastern Lawn Tennis Association will take a position today on the rebellion of the British Lawn Tennis Association in voting to conduct Wimbledon as an open tournament, in defiance of the International Lawn Tennis Federation, and to end all distinction between amateurs and professionals.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 19 -- The Government said today that United States and South Vietnamese forces intruded 200 yards into Cambodia at 5 A.M. yesterday, killing three Cambodians and wounding two.

Trans World Airlines said yesterday that it would offer a 50 per cent discount on its domestic flights this summer to all residents of countries outside North and Central America and the Caribbean area.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- A mechanical engineer has combined art and mathematics in a changeable wall decoration. The changes are made by the scientific rear rangement of the verticle panels that form the picture.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -Senator George D. Aiken accused the Johnson Administration today of resorting to "military strength" in Vietnam to camouflage its "political ineptitude."

ATHENS, Jan. 19 -- Greece's military regime today rearrested Christos Lambrakis, owner of five Athens publications, 26 days after having released him from exile under a Christmas amnesty.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 19 (AP) -- Surveyor 7 tried to photograph laser beams fired at the moon from five points on earth today in a test for a planned Apollo experiment.
The nation's leading chain stores broke most existing sales records in December and in 1967, according to a survey completed yesterday by The New York Times.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The savings and loan industry enjoyed a 192.4 per cent savings gain in 1967 from the depressed level of 1966 despite the smallest December increase in six years, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

Eartha Kitt's rude confrontation with the First Lady at a White House luncheon the other day did not add significantly to the national dialogue on juvenile delinquency, the war, taxes, poverty or race -- although she touched on all of these subjects, directly or by implication, in her biting comments on crime in the streets and its causes.

LOUVAIN, Belgium, Jan. 19 -- After four days of riots between French-speaking and Flemish-speaking students, Louvain University, the largest Roman Catholic university in the world, is in a state of siege.
Wall Street gave a resounding "amen" yesterday to plans of the nation's leading securities markets to shorten trading hours in a move to cut the mounting backlog of paperwork in brokerage offices.

MUSCATINE, Iowa, Jan. 16 -- The student body of Muscatine Community Collge wants to go to Vietnam -- not to fight, not to protest, not to negotiate, but just to sit around and talk with the troops. Troubled by what they consider the erroneous image of American college students that is presented to the world by campus protests, the student council drafted a plan called Expedition Uplift.

Approval of the Pennsylvania - New York Central merger by the Supreme Court marks the beginning of a new era in rail transportation. H. -- In days gone by, winter-carnival time evoked images of horse-drawn sleigh rides, skating on frozen ponds, toasting marshmallows over pine-scented fires and coasting downhill on makeshift bobleds. WALL STREET'S increasing thirst for answers to a host of gnawing economic questions went unquenched last week. Since the start of the new year investors had been anticipating the annual State of the Union message. But what was to have been an oasis of information and new policies turned out to be a mirage.

WASHINGTON -- In the aftermath of President Johnson's drastic New Year's Day package of measures to improve the balance of international payments a number of Americans, and foreigners, too. have begun to wonder whether the world might be heading toward a renewal of economic nationalism, with each nation taking measures to protect itself at the expense of all the others.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 20 -- The Riverside Yacht Club Frostbite skippers defeated Rocky Point Club, 4 races to 1, off Rocky Point today for Riverside's third inter-fleet team victory of the season in three matches.

HOUSTON, Jan. 20 -- Houston's inspired Cougars, led by Elvin Hayes, toppled the University of California, Los Angeles, 71-69, tonight and ended the Bruins' myth of invincibility in college basketball.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Construction of a Federal flood control dam in the scenic Red River Gorge of Eastern Kentucky, a project bitterly opposed by conservationists, has been delayed "indefinitely" by budgetry and planning difficulties, the Army Corps of Engineers said today.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 20 -- Considering the trouble to which revivers of forgotten operas sometimes go to find viable materials, it seems rather surprising to report that the first American performance of a reputable opera by Mozart was given at Peabody Concert Hall last night by the Chamber Opera Society of Baltimore.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Minnesota scored victories over Ohio State and Bemidji (Minn.) State today, but the Buckeyes bounced back to defeat Bemidji in a three-team gymnastics meet.
The New Election Service has announced that it will extend its vote tabulation operation to this year's Presidential primary elections.

Carl A. Benscoter, executive vice president of Mohawk Airlines, has resigned his post to become president and chief executive officer of Air California. Mr. Benscoter, who joined Mohawk as a pilot in 1946, will assume his new position Feb. 1. He succeeds J. Kenneth Hull, who has retired. Air California operates flights between Orange County, San Francisco. San Jose and Oakland, Calif.

THIS week television gets lucky. Kim Stanley hasn't been on the Broadway stage since "The Three Sisters" four years ago and she hasn't been seen in a movie since "Seance on a Wet Afternoon" three years ago. But Friday night at 8:30 she will be on NBC -- and that's an event. Miss Stanley plays a wife with a secret in "Flesh and Blood," an original two-hour drama by William Hanley.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Additional figures made available by Government officials today on the President's budget for the fiscal year 1969 raised the possibility that the new budget might, after all, meet the economy requirements set forth by Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.
The Military Airlift Command set records in all airlift categories last year as it stepped up its operations in Southeast Asia.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- The former world amateur champion, John Newcombe, made an unimpressive entry in the professional tennis ranks today when he struggled to a 74-72 VASSS victory over South Africa's Cliff Drysdale.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., Jan. 20 -- James Garner, who played one of the principal roles in the movie "Grand Prix," said today he was organizing a racing team to compete in this year's endurance races at Daytona Beach and Sebring, Fla., and Le Mans, France.

The uses of sand are many and historical -- in hourglasses, in mortar and cement, in making glass and for battening bathing beaches. The tourist also is a prime user of sand, as a means to an end while holidaying. A few of the many pleasurable uses of sand are shown in these photographs taken at Miami Beach.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Rev. Richard F. Ryan, president of Regis College in Denver, was appointed today to the newly created post of assistant to the Very Rev. John P. Raynor, president of Marquette University. Father Ryan, 55 years old, will be succeeded by the Very Rev. Louis G. Mattione, former assistant dean of the College of Liberal Arts at Marquette.

HOUSTON, Jan. 20 -- Richard M. Nixon leap-frogged from one major Texas city to another today, assessing his political strength in this key Southern state. He could not have been displeased by what he saw and heard.

TOKYO,, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- The Japan Boxing Commission said today it had been informed by the World Boxing Association that Jesus Pimentel of Mexico had lost his chance to challenge Fighting Harada, the world bantamweight champion, for the title. The match had been scheduled for Feb. 27 here. The W.B.A. said Pimentel had not come to terms on a contract.

NORTH HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 20 -- Indiana's Big Ten champions dominate the list of college swimming's best performances of the season. The weekly list was released today by Swimming World Magazine which compiles the performances for the College Swimming Coaches Association.

OTTAWA, Jan. 20 -- The eight candidates who are sharply contesting for the post of party leader and Prime Minister of Canada offer Liberals a broad spectrum of political thought and a range of ages and personalities.
The determination of a neighborhood group on the Lower East Side has been credited with saving a widely praised poverty program that had wallowed in administrative processes for six months.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- A new Federal-private program to provide health and housing facilities for the urban poor, with emphasis on the elderly, was announced today at the White House.

The Johnson Administration has persistently charged Vietnam critics with failure to put forward realistic alternatives to its policies in Southeast Asia. This charge was never fair nor wholly true. It is even less true today.

The tightening of the economic reins by Britain and the United States in the opening days of 1968 has caused a great deal of consternation on the stock markets of the world and some reversals of price trends.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Attorney General Ramsey Clark said today that the nation must "plan for the worst and hope for the best" in order to prevent widespread rioting in the cities this summer.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Doug Brittelle, who scored 39 points, led Rutgers tonight to a 74-68 victory over Boston University. Rutgers went ahead for good in the hard-fought contest on two foul shots by Dick Stewart with 3:04 minutes left to play.

A Canadian correspondent who worked in Moscow in recent years writes in a United States anti-Zionist magazine that he found "very little of what I would call discrimination or official anti-Semitism, and nothing that could even loosely be termed persecution" of Jews in the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The nation's capital, a city acquiring a reputation for crime-ridden streets, is beginning an uncertain struggle to cure itself of lawlessness.

MONTE CARLO, Jan. 20 -- An Italian driver, Luciano Lombardini, was killed and his teammate, Sandro Munari, was seriously injured today when their Lancia-Fulvia sideswiped a passenger car in the 37th Monte Carlo Rally.
The United States is urged in the Jan. 27 issue of the Jesuit weekly America to pause in bombing of North Vietnam unilaterally and unconditionally.

A COLORFUL farm panorama will form the basis for a 6-cent postage stamp to be issued February 12. The stamp will commemorate the 150th anniversary of Illinois statehood. It will have its first-day sale at Shawneetown, the oldest continuous post office in that state.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20 -- (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Times indoor track meet will be held at the Forum at Inglewood, on Feb. 10. Ron Clarke and Kerry O'Brien, Australian distance runners, are scheduled to compete.

LANNING ROPER, landscape designer from London, will present an illustrated lecture in the auditorium of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, Tuesday at 8 P.M. There is no admission charge. Mr. Roper will discuss the Winston Churchill and Sackville West Gardens, and other gardens of the National Trust on which he is presently working. The botanic garden parking area will be open for the evening, without charge.

The office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, working in secrecy yesterday, prepared a roster of people in business and public office who will be called before the grand jury of questioned in the scandals growing out of alleged kickbacks involving former Water Commissioner James L. Marcus.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 20 -- Gov. Ronald Reagan finished up tonight the bulk of his planned cross-country speechmaking before the Republican National Convention.
URBANA, Ill., Jan. 20 -- Coal produced in Illinois increased in 1967, but the value of all minerals produced in the state decreased slightly from 1966 levels.

CHRISTIANSTED, St. Croix, V. I. -- The future of the performing arts in the United States Virgin Islands has brightened considerably with the opening of Island Center, a new type of theater structure about five miles west of here.

MIAMI, Jan. 18 -- His name is Fernando Maria Orbea Alcibarareichuluaga but the fans simply call him Orbea. Until a ball hard as a rock struck his temple a year ago, he was considered the world's best jai-alai player.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 20 (UPI) -- Ronald McAnally, a trainer, was suspended today by Board of Stewards at Santa Anita when a laboratory test revealed that one of his horses, Luz Del Sol, showed traces of a drug after the filly won the sixth race last Wednesday.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 20 -- Communist China appears to be extending its influence in Singapore through department stores.
MOSCOW, Jan. 20 (UPI) -The Soviet Union launched today the 200th satellite in its Cosmos program. The Cosmos program, begun five years ago, has included a number of different types of space shots.

ABOARD U.S.S. KITTY HAWK, Off North Vietnam, Jan. 14 -- At night, the hookmen stand on the deck and watch the faint glow in the murky sky -- the glow of a jet fighter that approaches suddenly and hits the deck in a burst of sparks and jolts to a halt.
The tax-exempt bond market -- the most unregulated part of the securities markets -- may come under increased supervision in the year ahead.

WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 20 -Vicar Hanover went the way of all favorites so far in the Early Bird Pacing Series as Don MacFarlane's Little Brown Jug winner of 1964 wound up third in the third division of the preliminaries tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

Ken Sakraido of Manpower, Inc., has been elected president of the Association of Temporary Personnel Contractors. WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- One year from today Lyndon Johnson will ride down Pennsylvania Avenue to the White House by himself or with his successor, and he is now obviously writing the scenario and picking a new cast of characters for the election of 1968. The appointment of Clark Clifford as Secretary of Defense is only the latest evidence of the point.

HOUSTON, Jan. 20 -- A planned "friendship mission to the Arab world" by the American Arab Society has been postponed after a meeting with Arab ambassadors to the United States.

Howard Haring, a handwriting expert in New York, has concluded that President Heinrich Lubke of West Germany built concentration camps under the Nazis. KNOKKE-LE-ZOUTE, Belgium. EVERY four years, an exotic, semi-surrealist ritual occurs between Christmas and New Year's at this posh North Sea resort: The International Experimental Film Festival, played out against a da-daist backdrop of fog-bound ocean, bourgeois Belgian vacationers with children and dogs, and a conglomeration of European hippies, radical students, famous film directors, critics, assembled to pay homage to the avant-garde film. The mixture, this year, proved even more explosive than usual.

NAPA. Calif., Jan. 20 -- Dave Marr finished in 78th place last Sunday in the Bing Crosby tourney. but today he continued to lead the $125.000 Kaiser international open field. With this third consecutive round in the 60's, Marr brought his 54-hole aggregate to 204 with a 67.
The Pennsylvania Railroad has signed an agreement for a long-term lease of 50 new 3,600-horsepower diesel locomotives from the C.I.T. Leasing Corporation.

He bettered the mark of 27 feet set two years ago by Igor Ter Ovanesyan of the Soviet Union.

South African Airways and UTA, a French carrier, have started a new jet freighter service between Europe and South Africa. The service is operated with DC-8 jet freighters. An airliner leaves Paris every Tuesday evening and arrives in Johannesburg the following morning. Northbound, the plane leaves the South African city in early afternoon and arrives at the French capital early the next morning.

ONE of Florida's principal highways and one of its leading tourist attractions each did a record business last year. The 265-mile Sunshine State Parkway was used by 10,780,000 vehicles in 1967, about 908,000 more than in 1966, and the Cape Kennedy Space Center bus tours were taken by 486,225 persons.

HILLSBORO, N. H. -- The white clapboard, green-shuttered home of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Cart sits amid the customary January snowbanks just off the crest of the main road of this tiny New Hampshire village, next door to the lumber company.

PALERMO, Sicily, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- Another strong tremor shook western Sicily today, causing panic but no damage. The tremor centered in Camporeale, but was felt throughout the area. It was the second of the day and the 57th since last Sunday. Officials said 198 died in last Monday's earthquake. The injured numbered 478.

Three brownstones on West 136th Street in Harlem have been rebuilt into a contemporary-style church for the Beulah Wesleyan Methodist Church, founded in 1913.

THE chance discovery in a Greenwich Village art gallery of what its owner believes to be a new and unique portrait of Abraham Lincoln has precipitated a one-man campaign to establish its authenticity. The man is Leo Stashin, magazine photographer. The portrait is an 1849 daguerreotype for which he paid $28 last February when, he reports, "as I examined it, I wondered whether this could be the real Lincoln."

Walker G. Buckner and George W. Knight, partners in the brokerage firm of Buckner , will head the 1968 Salivation Army Greater New York fund campaign. The two men headed last years campaign which raised $5,059,828.
