SOME players seem to take it as a personal insult if their opponents bid a game with a combined point-count below the usual requirements. They double "in rage," to use a term coined by S. J. Simon, a great English bridge writer, and usually regret it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UPI) -- Seventeen demonstrators protesting the Vietnam war and defending Eartha Kitt's outburst at the White House were ejected from President Johnson's Washington church today. Mr. Johnson was not present.
LONDON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- A week of prayer for Christian unity opened in Britain tonight, with Anglicans, Methodists and Roman Catholics participating in joint services.

TORONTO -- Canada's exports of motor vehicles and parts soared to $1.7-billion in 1967 from $1-billion in 1966. The increase put automotive products in first place in the export table, ahead of wheat and newsprint.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 21 -- American troops wearing helmets and carrying rifles are no longer seen on downtown streets looking for a change from the pressures of patrols and fighting.

Robert Collier's record for the past seven months shows that he has made a substantial contribution to the betterment of the Tompkins Square community. Under his chairmanship the Committee for a Tompkins Square Community Center convinced the city that it should make Christodora House available as a recreation center to this densely populated area.

Paul Bley, a pipe-smoking pianist who describes himself as "an original member of the jazz avant-garde," gave a concert with a trio at Town Hall last night that was intended to place the jazz piano in a different relationship to the brass and drums from what is usually the case.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay -- A "healthy deterioration" of the nation's groggy economy was prescribed by President Jorge Pacheco Areco to cure this lovely land's monetary woes. The cure is planned for this year and next.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Whenever domestic critics suggested in the past that the Johnson Administration might be overlooking some peace signal from North Vietnam, the Government replied that it had reliable ways of checking quickly with Hanoi.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Jan. 21 -- Repercussions from President Johnson's crack-down on the nation's balance-of-payments problem are being felt in this warm, sunny tourist town.

NAPA, Calif., Jan. 21 -- Kermit Zarley, who eats an apple a day, won his first professional golf tournament today by one stroke, taking the Kaiser Inter-ternational open with a 72-hole score of 273. Dave Marr, who had been setting the pace, was second.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Jan. 21 -- Mike Kasperak, this country's first adult to receive a heart transplant, died in Stanford Medical Center here today. He had survived completion of the transplant operation for 14 days and a little more than five hours.

BOGOTA, Colombia -- "The International Monetary Fund often behaves like a doctor who knows only one prescription. Be it dandruff or athlete's foot, their cure is the same -- devaluation. Don't they realize that our problems are vastly different from those in the developed countries?"

FECAMP, France, Jan. 21 -- The Pardon des Terre-Neuvas rite, which for centuries has marked the departure of Norman fishermen for the Grand Banks off Newfoundland, appeared today to have ended forever.

DETROIT, Jan. 21 -- The Chrysler Corporation today reported fourth-quarter net income of $107-million, or $2.32 a share, a record for any quarter. This was up about 61 per cent from the year-earlier $65.8-million, or $1.44 a share.

A close aide to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. has said that the civil rights leader was planning his program for a series of protests this coming spring as "a nonviolent crisis or shock that almost acts like an electric shock on a very sick person."
JERUSALEM, Jan. 21 -- Three of Israel's major political parties merged today to form the closest thing to a majority party the nation has known.

MONTE CARLO, Jan. 21 (UPI) -- A total of 187 drivers of the 200 starters converged on this Monaco city today for the next stage in the Monte Carlo Rally that already has claimed the lives of two persons through fatal accidents.

TORONTO -- The value of trading in stocks listed on Candian exchanges rose 21 per cent to a record $5.1-billion in 1967, according to estimates by the Toronto Stock Exchange. But the volume of trading declined by 11 per cent to 1.5 billion shares.

BOSTON, Jan. 21 (UPI) -- Gerry Cheevers returned as the Boston Bruin's goalie tonight after two weeks on the injured list and shut out the Chicago Black Hawks, 6-0, leading the Bruins into first place in the National Hockey League's East Division. The teams had been tied for the lead.

BOSTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Don Nelson's scoring and rebounding sparked a Boston rally early in the fourth period today as the Celtics broke open a tight game and rolled to a 139-112 National Basketball Association victory over the San Diego Rockets.

The recent release by India of Sheik Mohammed Abdullah, charismatic leader of five million disaffected Kashmiris, reawakens some hope for solution of a dispute that has poisoned relations between India and Pakistan for two decades, seriously compromising the security and development of both countries.
RIO DE JANEIRO -- Brazil, in many ways the most developed of the world's underdeveloped countries, increased her grip on economic progress last year.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 21 -- European companies are taking a more active interest in establishing manufacturing operations in the United States.
MONTREAL, Jan. 21 -- Raphael Lallouz, a 38-year-old banker from Casablanca, is helping to keep Quebec part of Canada.

PALO ALTO, Calif. -- The era of human heart transplants is still far too young for anything resembling a definitive balance of the new promises and perils. Yet at least some of the first items essential for inclusion in any accounting became available here at Stanford University Medical School during the two weeks Dr. Norman E. Shumway and his associates fought for the life of Mike Kasperak.
CARACAS, Venezuela -- Foreign businessmen call it "economic nationalism." Local entrepreneurs say it is merely "second-stage development."
TORONTO -- It was only fitting that 1968 began with a rush of Arctic air that drove the thermometer 60 degrees below zero in northern Ontario and forced some Quebec schools to close.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Jan. 22 -- North Vietnamese troops staged a series of attacks yesterday close to the United States Marine stronghold at Khesanh, near the demilitarized zone and the Laotian border.
VANCOUVER, British Columbia -- As if a serious cost squeeze were not bad enough, the forest products industry also had to cope with a leveling off of demand for pulp, paper and newsprint in 1967.

SANTIAGO, Chile -- During the California gold rush, the produce from this land's fields, orchards and vineyards nourished the 49ers. The voyages of food-laden boats along the Humboldt Current northward to California have been memorialized in Chilean history looks. As late as a generation ago, Chile was an important exporter of food.

The American ORT Federation (Organization for Rehabilitation through Training) yesterday set a goal of $15,109,500 for the support and expansion of ORT's 650 installations and schools in 23 countries, especially Israel.
Two Manhattan realty deals completed in 1967 have won awards for three brokers in the annual contest sponsored by the Real Estate Board of New York for the most ingenious transactions of the year.
THE year 1967 has been a year of unusual contrasts in Canadian assessments of the country's achievements, problems and potentials.

REGENSBURG, West Germany, Jan. 17 -- Officials of this East Bavarian city are finding that urban renewal is a controversial as well as an expensive task when the area concerned is northern Europe's biggest and most intact medieval town.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 21 -- A four-day poverty conference on education and black power ended here this weekend, and the man who helped organize it described it this way:
OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 21 -- The New York Rangers ended an unusual, but productive five-game road trip last night with a 3-0 victory over the Oakland Seals.
WINNIPEG, Manitoba -- Canada's wheat export boom is over. Prices are down and so is the volume of wheat farmers can sell. The glorious days of the middle 1960's seem to be fading into history.

The Soviet-American agreement on a draft non-proliferation treaty should prove significant not only in checking the spread of nuclear weapons but in advancing the prospect of further accords on arms control and other issues.

Lieut. Thomas R. Gilligan, who shot and killed a 15-year-old Negro shortly before the 1964 riots in Harlem and the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, is being retired by the Police Department because of a back injury.
OTTAWA, -- Canada has begun a year of stimulating promise in political activity -- and of sober prospects in economic development.
ELSINORE, Denmark, Jan. 21 -- Opposition candidates came to Hamlet country this weekend to campaign against the Government of Premier Jens Otto Krag.
MIAMI -- Cuba's fluctuating, state-controlled economy appears to be heading for a new decline after a modest and limited gain in 1967.
SYDNEY, Nova Scotia -- "This is the worst rotten town in the world," the youth said as he maneuvered the taxi through the slush.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Supreme Court refused today to hear the appeal of William Epton, the leader of the Harlem Progressive Labor Movement, who was convicted of encouraging Negroes to riot in Harlem in July, 1964.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI) -- The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield, said today that a "national disaster" faced American cities because the Vietnam war had drained energy, attention and money from the country's problems at home.
Short-term interest rates declined yesterday despite news of credit-tightening moves by the Bank of Canada.

District Attorney Aaron E. Koota of Brooklyn will open a grand jury investigation today into alleged fraud by a trucking concern that runs a city antipoverty program to train young men as truck drivers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Supreme Court let stand today a lower court ruling that a verse recited by kindergarten children in De Kalb, Ill., was an unconstitutional prayer, although the word God had been deleted.

PATERSON, N. J., Jan. 22 -- A woman described as a witness to the murder of Mrs. Judith Kavanaugh nearly two years ago said in a statement today that the accusation was "a deliberate and knowing fabrication."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
PARIS, Jan. 22 (Reuters) -- President de Gaulle lost his parliamentary majority today when a Tahitian deputy announced he was leaving the right-wing Gaullist group in the National Assembly.

The Queens District Attorney is investigating the World's Fair Corporation and others in connection with charges of kickbacks and unwarranted expenditures in the construction of the Belgian Village exhibit.
" It puts the finger in the dike, but nobody has shut off the flood water."

TORONTO, Jan. 22 (UPI) -- Medical experts reported today that they could find "no evidence" to support an assertion by Dr. Gordon Murray that he had devised an operation to rejoin and regenerate the severed spinal cords of paralytics.

The Houston Cougars, who ended the unbeaten string of the University of California, Los Angeles, at 47 games, toppled the Bruins from first place in The Associated Press' college basketball poll yesterday, while taking over the lead themselves by an overwhelming margin.

An oceanographic specialist who helped recover the hydrogen bomb that fell near the coast of Spain two years ago said yesterday that finding the wreckage of the B-52 that crashed off Greenland should be easier.

The Newark Evening News decided yesterday to change the name of a special New York edition that will appear beginning today to avoid a conflict over using five columnists whose work appears in The New York Post.
A sharp decline of public confidence in Congress, to its lowest point in the last five years, was reported in the latest poll by Louis Harris, published yesterday in The New York Post.

DONALD MCKAYLE, who brought his dance company to the Opera House of the Brooklyn Academy on Saturday night, has established himself as one of our leading modern-dance choreographers. Recently his company has been on a very extensive tour of Europe with a program called "Black New World," while Mr. McKayle has been choreographing a musical in London.
DETROIT, Jan. 22 -- The Chrysler Corporation proposed today to "adopt" a largely Negro high school in the city's riot area.

GREENVILLE, S. C., Jan. 22 (AP) -- The announcement over the weekend by the Textile Workers Union of America of intensification of its five-year effort to unionize the J. P. Stevens Co. plants was followed today by a company statement that the drive came from union leaders, not from Stevens employes.

With much dismay I read the article "Nation's Police Arming for Riots" in your Jan. 18 issue. That same issue reported that President Johnson, in his State of the Union address, dismissed the "sense of restlessness" that has arisen in America as "ripples in the wake of a great ship."

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 22 -- About 150 left-wing demonstrators protested tonight in front of the United States Embassy after word arrived of the crash off Greenland yesterday of a United States B-52 carrying hydrogen bombs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Following are excerpts from a commentary in Nhan Dan, the official North Vietnamese party newspaper, as broadcast by the Hanoi radio and made available by American sources here:
MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 22 -- A second Long Island school-bus strike, adding 12,100 public and parochial school pupils to the 55,000 pupils already without service, was called today.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 22 (UPI) -- A hooded gunman attacked a Baltimore teamster official with a metal pipe tonight, knocked him to the ground, then stood over him and fired four bullets into an arm and a leg.

A bundle of a new type of mutation mink brought $240 a skin at a sale of the New York Auction Company, Inc., here yesterday. The bundle was among 3,600 skins owned by breeders in the Great Lakes Mink Association and sold under the trade name of Jet Black.

IN Dave Bing's basketball debut as a professional, he found himself on the same court with the great Oscar Robertson and a sensation of total awe descended on Detroit's rookie from Syracuse University.

SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 22 -- The mission of the 31 armed North Korean infiltrators who attacked South Korean policemen and civilians in Seoul last night was said to have been to raid the presidential mansion and kill the President, Gen. Chung Hee Park.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Government's top economist told Congress today that failure to enact a tax increase now could be justified only by a belief that the economy was headed into a slowdown. Any such possibility, he said, is "remote."
MIAMI, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The favored entry of Polyfoto and Reet Lass finished first and third today in the eighth race at Hialeah, with On Your Mark II getting home second.

OSSINING, N. Y., Jan. 22 (AP) -- Two priests and a num of the Maryknoll order, directed to come home from Guatemala because of their activities with guerrillas, will meet only concern and forgiveness if they do so, a Maryknoll spokesman said today.
LONDON, Jan. 22 -- An experiment in computerized traffic control started today in the western part of London, the most congested area in the city.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 22 -- Three combined platoons of United States marines and South Vietnamese militiamen pulled back today into their central strongpoint at Khesanh. Following the military withdrawal from civilian areas, hundreds of villagers boarded helicopters for Danang, 110 miles to the southeast.

The Royal Philharmonic Orchestra, at the tag end of a 22-city North American tour, came to Carnegie Hall last night for the first of two concerts there. For a variety of reasons, the orchestra that the late Sir Thomas Beecham built did not sound up to its own best standards, and occasionally slipped into fullblown mediocrity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy says Senator Robert F. Kennedy would "have a fight on his hands" if he tried to take over command of anti-Johnson Democrats just before the Democratic National Convention.
TRENTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The New Jersey Supreme Court today ordered an insurance company to pay $29,000 in a negligence suit, although the policy in question had a $20,000 limit.

Mayor Lindsay signed into law yesterday bills to require the posting of polluted beaches and to stiffen the penalties for those who dump refuse illegally on vacant lots. However, he reserved decision on a controversial bill that would require the transparent packaging of meat.
Ron Swoboda took an economics examination at New York University yesterday morning, then went out to Shea Stadium and showed the Mets what supply and demand is all about.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Jan. 22 (UPI) -- A storm-battered Dutch freighter and the 16-member crew that abandoned it were safe in port today, but it could be some time before the crew gets the ship back.
The Columbia Broadcasting System will televise on Tuesday, April 2, an hour-long behind-the-scenes study of the Vietcong.

The widely diversified Transamerica Corporation announced yesterday in San Francisco plans to expand into the computer services field. It has formed a new subsidiary, the Transamerica Computer Company, and has elected James J. Ritter president of the new unit.
The American Electric Power Company announced last night plans to acquire the Columbus and Southern Ohio Electric Company through an exchange of stock valued at about $272-million.
A Congressional move to limit commercial bank ownership of small business investment companies appears to have backfired -- at least partially.

SOME powerful distributional hands qualify for a forcing opening but experts choose to open them quietly with a one-bid. The South hand shown in the diagram is example. Those using traditional strong two-bids can bid two diamonds with the intention of bidding hearts on the next round, but this method is out of favor among tournament players.
TRENTON, Jan. 22 -- The overwhelming Republican majority in the Assembly voted today to repeal the controversial new law providing weekly unemployment benefits to strikers.
LONDON, Jan. 22 -- The Times of London reported tonight that Greece would become a "guided democracy" under the revised constitution drafted by a commission of jurists.
Steel mills last week posted the largest week-to-week production increase in two months, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
HOT CREEK VALLEY, Nev., Jan. 22 (UPI) -- An underground nuclear explosion here last week left a 4,000-foot-long crack in the level, sage-covered desert terrain.

Foreigners running on an American indoor track for the first time often finish their races -- if they finish -- with battle fatigue. They are elbowed, kicked, pushed, bumped and bruised. In short, they are treated like any other runners in a sport in which self-preservation is as important as speed and endurance.
Sales and earnings of Trans World Airlines, Inc., rose sharply last year, it reported here yesterday.

School Superintendent Bernard E. Donovan, reacting to last week's attack on a junior high school principal, asked the Board of Education yesterday for an emergency allocation of $1.25-million to establish a security force in the city's public schools.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the seizure of a labor union's records to help convict a union official violated constitutional guarantees against unreasonable search and seizure.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 22 -- Gov. Claude Kirk of Florida is about as shy and retiring as his state's tourist promotion ads. Asked here the other day what he thought about speculation that he might be chosen to run for Vice President on the Republican ticket, he recoiled as if he had been confronted with a California orange.
For the last couple of years, Leber Productions has been turning out television commercials in what was once the Walt Whitman School, just off Second Avenue on 63d Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The leaders of the United Automobile Workers union appear inclined to delay a policy showdown with the A.F.L.-C.I.O until after the November election.
Once upon a time, when sports meant only fun and games, you could look out the window and tell which sport was in season. Summer meant baseball, autumn meant football, winter meant basketball.
Milwaukee and Phoenix, Ariz., were added to the National Basketball Association yesterday, giving the 22-year-old professional league 14 teams for next season.

BONN, Jan. 22 -- A ranking member of the West German Parliament charged today that the United States and other Western allies were using wire-tapping and postal-inspection rights here to obtain West German industrial secrets for companies in their own countries.

City Council President Frank D. O'Connor said yesterday there were "a growing number of indications this city has never been more vulnerable and wide open, not only in gambling and narcotics, but also prostitution and obscenity."

HONG KONG, Jan. 22 -- Peking has decreed that Communist China's students will have no winter vacation this year in a move to keep them in school in order to prevent a resurgence of the turmoil that prevailed last year.

In many circles it is common belief that insurance companies are constantly fleecing the public, especially with respect to automobile insurance. Nothing could be further from the truth. One needs only to consult the records of the New York State Insurance Department (which is universally conceded to be the most efficient in the entire country) to verify the truth of this statement.

The lawyer for the Harlem widow who collected $56,000 in a protracted defamation-of-character suit against Adam Clayton Powell went back to court yesterday to seek an expected $1-million in additional damages.
PARIS, Jan. 22 -- American manufacturers and store buyers are not boycotting the Paris haute-couture collections despite rumors here that many of them would not show up.

THE drama of the downtown auction lures many a housewife away from her dust mop and dirty dishes. It offers more excitement than a television soap opera and more suspense than an Alfred Hitchcock production.
